PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is leaving Australia today and will return on 21 June. In the Prime Minister's absence, the Honourable Lionel Bowen will be Acting Prime Minister.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Lump Sum Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth: Their opposition to any change in the taxation of lump sum superannuation.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reflect our opposition to any changes in the taxation of lump sum superannuation by voting against any such motions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Housing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of we, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:

In the pursuance of justice and fair play, the government's taxation portion must be removed from the home purchasers time payments and transferred to a small levy or taxation deduction from all wages and income in all aspects, including the home purchasers and not this grossly unfair crippling procedure that exists today.
From the foundations to the last coat of paint, interest and inflation expectations are applied to the family homes with interest rates of unreasonable magnitude to the completed structure.
Truly, this is a national monetary obligation, particularly in as far as the home purchaser is concerned and a major cause of wage demands and the grass roots of inflation.
We therefore humbly pray that your House take urgent action to apply such a percentage levy or taxation.

PETITION.TITLE: Scullin Health Centre, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Australian Capital Territory respectfully showeth:

That being mindful of the important role that the variety of Community Health Centres play in the provision of health care for the citizens of the Australian Capital Territory and of the vital part played by Scullin Health Centre in the provision of such care in Central and Southern Belconnen, are distressed at the uncertainty over the possible closure or disruption of current medical, paramedical and ancilliary services at that Centre.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will prevail upon the Minister for Health to take no action that would in any way affect the continuity of operation of all existing services at the Scullin Health Centre or diminish services to patients, professional and other staff at that Centre until the report of the Task Force on the structure of the Capital Territory Health Commission has been published and the community served by that Centre has been fully consulted.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President, and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that ''The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State''. And whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
1. Undue cost to the nation at this time.

2. ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

3. The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
4. The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Boswell (from 5,622 citizens), Hill (from 156 citizens) and Walters (from 55 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia, believing that men and women are equal but different, convinced that Australia can provide equal opportunity for all citizens without foreign treaties, concerned that ratifying the UN Discrimination Convention would give a Communist-dominated international committee the power to judge Australia's laws, humbly petition that your Honourable House will not ratify the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women.
And we will always thus petition.

(a) recognises that major capital development programmes
(1) have the potential to create long-term employment opportunities which would not otherwise be available, especially for unskilled and semi-skilled workers;

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Button) agreed to:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Senate proceeding forthwith with the matter of public importance submitted to the President this day.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Chaney proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's election confidence trick in promising one thing and doing another and its sorry record of mismanagement and maladministration.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition brings forward this matter of public importance for discussion in what are the closing days of the first parliamentary period of the new Government. We bring forward for discussion the statement, 'The Government's election confidence trick in promising one thing and doing another and its sorry record of mismanagement and maladministration.' It is quite clear how this debate is going to be conducted. The Government has made that quite clear by the way it has started shouting, catcalling and carrying on before any- thing has been said. I suppose the Government's attitude to debate in this place is best summed up by referring to the handwritten note which was tabled by Senator Walsh yesterday as the information which he had used as his guide to answering questions in this place. We find, underneath references to what has happened to gross domestic product, the words, in Senator Walsh's handwriting, 'Bucket Howard'. That, I suggest, shows the standard of debate we can expect from Government senators. They have nothing to do with argument; all they wish to do is enter into vulgar abuse. The matter of public importance which I have brought forward raises a number of major concerns about the three-month-old Government of Mr Hawke. The first concern is the way it gained office, promising one thing and setting out to do another. The second broad area is its record of mismanagement and maladministration.

SPEECH.PARA: Government senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Government senators might like to howl me down but the case can be made out against the Government simply by quoting the Government itself. The Government, the Australian Labor Party and Mr Hawke are damned out of their own mouths. Honourable senators do not have to rely on what was said by politicians from the Opposition or on what was said by journalists to make out this case; they have only to look at what was said before and after the election. If there is any query about whether this is a Government of broken promises I invite the people of Australia and honourable senators opposite to read what Labor said before the election and to read what it has said since the election about what it is doing.

SPEECH.PARA: If there are queries about maladministration in this Government let us not enter into dispute and let us not worry about disputed areas; let us look at the area where the Government has admitted to maladministration and failure on the part of its Ministers. Mr Hawke has had to carpet a series of Ministers in the first three months of this Government. It cannot be denied by Government senators that there has been maladministration in this Government when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has had to pull Senator Evans up over his use of the Royal Australian Air Force against the civil Government of Tasmania-the spy flights. The Prime Minister has reproved Senator Evans about that piece of maladministration. The Prime Minister has had to reprove Mr Young for his loose- mouthed approach to security matters. The Prime Minister has had to reproach his Minister, Mr West, for speaking against the Government on wages policy. The Prime Minister has had to reprove Mr John Brown for his extraordinary anti- tourism statements. So this is not a matter of the Opposition saying that there is maladministration; the Prime Minister has made it quite clear that he regards his own Ministers as having engaged in maladministration during the early months of the Government.

The admitted list is enough to give substance to this debate today. But let us look at some of the not admitted examples of maladministration. Not one Government senator could look himself in the eye and say that these are not examples of maladministration. Consider Senator Evans's copybook demonstration on how not to protect the civil liberties of David Combe. Senator Evans is not here but we know what high regard Government senators have for his protection of the civil liberties of Mr Combe and how ably he was assisted by Mr Young with his loose-mouthed approach to national security! Who else in the Government was guilty of the same sort of behaviour? Nobody sitting opposite would really defend Mr Bowen for his gratuitous entry into the foreign affairs field in suggesting a peacekeeping force involving Japan in Kampuchea. That is an indefensible situation. It is typical of the early record of this Government.

I return to the broken promises part of this debate. Even briefly to list and describe the promises which have been broken by this Government would take more than the 20 minutes which is allotted to me in this debate. But the central concern which I put forward is the promise which the ALP, Mr Hawke and every major Labor Party spokesman made before the election that they would change the Fraser Government's economic policy. There is no doubt what was meant by that. The Labor spokesmen from Mr Hawke down promised to change Australia's economic policy. They made it quite clear that they would change to an expansionary economic policy because they claimed that was the solution to Australia's woes. Let us look at what was said by Mr Hawke and in the official documents of the Labor Party. We were told before the election in Labor's national recovery and reconstruction plan:
The principal cause of our continually poor economic performance and our current alarming decline has been the constant contraction and eventual collapse of the demand for goods and services.
That is a direct quote from Labor's own document. Labor's document also stated:

The principal thrust of Labor's economic strategy will be to reject the policies of contraction and embrace the policies of expansion . . . the achievement of these aims requires a substantial change in national economic policies to urgently lift demand . . . Labor will not wait until the 1983-84 budget to commence this recovery program. Immediate action will be taken to stimulate activity in key sections.
What did Labor say before the election? Again I quote from the Australian Labor Party policy speech, which stated:

Recovery can only be achieved and sustained by a change to national economic policies which lift and sustain demand. There can be no lift in profits or a lift in growth unless there is a lift in demand. And that cannot be done by taking money out of the weekly pay packet or the pensioner's cheque.

What a wonderful quote when Labor has already done so much to lift out many dollars from the weekly pay packet of Australian taxpayers and when it has already lifted money from the pensioner's cheque! What has come about is a complete reversal, in rhetoric, at least, but also in those actions which have taken place and further in what was promised to the Australian people-a policy of expansion.

I will not again go through all of the quotes from the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) which bear this out. I simply remind the Senate of the sorts of actions which have been taken.We have a government which suddenly is deeply conscious of the deficit-I will talk more about that a little later-yet it is a government which said that it would throw away the calculators. We have a government which is pursuing tighter monetary targets and yet it is a government which abused us, when it was in opposition, for a fetish about monetarism. We have a government which is taking away the purchasing power of the Australian people by the loss of the tax concession on health benefits, which affects 70 per cent of our families, and by the loss of the tax deduction for housing interest which again affects many millions of Australians. We have the complete reversal of form. That is the most serious allegation which can be made of this Government: It has turned on its head the central promise that it made to the Australian people.

If one looks in detail at what was done by the Government-I will do so very quickly-the broken promises become readily apparent. The Prime Minister promised 'immediate reductions in income tax'. We know that instead there have been increases. He promised to 'retain the tax rebate for home loan payments'. That, of course, has gone. He promised to introduce a first home ownership assistance scheme as 'an option to the existing deposit assistance scheme, which will be retained'. He promised not to increase tax on lump sum superannuation. We know what has happened there. He promised not to take 'money out of the weekly pay packet'. We know what has happened on that matter. He promised not to take money out of 'the pensioner's cheque' and we know what has happened there.

He promised not to abandon the Alice Springs-Darwin railway and we know what has happened to that promise. He promised to continue the Government's major airport development program, including the upgrading of airport facilities in Brisbane, and we know what has happened there. He promised to reduce the price of petrol by 3c litre and, after the price of oil had dropped $5 a barrel, he gave one half of what he had promised and effectively ignored the change in the world price of $5. We know what has happened there. He promised to move to achieve fixed term four-year parliaments but he gave that away and decided he would have a flutter with three-year fixed term parliaments. Now he has backed off that proposal. He promised to retain the health insurance rebate until the introduction of Medicare and that promise has been broken too. That is as sorry a litany as one could imagine after a short three months in government. Labor has completely overturned what it promised the electorate both in detail and in the broad thrust of what it is doing.

Let us look at why this has occurred. It has occurred for two reasons: One is a stated reason and one is an unstated reason. The stated reason is a budgetary problem that the Government-surprise, surprise-discovered for itself when it was elected to government and the unstated reason is that Government senators and the Labor Party were so desperate to get into government that they were prepared to promise anything that would achieve that end. I will deal with that after I have looked at the question of the Budget deficit. When Labor come to government Mr Hawke very quickly made the position clear. He said in the Governor-General's Speech:

My new Government has inherited a budgetary deficit problem of an unprecedented magnitude. A comprehensive review of budgetary commitments, both in terms of outlays and taxation expenditures, has been set in train.

So on the first day of this new Parliament, Mr Hawke's professed horror at the size of next year's deficit was to become the standard excuse for the wholesale breaking of promises. We are now told that a party which before the election put no discernible limit on Budget deficits finds that a prospective deficit of roughly $10 billion is simply not on. With a weary regularity, particularly in this chamber, we have heard over the last month the mythical $9.6 billion figure trotted out. Of course, we know that one honourable senator opposite at least thought that that was the figure for this financial year-a nice comment on the degree of knowledge that exists on the Government benches.

But what is the truth behind that figure? That claim, I believe, is clearly and publicly now quite discredited. The fact is that Labor did not care when it made its promises whether it could afford them or not and it made them before there was any public estimate of the deficit on the part of the then Government. But having won office by promising what it had no intention of ever providing, the Government had to find an excuse, and it had to find that excuse both for the electorate and for its own back bench which had gone to the election on the basis of expansionist policies. As the Sydney Morning Herald's economic editor wrote on 24 March:

I've always believed that the $9.6 billion estimate is exaggerated and misleading . . . it is based on an excessively pessimistic forecast for the level of economic activity and employment growth in 1983-84.

He added that Mr Hawke himself had already said that the Labor Government's 10 per cent devaluation would alone reduce the deficit by up to $500m. But if the figure was out of date by March it was certainly destroyed by April when the National Economic Summit Conference documents indicated that a more realistic projection would be around $8.5 billion because economic growth was likely to be around 2.7 per cent rather than the 0.5 per cent that Mr Hawke had told journalists was the basis of the discredited $9.6 billion. Since then this phoney figure has been further discredited, along with those who continue to pretend that it means something.

It is worth recalling that the former Treasurer, Mr Howard, at all times has rejected the $9.6 billion figure on the same basis as the Sydney Morning Herald- that growth figures were far too low. It was only after persistent questioning, and that questioning was met with the usual tirade of personal abuse that we get , that this economic genius, Senator Walsh, who has been parading himself in that guise for so long, admitted yesterday that the deficit figure he deceptively misused was something less than the $9.6 billion. This very reluctant admission from the now discredited Minister for Resources and Energy ( Senator Walsh) was nevertheless accompanied by an attempt again to mislead the Senate about the growth and deficit figures. His desperation to maintain his phoney excuse for breaking his promises and rejecting his own party's big spending programs led him to yesterday's farce over the document he tabled at Question Time. That document, which was tabled at Senator Messner's request, was in Senator Walsh's own handwriting. He cannot claim, like Senator Evans, that it just came off an automatic typewriter. He cannot pretend that he did not understand it.

That document revealed that Senator Walsh deliberately misled the House when he denigrated the former Treasurer's claim that there had been a major increase in economic growth forecasts affecting the deficit from the 0.5 per cent gross domestic product rise on which the superseded $9.6 billion figure was based. Senator Walsh said the figure should have been only 1.5 per cent and tried to suggest that the deficit had been cut only by about $200m by the recently improved growth forecasts. That is another attempt to confuse. Senator Walsh's tabled document clearly shows that the 1.5 per cent relates only to non-farm gross domestic product. He was trying to hide a further cut in the size of next year's forecast deficit of about $500m-that is, of course, if the analysis of the Economic Summit documents are to be believed, and they certainly have more credibility than Senator Walsh.

So, the simple fact of the matter is that the Government has been trying to maintain a fiction in this Parliament. Frankly, we do not know for certain exactly how wrong the $9.6 billion estimate is because the Government has not yet done the Parliament the courtesy of telling us the figures that it has been prepared to reveal in background briefings to the media. What we do know is that it is wrong by a very considerable amount, probably by about $1.5 billion. Not even the campaign which the Government has run has been able to hide that from the Australian people. Indeed, most leading journalists have exposed the deception.

The Australian pointed out last week that if the Treasurer admitted that the new forecasts were for greater economic growth, then he would have to admit the big deficit being touted by the Government was just so rubbery as to be unbelievable. The Australian Financial Review talked of the 'myth' of the $9.6 billion deficit and said that after the revised growth figures it is now inoperative. The National Times said:
. . . it is now largely an irrelevant figure . . . the improved outlook for growth in 1983-84 could reduce the size of the prospective deficit by up to $1 1 /2 billion.

The Sydney Morning Herald said that the new economic growth projections are casting doubt on the validity of the $9.6 billion that is Mr Hawke's justification for breaking his promises. The article stated:
. . . it is dying as a political justification . . . improved growth estimates must mean a lower deficit.

So the Press has seen through these phoney measures and I believe the Australian people have seen through them. The question remaining to be answered is this: Why did this Government set out to make promises which it knows cannot be kept and then set about so freely breaking them in the first quarter of Government, following the pattern established so ably by Mr Cain, Mr Bannon and Mr Burke? Now that this Government is in office it says it cannot afford to carry out any of the promises it so glibly made to the Australian people.

I believe there is a quite simple explanation as to why these extravagant promises were made and why they have been broken as, of course, they had to be broken-it was because the Australian Labor Party was desperate to win office. The simple truth is in what was said by Senator Button in an interview which was reported in the Weekend Australian of 16 April. Senator Button was trying to explain his part in deposing the Labor leader, Mr Hayden. He was trying to explain how it came about that the Labor leader could be brought down so mercilessly by the Labor Party. The article in the Weekend Australian states:

Button rationalises his motives in terms of his past. 'Late last year, there was a feeling of total hopelessness around this place. It's hard to understand now. I had the feeling we just had to win the next election. If we didn't, the party would split and we'd have 25 years in opposition.'

This sorry mess is because of the desperation of the Labor Party to get into government. The fact is that the party will split anyway because of its total failure to stick to the principles it has put before the Australian people and by its total failure to behave in an honourable way since it came into government. I believe this Government in its first quarter is in its sorriest state that Australia has ever seen in the early years of a government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we arrived this morning and read the matter of public importance which had been sent to the President we wondered just what the Opposition was about. We are concerned, of course, as everyone should be, because democracy requires that there be a strong , active, thoughtful and constructive Opposition. This Opposition is none of those things. That is demonstrated by the fact that it brings down a matter of public importance today at a time when, although things are improving, unemployment is at a record level, inflation is too high, and the economy is still not expanding as much as any of us would like as a result of the previous Government's policies. Yet all that Opposition members raise is a nit-picking, nonsensical matter of public importance like this.

SPEECH.PARA: To lead the debate we had the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) who, I must say, is not much of an opening bowler. I think he is probably best described the way Geoffrey Boycott described an English opening bowler yesterday : 'He runs in like Dennis Lillee and he delivers with the pace of Denis Thatcher '. What sort of a performance is it in a time of economic stress like this when all Senator Chaney can do is to come into this place, and raise a matter of public importance dealing with broken promises. All we have had from the likes of Senator Chaney and honourable senators opposite is talk of broken promises. Senator Chaney commenced his speech by complaining about the way we got into government, the way we gained office. I remind honourable senators opposite that we gained office at an election at a time picked by the previous Prime Minister and on issues picked by the previous Prime Minister. At an election that was called early because the Prime Minister thought it was the best time to go there was an overwhelming vote against the former Government and for this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in Tasmania.

—That is how we came to power, and that is why Senator Walters is sitting where she is. I think she will have to get used to it. Honourable senators opposite will have to put a few constructive ideas before the people of this country before they get back into power. I suggest that they will have to do much better than Senator Chaney has done today.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney's main problem seems to have been the economic statement of 19 May. According to Senator Chaney, it seems that we were not radical enough. It seems to me that Senator Chaney is concerned that we had some concern for the Budget deficit in this country. I think anyone who is responsible should be concerned about the Budget deficit. I remind Senator Chaney that, when that statement was brought down, it was greeted well by the Press. It was considered to be a responsible statement. The measures contained in it were considered to be responsible by the vast majority of economic commentators in this country, the leaders of industry and particularly the superannuation and insurance industries that were directly affected.

On 24 May 1979 another economic statement or mini-Budget was brought down which caused quite a different reaction in this country and in this place. It was at that time that Senator McLaren came into this chamber with the famous newspaper headline, 'Lies, Lies, Lies'. The mini-Budget was described in the Illawarra Mercury and in every other newspaper in this country as a savage mini-Budget which broke two promises on income tax and announced big cuts in government expenditure. It was condemned all over the country because it broke promises and because it was a contractionary document. It received a much different response from the Press than that which was received by our economic statement.

If the previous Government had attempted at any time to enforce the standards of honour which are implied in this matter of public importance by Senator Chaney it would not have lasted in its first week, and Senator Chaney knows it. The former Government was led by a person whom I realise Senator Chaney admires very greatly because every time anyone mentions his name in this place Senator Chaney jumps to his feet to defend him. It was led by a Prime Minister who had previously stabbed in the back two leaders of the Liberal Party. It was led by a Prime Minister who achieved power by conniving with a Governor-General and others at the time. For seven shameful years it was led by a leader who said:
When you go into an election with a commitment in 1980 I think it is nonsense to suggest that a commitment made in 1975 on the same subject overrides the one made five years later.

This was a man who changed his commitments, changed his promises and broke his promises all the time. The Liberals never intended to keep the promises they made in election campaigns. They never kept to the principles they espoused either in opposition or in government. Who will ever forget the Malcolm Fraser line on the unemployment benefit when he was a shadow Minister in 1974? He said then that, as unemployment increased so should the level of the unemployment benefit so that it would, after prolonged unemployment, reach the minimum wage. That was the policy and the promise of the former Prime Minister who reduced the unemployment benefit, inflicted on the single unemployed a reduction in the unemployment benefit through non-indexation and considerably reduced the standard of living of under 18-year-old unemployed persons by not increasing their unemployment benefit at all from 1975 to 1982. This was the Liberal leader , the leader whom the present Opposition so slavishly followed.

This was the Liberal leader who said that a Labor government should have resigned because unemployment in this country had reached 190,000, yet who, in government, oversaw an increase in unemployment to 700,000 on any estimate. Probably, if we consider hidden unemployment, it had reached about one million at the end of his Government's time. But he would never have resigned. What he did was blame the unemployed, their parents, the educational system, the trade unions. He probably would have blamed anyone within this country, within this world, or within this universe if he could have. For all of that time the present Opposition senators continued to sit obediently behind him, to applaud everything he did, to applaud his policies, in particular his promise in 1975 that there would be jobs for all who needed them; yet, at the same time, they oversaw this great increase in unemployment.

I think that we should look quickly at some of the things that were promised. I am sure that Senator Richardson, who will be speaking on this matter for our side, will look at some others. But we have to remember that the previous Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, promised to bring down taxes, not to increase them. In fact, he ended up leading the Government which was the highest taxing government in the history of Australia. The previous Government's taxation measures in its last seven Budgets took $203 billion from the pockets of Australian taxpayers; that is, as much tax was collected in seven years under the Fraser Government as the combined total of all taxes that were collected in the previous 75 years since Federation.

In 1977, during the election campaign speech of Mr Fraser, the present Leader of the Opposition sat on the platform and clapped while his leader said: 'We have ended the big tax rip-off'. Now the Senate is kept here day after day protecting the very people responsible for exploring every tiny loophole in the law, who have ripped-off the community by the infamous bottom-of-the-harbour and other schemes, making the low income earners cough up and pay for that tax evasion and avoidance. To keep the tax evasion industry in luxury, in 1976 the Fraser Government introduced legislation which imposed a discriminatory tax on the children and spouses of the unemployed, people whose standard of living is miserable, who should have been protected by the Fraser Government's Ministers for Social Security and who should have been protected by those who were in the Fraser Government who in fact expressed concern for groups such as this. But in fact what happened was that taxation of their benefits was introduced while the income tax evasion industry continued to expand.

As I say, we sit here day after day with members of the Opposition trying to stop legislation which will end, once and for all, the tax avoidance and tax evasion industry and will have people repay to the taxpayers and to the Government of this country some of the ill-gotten gains that they have received over recent years. Yet no more clear promise and no more clear mandate was given to any government than our mandate to introduce this legislation and to carry through with this recoupment of the taxation which was evaded and avoided over all this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —If that were what it was you would get it through.

—We cannot get it through because a quite clear promise has been made that Senator Peter Baume and his colleagues, who are so concerned about these people, will hold up its passage and, if possible, defeat it. I believe that we should now look at what has happened since we came to government. We should remind the Opposition just what this legislation is all about. We came to government with a very large win in the election. We came to government with a series of promises, but in particular with promises to do something about unemployment, to do something about the deplorable standard of living of those who were suffering from unemployment, to do something about the redistribution of the wealth of this community to those who in fact needed assistance. We realised that all this would not be easy to do quickly and that the next Budget would be a difficult one. But we also quickly realised that something had to be done before the next Budget; hence the economic statement from Mr Keating; hence the new policy proposals which were introduced by Mr Keating at that stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Within three days of our being sworn in, before that economic statement, and before anything else was done, we increased the unemployment benefit for single unemployed people which had fallen way below the poverty line and which is still way below the poverty line despite the increase. Prior to the increase, the benefit for single people was less than half the married rate. We did that very quickly because it was an election promise and because the unemployed are a disadvantaged group in the community. In the economic statement we introduced measures to increase employment through the Community Works Program and the housing program, to increase the expenditure on public housing and to increase the assistance to first home owners to create a stimulus in the housing industry . All these measures were welcomed by the housing industry, builders, building societies and every right thinking person in this country. Those measures are condemned only by the nitpickers in the Opposition.

We took our first step in the budgetary process to reform the superannuation industry and the treatment of superannuation payments in this country which had been advocated in 1979 by the previous Treasurer, which had been talked about in 1981 by the previous Minister for Social Security and which had been recommended by the Hancock National Superannuation Committee of Inquiry and the Asprey Taxation Review Committee. We did all those things and they were welcomed by the insurance companies in the community and by reasonable and moderate economic writers. I commend to Senator Peter Baume and others here the article by Yvonne Preston in the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday which pointed out the unfortunate nature of the debate in this area. Of course, the measures were opposed by a few people who saw their privileged positions and their vested interests affected. But in fact the vast majority of sensible people in the community welcomed those moves.

In the next Budget we will have to review certain areas of expenditure as we have had to review certain areas of the previous Government's expenditure. Yesterday we had a series of notices of motion in this place on the Bicentennial Water Resources Program from honourable senators allegedly representing the interests of the various States. There is no one in the community, and in fact no honest person in the Opposition, who does not admit that that Bicentennial Water Resources Program was in fact dreamt up as a gimmick. No one-not even Senator Sir John Carrick if he is at all honest-can deny that the Fraser Government went to the bottom drawer and dragged out every water resources program that had ever been suggested, including some that were not approved by the States involved. The then Government then stuck them all in something called the Water Resources Program and put it up as an election gimmick. Yet the Prime Minister of the day and the Treasurer of the day knew quite well that the projected Budget deficit was such that the Government would have to cut expenditure considerably and that that program would be the first expenditure that it would cut. It was a phoney program and the Opposition knows it. Yet yesterday we had a parade of people from each State saying that we should restore to the economic program all those fairy tales that had been introduced by the previous Government. Senator Chaney came in here today suggesting-Senator Martin suggested it yesterday and today-that the new construction and changes to Brisbane Airport have been halted and will not proceed and that Brisbane will not get its new airport. Senator Martin, in her usual sensitive way, will doubtless now seek to make a personal explanation. That is clearly the implication of what she was saying yet she knows, and Senator Chaney knows, that the Brisbane Airport will proceed-the order of works will change, but certainly it will be completed.

Phoney water programs were introduced by the previous Government, with no intention of ever carrying them out. The present Government realised that it had to review programs such as those. We realised the sort of political capital that honourable senators opposite would attempt to make of the review that we had to do, but we had to do it. We did it because it was necessary for the economic development of, and sensible budgeting in this country, and we will continue to do it. I do not think anyone in this community envies the role of the Government in having to take over the sort of deficit problem that we have taken over, having to take over the country at a time of record unemployment, having to take over at a time of high inflation and record interest rates in the community and having to take over at a time when the world economic situation was such a problem to us. But we are facing the problems that confront this country. We are facing the budgetary problems with courage, common sense and sound economic management, and we will continue to do so.

One would have thought that, in all the nonsense that has been going on here in regard to the three matters of public importance introduced this week, there would have been just one positive suggestion from the previous Government-the present Opposition-but there has been none. Every move taken by the present Government, as set out in the economic statement, every single thing that has been done, has been opposed by the Opposition, which has made not one positive contribution. I ask the Opposition, as I did the other day: If it believes every one of the moves set out in that economic statement has been wrong, what would it have done? The alternative was to let the Budget deficit blow out to $10 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said: 'Throw away the calculators'.
—I do not think even Senator Chaney would believe that we should let the Budget deficit blow out to that extent.
—Senator, you said: 'Throw away the calculators'.

—The honourable senator ought surely to make at least one suggestion. His party has just been defeated. He was recently a senior Minister, in the former Government, but he has no suggestions at all as to what should be done in this country.
—You said: 'Throw away the calculators'.

—Nobody said: 'Throw away the calculators'. We said: 'You need some economic management'. I hope that Senator Peter Baume will now get up and, rather than engage in nit-picking, shouting and rhetoric, say in what respect our economic policy is wrong and, as the Opposition has opposed the Government's every economic move, what alternatives he would propose. Until the Opposition does that it will not be a credible Opposition, and until it is, it will remain in Opposition for a long, long time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —To the public there is no more important matter than the performance of its national Government, and there can be no more relevant time for the performance of its national Government to be examined than at the end of a parliamentary session. That is an appropriate time to look at what the Government has or has not achieved. It is entirely appropriate that we should attempt to make some judgment as to what this new Government has and has not done during its first three months in office. If Senator Grimes wants us to show how the country should be run, he has only to offer to resign. We will gladly take over and show how government can be conducted with competence, honesty and a certain amount of dignity.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government, like all governments, is accountable for all its actions. One of the proper tasks of any Opposition is to set in train that process of accountability. The matter of public importance proposed today is part of that process and enables us to set out some of the failures of the Government in its first three months in office. It is no good Senator Grimes coming in here and holding up newspaper headlines of two years ago. We are talking about the defence and record of this Government, the Government elected this year on this year's promises. It is clear that the Labor Government, which has now been in office for almost three months-almost 90 days-has not displayed competence, any coherence, any cohesiveness in its own ranks, and is not consequential; that is to say, it does not look ahead to what will be the consequences of the things that it proposes I am really forced to the conclusion that many of the broken promises, gaffes, and embarrassments heaped upon embarrassments, are because this Government simply cannot do any better at this stage. It is going down the road of embarrassment and incompetence because it does not know how to do anything else. I hope for the sake of the country that it starts learning, because Australia deserves a national government that is competent, coherent, cohesive and consequential.

The Australian Labor Party and its Government must look at the Government's record of the last three months. They must learn from the lessons and from what they have not done. In three short months-when the Government should have been enjoying its honeymoon and getting nothing but good Press for anything it said or did-we have seen the most amazing series of foul-ups instituted by the Government and done by the Government to itself. It is having difficulty in extricating itself from these problems. We have seen the National Economic Summit Conference with whole sections of the Australian community ignored. We have seen the furtive spy flights over Tasmania. We have seen vicious and unwarranted personal attacks upon the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. We have seen the Star Chamber treatment handed out to a former national secretary of the Australian Labor Party, Mr David Combe. We have seen a Minister leaking national security information. We have seen referendums proposed and then called off again. We have seen a tax recoupment Bill that not only will be unfair in its extent, but also will cost jobs for Australians at a time when jobs are needed.

It is difficult to conceive that a party that has been in office just three months could have achieved such a level of mismanagement; that it could have been involved in such a breach of faith with so many sections of the Australian electorate that gave it its mandate and their trust. It has abandoned the people who put it in office in the expectation of a better chance and a better life. After three months, the party which went to the electorate with rhetorical statements about stable, honest, effective and responsible government-that is how it saw itself-stands condemned not only in this Parliament, but also in the community at large. It stands condemned in the Press and, most interestingly, it is the butt of every cartoonist across the country. The events outlined earlier by my colleague Senator Chaney, the economic mismanagement and the various scandals-this is not some time warp taking us back to the Whitlam era-represent a faithful account of what the Hawke Government has done in just three months, from its first day in office. The Government has moved from sham to shamble.

The Economic Summit, from which so much was expected and which had so much promise, failed the expectations of even Labor's supporters. It was grand in conception and heady in rhetoric, but defective in delivery. What was Labor's idea of bringing Australia together? It was to call a conference of big business , big unions and government. It was a meeting of the haves, who sat down together, at the expense of the have nots, the people the Labor Party purported to represent. That Economic Conference, so grand in its design, failed to take any difficult decisions. The so-called consensus which was reached was only a recognition and statement of problems; it was not an agreement on what the solutions could or should be. The Summit failed to endorse the wages freeze, the one thing which has shown promise of restoring jobs in Australia. Of the options available, it chose the wrong one. It chose the option which, by Treasury's own figuring, would not bring about a return of jobs.

Let us move on from the euphoria of the Summit to the real business of Government which followed, when this Government, which had good will for the start of its term as the elected government of Australia, came to the Parliament and its Ministers began their real work in administering the country. What have we seen since then? We have seen the rough-shod and unnecessary treatment of Tasmania. Leaving the merits of the dam aside, the Labor Party has shown a flagrant disregard for the rights of that State and I think it will show the same disregard for the rights of every other state. I refer to the decision not to proceed with an aircraft carrier capable of taking fixed wing aircraft and the decision on the Fleet Air Arm. Again, leaving the merits of the decisions aside, on each occasion the Government failed to consult with those most concerned; that is, officers of the Royal Australian Navy. It is possible to forgive some of these things. We can put them down to incompetence, naivete, inexperience or ignorance of proper procedures, but the Government's first three months have exposed much more than sheer naivete.

It has been pointed out already that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has had to carpet several of his Ministers: Senator Gareth Evans over the spy flights; Mr Young over the breach of security; Mr West over his statements on wages policy; Mr John Brown-I think one of the cartoons I enjoyed most shows a couple of koalas saying that they would not like to be politicians, either-and Mr Lionel Bowen, who put forward his extraordinary proposal that we should put troops in South East Asia as some kind of peacekeeping force, no doubt a new kind of far- eastern co-prosperity sphere.

The ALP should recall that the Government that preceded it had very strict standards in this kind of case. My very good friends and colleagues Mr MacKellar and Mr Moore, over a very trivial matter, stood aside as Ministers. There is no doubt in our minds that Mr Young, for the breach of national security of which he was guilty, and which is admitted, should have stood down as a Minister. In the action he took he breached the standards which are required of a Minister. He breached them in a matter of national security.

Let us look at the areas of incompetence. The spy flights need not have occurred. We were told that they seemed like a good idea at the time. The pursuit of Tasmania that has taken place need not have occurred. Ministers have been unable to cope in Parliament. In Question Time, in the Senate at least, we have the spectacle of Minister after Minister refusing to answer questions. That need not happen. We had Senator Evans this week refusing to endorse the parliamentary statement by his former leader, Mr Hayden. That need not have occurred. We have the injustice and the leaks concerning Mr Combe. They need not have taken place. We have his total destruction by Government edict. We have the Government forced, unwillingly, to set up a royal commission to try to restore some semblance of decency to a man who has been destroyed by the Government without trial. We have the events which occurred in relation the Australian Broadcasting Commission following a gratuitous off-the-cuff remark in the Senate , which need not have occurred. We have the refusal of the Minister concerned to back up those allegations in the Parliament. What contempt for the place where he is answerable! We have the on-again, off-again referenda. We had Senator Evans's amazing statement this week that he is not responsible for the content of a letter which misled a constituent, simply because it was produced by a word processor. The honourable senator said: 'Do not hold me responsible for what I sign; it came off a word processor'.

Incompetence is one thing, broken promises are another matter. In three months the Government has achieved an impressive record! It has no intention of supporting the arrangements and proposals which came out of the National Economic Summit Conference. What about the average Australian who has been looking forward to job protection and the tax cuts which were promised? Let us talk about tax cuts. I can remember the covering paragraph in the election speech of the Prime Minister regarding taxation. He said:
I believe the Australian people have had enough of election promises made only to be broken. I offer no fistful of dollars to be snatched back after the election.
A few days later he was already reneging. Three days after the election he said:
We will have to reconsider the whole of our program.

What do we have now? The Government has introduced a mini-Budget which taxes Australian families an extra $10 a week. We have had broken promises in the areas of petrol pricing, tyre retreading, fixed wing aircraft, superannuation, education and many others. Some of the promises were broken no doubt because money is tight. But we told the then Opposition that money was tight when it made its promises. We told the then Opposition that it could not fund its promises but it chose not to listen. Perhaps some of the promises have been broken because they were never meant to be kept. Some of them have been broken, we think, just out of spite or incompetence. The Government's punitive measures do not stop there. The Government decided in its mini-Budget to take away rebates available for health insurance nine months before it needed to do so. The Government has decided to hurt Australian families. It is taking action now which will harm jobs and job creation and which will diminish our prosperity rather than increase it. The Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Susan Ryan, put the situation eloquently in a speech she gave last weekend. Lest the Australian people forget, she said:
Our Government is a Democratic Socialist Government: That means that within Australia we are committed to the redistribution of wealth and power.

The Government is going about it. The cartoonists have said it all. A cartoon by Pryor which appeared in the Canberra Times not very long ago depicted a row of unhappy looking Labor Government Ministers, each with a shoe fixed firmly in his mouth and the Prime Minister standing uncomfortably in front and saying: 'Yes, we do have a few teething problems'. Pryor was kind enough to put Mr Hawke's shoe in his pocket ready to go into his mouth when it was needed. The streaker's defence will not do for the kind of things which this Government has done. To declare 'it seemed like a good idea at the time' is not good enough. Let us hope the Government performs better next session because the country needs it. The Courier-Mail described the Government as:
a government lurching around in search of direction, showing clear signs of amateurism.

That is what it is doing. It is maladroit, clumsy, incompetent and non- consequential. Sadly for Australia, Government members seem to be slow learners. The Government, in its first session of parliament, has done poorly; perhaps it still has its 'L' plates up. For the sake of the nation it has to do better. Australians who voted for the Labor Government might be forgiven for saying that 'it seemed like a good idea at the time'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning the Government Whip, Senator Robertson, asked me to speak on this matter of public importance. He read out the terms of it to me and I smiled. I went into a meeting of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and read out the terms of the matter of public importance. Members of the Committee laughed. I think that was because this matter of public importance can best be described as a joke. If it is not a joke, it is the greatest display of hypocrisy this chamber has ever seen. The Government has been in office for 11 weeks. We have had one parliamentary sitting. Already the Hawke Government has introduced the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill and associated Bills for which we had a clear mandate on 5 March to try to get back some hundreds of millions, indeed billions , of dollars which had been ripped off the Australian community by the crooks and cheats who sent all those companies to the bottom of the harbour. Already we have witnessed the spectacle of Opposition senator after senator defending those people and trying to ensure that they keep their ill-gotten gains. They have tried to ensure that the average Australian who has had to pay all of that extra tax will have to keep paying and indeed pay more if the Opposition succeeds in defeating the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: We have introduced the world heritage legislation to try to stop the construction of the dam on the Franklin and Gordon Rivers. The Opposition will be damned forever for trying to ensure that that dam is built. I note Senator Peter Baume's comment: 'The merits of the dam aside'. How can we put aside the merits of the dam? This project would ensure the destruction of the last great area of Australian wilderness. He said that we should put the merits aside. The Hawke Government will not put aside the merits of any issue. It will proclaim those wilderness areas and the construction of that dam will be stopped.

We have introduced legislation to revamp the Australian Broadcasting Commission to make it a corporation. This will prevent the strangulation of the ABC that has occurred over the last seven years and will give it a chance to compete reasonably with the commercial networks for the listening and watching ears and eyes of Australia. We will introduce Medicare in order to have an understandable system which will allow our citizens to live in some dignity and which will provide them with some decent health care. We will not change the system with the seasons every few months to reflect the change on the trees. Each new Minister for Health in the Fraser Government-even one Minister three of four times-changed the health scheme so that now health care in Australia is something that no one can understand, with fewer and fewer people having access to it.

There will be a return to a centralised wage fixing system so that ordinary working Australians will have some rationality in their lives. In the economic statement announced a few days ago, tremendous assistance is provided to first home buyers. The home building industry is pivotal to any economic recovery. I note that even the National Australia Bank, in its last media release, welcomed the recent announcement by the Federal Government of a change in methods of assisting first home buyers.

Most importantly, the Government has announced that hundreds of millions of dollars will be provided for job creation schemes to try to get people working again. Let no one on the other side of the chamber forget that unemployment was the rock upon which the Fraser ship of state foundered and sunk to the depths. I suggest that no government has attempted to keep so many of its promises in such a short time. But the biggest promise of all, the campaign theme of 'bringing Australia together' led the way to the National Economic Summit Conference which was held only a few weeks ago. Why has the Opposition screamed about big business and big unions getting together? Big business, for so long the exclusive preserve of the Liberal-National Party coalition, is a constituency that is being taken away from it, because even big business-the heartland of the Liberal Party- is sick and tired of ineptitude, sick and tired of seeing its profits dwindling, and sick and tired of seeing colleagues and friends go to the wall as business after business closed.

That Economic Summit was called to look at, and try to come to some consensus on, Australia's problems. What problems were faced by the new Hawke Government? My colleague the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, has so often reminded the Senate in the last few days that the great problem on coming to office was that we found we had inherited an expected deficit of $9.6 billion instead of the $6 billion which we had been told again and again, at least during the last few weeks before the election, was the real deficit. I am indebted to Senator Walsh for his contribution to economic parlance. As well as the GDP and the GNP we now have the DFT-the discredited former Treasurer. This term has passed into our parlance and will remain there forever. Mr Howard's first attempt at trying to explain away the big lie of $9.6 billion was to say that it consisted of departmental first bids. I am happy to say that this defence petered out for lack of substance. It lasted only a few days. The admission by silence from Mr Howard was deafening to us all.

What did Mr Fraser have to say? I would still like to know. It is hard to find him these days. I think most Australians would prefer to forget his period in office, as would most members on the other side who very rarely mention his name , let alone recall the things that he had to say. I hope I will have the opportunity in a few minutes to recall some of the things that he said. I am reminded, when speaking of Mr Howard, of the comments made by the current Treasurer, Paul Keating, when he first became the shadow Treasurer only a few months ago. He stated that John Howard had been reduced to the role of a commentator on the economy, unable to introduce any initiatives to fix it and only able to chronicle how badly the economy was going.

Labor's economic promises on tax cuts and stimulating the economy were based on the belief of what Fraser and Howard had to say. If we can be criticised, I suppose that we should be criticised for ever believing anything that they had to say, because their record on broken promises is unparalleled in Australian political history. Right up to Friday, 4 March the $6 billion claim was maintained, although I suppose I have to concede that the then Government had never been too concerned to stick to the figure; it had never been too hard and fast. We should all be reminded that it reviewed that figure on the deficit four times in the six months from when the Budget was announced in August.

We started off with $2.5 billion or $2.7 billion, and each estimate took the figure up and up. Why was that? It was because, as our then shadow Minister, Bob Hawke, now the Prime Minister, had said on Budget night, the figures on unemployment were rubbery, and the books had been cooked. Within weeks Howard had to acknowledge that that was true. Within weeks he had to acknowledge that the estimates for unemployment were wrong, and that the deficit would blow out because more and more Australians would be in dole queues and more and more Australians would not be able to have taxes collected from them.
If we are to look at the record of those who are now trying to lambast the Labor Government for breaking promises, we should first look at what was said by Malcolm Fraser on 1 May 1981. He said:
When you go into an election with a commitment in 1980 I think it's nonsense to suggest that a commitment made in 1975 on the same subject overrides the one made five years later.
In other words, if one does not keep a promise for five years, one does not have to keep it at all. That was the very basis on which the Fraser Government worked .
I should like to go through just some of the areas. As regards Aboriginal affairs, the 1975 Liberal election speech said:
We will introduce land rights legislation based on justice for all.

As soon as it gained office, the Fraser Government took back land from the Gurindji people at Wattie Creek that had been given to them by the Labor Government. Land rights legislation under Fraser concentrated on justice for land developers, for miners and for the Queensland and Northern Territory governments, which stand damned for their paternalistic attitude to Aboriginals unfortunate enough to live within their borders.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is absolute rubbish.
—As regards health, the Liberals' 1975 election speech said:

SPEECH.PARA: We will maintain Medibank and ensure that the standard of health services in this country do not decline.

Is that rubbish? In 1975 health cover for a family on average weekly earnings amounted to 1.1 per cent of income. Today the cost for equivalent cover amounts to over 6 per cent, and it is still rising-that is, until, in the August session , the Medicare legislation of the Labor Party passes through the Parliament. Under Fraser, the only people who benefited from medical health care were doctors, health funds and private hospitals. The principle that the sick had to pay was certainly one that the Fraser Government relied on.
I turn to inflation. For seven years we were told that we were fighting inflation first. On 12 September 1978 Mr Fraser said:
Inflation at an annual rate of 5 per cent is within our reach by mid-1979. It will go on falling under the policies of this Government.
In June 1978 the inflation rate was 8.8 per cent. By mid-1979 it was 10.7 per cent, and it continued to rise. As regards interest rates, who could forget the December 1977 election promise:
A 2 per cent reduction in interest rates in the next 12 months is a target that can and will be achieved.
Also, from the 1977 campaign speech of Mr Fraser:
Interest rates have begun to fall-and they will keep on falling.
On 6 December 1977 Mr Fraser said:
Once the election is over, we will start to move to the consumation of a 2 per cent reduction in interest rates.

At the end of 1977 new housing loan mortgages from savings banks were at interest rates of 9.25 per cent to 10.5 per cent; now the rates are over 13 per cent. Such was the record of the Fraser Government. When one looks at the MPI-I should not concentrate solely on broken promises but divert for a moment-one sees that it mentions maladministration. I will quote one election promise made by Malcolm Fraser. He said:
There will be no more jobs for the boys.

The boys did pretty well. The boys soon realised that if they were about to be sacked or if their incompetence had grown so great that they would have to resign, the world was their oyster. The political dead of the Liberal Party were buried in the best cemeteries in the world. If one goes through the list-Dr Forbes, Gordon Freeth, Sir Robert Cotton, Peter Coleman, who came and went and came again, Jim Webster, Harry Miller and John Kerr-one sees that, by God, the boys did well. On the same point, consider some of these boys. If maladministration is to be the yardstick by which any administration is to be judged, let us look at the sackings and the resignations. The names include Don Chipp, Garland, Lynch, Sheil, Ellicott, Cotton, Robinson, Withers, Robinson again, Sinclair, Staley, Webster, Robinson for the third time, Adermann, McLeay, Garland, Groom, Peacock, Moore and MacKellar. The list goes on and on. In all, there were 22 separate resignations, sackings and suspensions from the Fraser Ministry in 6 1/2 years. Then there is tax avoidance.

TALK.START.PARA: —We ought to form a club.
—The honourable senator would have plenty of members. In 1977 Mr Fraser said:

SPEECH.PARA: We will move to close loopholes which permit tax avoidance. We are clamping down on tax avoidance.
I will quote from the Interim Report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union of 1981 which reported on tax avoidance. It states:

This industry has developed in Australia, particularly over the last five years , at a rate far in excess of any other industry and has brought with it profits comparable only to the heady days of the Victorian gold rush . . . The amounts involved are very large indeed, amounting to many hundreds of millions of dollars per year or more. The impact on the community has been very serious.
I turn to waste and extravagance, of which there was much in the last period of the Fraser Government. The Liberal election policy speech of 1975 stated:
There will be no international safaris by members of Parliament. Australia does not need a tourist as Prime Minister.

Mr Fraser made 28 overseas trips. He made more overseas trips than the five previous Australian Prime Ministers-Holt, McEwen, Gorton, McMahon and Whitlam- put together. Who can forget the yacht races at Newport, the fishing in Scotland or the diversion to Rome to have lunch with his sister? If they are not examples of maladministration I really do not know what would be. I turn to unemployment. While Mr Fraser complained that under Mr Whitlam unemployment had gone to 400, 000, it rose to 700,000 and was still rising when the Australian people kicked Mr Fraser out of office on 5 March. I would need an extension of time for an hour to go through all the broken promises of the Fraser Government. But that will not be necessary. The Australian people gave their verdict when they booted out that Government so unceremoniously only a few weeks ago.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, I present a report dated June 1983 on certain annual reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement relating to the report and to move that the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations has presented seven major reports to date. The Committee's third and sixth reports included case studies of authorities' annual reports which have been examined by the Committee. This report presents case studies of nine authorities' annual reports and another matter involving payments by two authorities to a public relations firm. These matters were initially referred in the Thirty-second Parliament. The Committee has also considered annual reports referred to it on 22 April 1983 and reports that there were no unreasonable delays in the presentation of those reports, considering the fact that Parliament was not sitting between 16 December 1982 and 21 April 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: Certain of these reports contained Auditor-General's qualifications. However the Committee decided merely to note that fact on this occasion and to take particular note of these authorities' reports next year to check on whether the matters leading to qualifications have been overcome. Certain other reports tabled between 22 April 1983 and 26 May 1983 also contained Auditor-General's qualifications-a disturbing proportion of those reports, if I may say so. Again, the Committee will take particular note when these authorities next report.

I want briefly to draw the Senate's attention to the Committee's conclusions regarding the 10 matters raised in this report. In relation to the Australian Maritime College's annual reports of 1980 and 1981, the Committee trusts that in future the preparation of the College's financial statements will be in accord with accepted accounting practice and the printing of the annual report will be achieved in a much shorter period. With regard to the Fishing Industry Research Committee's annual report 1980-81, we recommend that the FIRC make the necessary administrative arrangements to ensure that its annual report for 1982-83 is prepared and tabled within six months.

In relation to the Canberra Showground Trust's annual report 1980-81, the Committee expresses its concern that the treatment of the grant of $1,003,417 to the Trust was not fully considered at the time the grant was made. We are also concerned at the amount of time that passed before the matter was resolved and at the ability of the then Department of the Capital Territory to deal with the numerous reports it is required to edit. In relation to the Australian War Memorial's annual report 1980-81, the Committee has noted the steps taken to resolve accounting problems associated with its establishment as an independent statutory authority.

As far as the National Health and Medical Research Council's medical research projects annual report is concerned, we recommend that the report be prepared in two parts-the first providing audited financial statements, and the second containing details of research grants made.

With regard to the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority, the Committee examined concurrently the two annual reports referred to it for 1979- 80 and 1980-81 and concluded that the delays in presentation caused by a changeover in accounting methods will not occur again. We look forward to the timely presentation of this Authority's annual report in future. The Australian Canned Fruits Corporation's annual report 1981 was delayed due to the time taken in concluding the audit of the Corporation's accounts and the fact that the report was presented to the Minister early in the winter recess and could not be tabled until the Budget session. The Committee makes a general recommendation regarding reports deemed to have been tabled during recess periods in the introduction of this report.

Having examined the Australian Wheat Board's 1980-81 annual report we have concluded that it will be necessary to maintain our scrutiny of the financial affairs of the Board. The Committee considered the Canberra Commercial Development Authority's annual report 1980-81. This is another example of an authority which the Committee has had under its scrutiny in the past. The Committee finds it unacceptable that the Authority and the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) have not yet resolved the dispute over the treatment of depreciation. We have recommended that the Minister give immediate consideration to this report and that he direct the Authority to ensure that its financial statements reflect the format approved by the Minister for Finance and the Auditor-General.

The other matter dealt with by the Committee in this report is that of payments by Australian National Railways and Trans Australia Airlines to the firm known as Pieter Huveneers Corporate Positioning and Identification. We did not attempt to evaluate the necessity or justification for the expenditure as we are not convinced that a realistic cost-benefit analysis of such programs by trading corporations, whether private or public, can be made. This view appears to be borne out by the optimistic, though general, evaluation made by ANR and the frank comment made by TAA. We regard it as an unsatisfactory situation that sums of money of the magnitude spent by ANR and TAA may be expended without an effective means of measuring the cost-benefit of the investment being available. The Committee recommends that authorities consider carefully such expenditure before embarking on such programs.

The Committee draws attention to two developments in government administration which should greatly assist authorities in the preparation and timely presentation of annual reports: Firstly, the tabling in the Parliament on 11 November 1982 of Guidelines for the Preparation of Annual Reports and on 17 May 1983 of Department of Finance Guidelines for the Form and Standards of Financial Statements for Commonwealth Undertakings; and secondly, a Bill which has been agreed to by both Houses, the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1 ) 1983 which, by amending the Acts Interpretation Act and certain other Acts, imposes an obligation on statutory authorities to furnish to the Parliament annual reports of their activities within six months of the end of the reporting period unless the Act specifies another limit. Ministers must table reports in the Parliament within 15 sitting days of their receipt. When reports are not tabled in the six-month period a written explanation is required and an extension of time to report is to be sought. Both the letter of explanation and the reasons for seeking an extension of time to report are to be tabled in the Parliament. The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has stated that these requirements are to be adopted as an interim measure pending further consideration of this Committee's recommendations. The Committee welcomes this development and looks forward to further action by the Government on early tabling of non-business authorities' reports and for presentation of reports to the Presiding Officers during parliamentary recesses being deemed to be tabled. I am pleased to say that with this report all but two of the long list of references to the Committee are removed from the Notice Paper. I commend this report to the Senate. I move:
That the Senate take note of the report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
