SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the report of an inquiry concerning the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth and seek leave to make a ministerial statement and to move a motion in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday, 19 April 1983, I released publicly the report of inquiry concerning the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office, Perth. As released, there had been deleted from the report some relatively short passages that identified certain members of the public and certain officers of the Public Service. I indicated at that time that I would be tabling the report in the Parliament. The report tabled today is in the same form as that released in April.

SPEECH.PARA: I have concluded that no public interest would be served by including in the report as tabled the passages that were deleted from the report as it was released in April. Insofar as the deleted passages identify members of the general public whose affairs had been referred to the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in respect of matters that have not been in the public arena, it would be an unwarranted invasion of their privacy now to publish the passages that identify them. As to the deleted passages that identify certain officers of the Public Service, it is relevant that one has already been subject to much publicity and all have been subject to administrative action. The public interest does not, in my judgment, require that these passages be published.

As I said in a public statement when I released the report, which it is unnecessary to repeat in detail here, most of the recommendations that directly affect the efficiency of the Office have been implemented; other recommendations are being considered for implemention in the context of the proposal for a Directorate of Public Prosecutions. I move:
That the Senate take note of the paper and the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to this statement and this report. The report was released just prior to the sittings of the Parliament. I do not quite know why it was not tabled then with a statement being made in the Parliament at that stage.
—To get it out as soon as possible. That is why.

—The Attorney-General released it only two days before the Parliament sat, but that is by the way. I noted from the previous statement which the Attorney-General made when he released the report on 19 April that a certain number of recommendations about improving the efficiency of the Crown Solicitor's Office and so on had been implemented, and I am pleased to find that that is so. However, there is one very major problem which he has not addressed, either in the statement of 19 April or today; that is, the permanent appointment of a Deputy Crown Solicitor for the Perth Office. This seems to me to be becoming a matter of very great urgency because the Deputy Crown Solicitor, Mr Massie, was, of course, disciplined as a result of the inquiries into the allegations made by Mr Costigan and was transferred to another position. Nobody has occupied that office since in any permanent capacity.

SPEECH.PARA: The Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth has become notorious because of what was revealed by Mr Smith's report and by the way it handled a particular tax file. There are real problems in the administration and efficiency of that Office and the adequate delivery of legal services provided by it. Mr Smith's report raises very serious questions about the future of that Office. There is no way that Office can be put back into reasonable shape while there is merely an Acting Deputy Crown Solicitor, no matter how competent he or she may be. I think that what is required is a very new approach to Public Service appointments, particularly in the legal professional area. I believe that it is necessary that somebody be attracted to take on that position on a contractual basis for a reasonably short term; somebody who has some standing in the legal profession in Perth because the Office has to deal with the Perth legal profession and with clients in Perth. I think that the only way the standing of that Office can be restored is if a person of some standing can be attracted from private practice. The only way that can be achieved is by a special contractual arrangement. Unfortunately, there seems to be a reluctance on the part of young career officers in the Crown Solicitor's Office to go to Perth and take on that responsibility, even for a reasonably short period. If somebody of that calibre could be persuaded to go there that might be an alternative. I would like to know what the Attorney-General has in mind for this Office. I am deeply concerned that something be done very quickly to give leadership to that Office because there will never be a solution to the problem there until that is done.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Jack Evans) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Sales Tax ( Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1935 to provide exemption from sales tax of retreaded and recapped tyres.
Bill presented by Senator Jack Evans, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill has a simple objective that of ensuring that promises made by both the former Government and the present Government to exempt retreaded tyres from the imposition of sales tax, provided those tyres are retreaded in Australia are kept.

The Bill aims to amend the principal Act-the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act of 1935 first schedule. The terms of retreading or re- capping are not defined in this amendment as they are already covered in the Act under the first schedule item 113F (1) (b).

The situation with this tax is that the Tax Office was instructed to commence collection of this tax from the 1st June 1983. Notice of this Bill was given on that date precludes that action by the commissioner. This sales tax has an unfortunate history. It originated as a result of a change in administrative policy under the Liberal Government and was initially to apply from the first of January this year. This was then postponed to the first of March this year following representations from the industry. It was agreed during the election campaign by both the Labor Party and the Liberal Party, that the tax would not be introduced.

The then Treasurer, speaking on behalf of the Liberal Party in a Press release on the 11th February, 1983, made this assurance and then opposition spokesperson for economic development and tax, writing on behalf of the Australian Labor Party to the Executive Director of Commercial Vehicle Industry Association in Australia on the 21st of February 1983, gave a similar assurance.
Despite this assurance, during the week of the 6th April, 1983, the new Government issued instructions to the Tax Office to collect that tax from the 1st June 1983.

A 1931 Sydney magistrates decision that retreading does not constitute manufacture for purpose of sales tax law has been accepted by the tax commissioner for many years, but it seems that the interpretation has now been changed by the commissioner.

My concern stems from the fact that we already have a sales tax on new tyres. A retreaded or re-capped tyre contains a comparatively small proportion of untaxed material. The base of the retreaded tyre having already been taxed, should not be taxed again when the process of repairing has been undergone. If this principle was to be extended, then we would find taxes on repaired machinery, re -conditioned motor, and a great number of other items added to the tax schedules .

It is estimated that the cost to consumers of this additional tax imposition would be to increase passenger vehicle tyres by appropriately #4 and to increase commercial vehicle tyres by $15-$30. This would have the effect of making re- treaded tyres and re-capped tyres comparatively uncompetitive with new imported tyres and would give a substantial advantage to over-seas suppliers over local re-treading firms. These firms employ over 8,000 employees, many of whose jobs would be in jeopardy if the tax was to be imposed.

I make one other comment which supports the proposal to exempt retreaded and re -capped tyres from sales tax, and that is that there are less oil based products used in retreading than in the manufacture of new tyres which provides a substantial energy and environmental plus for the preference to re-capped or retreaded tyres.

Whilst this proposal may give initial benefits to those involved in the retreading industry, it provides substantial flow-on benefits to consumers not only of tyres, but of all merchandise which is transported by road.
I recommend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1983TAXATION (UNPAID INCOME TAX-DIVIDENDS) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 June, on motion by Senator Gietzelt:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bills which I inadvertently missed out last night when I spoke.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after 'That', insert: 'these Bills be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night I commenced speaking on the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill 1983 and I made the point that I have always agreed that governments have a responsibility to collect moneys that have been evaded, moneys that had they been paid into revenue would have resulted in relieving the general public of unnecessarily high taxation. I have also made the point over and over again that I am against retrospectivity when it comes to taxation matters. I recall that some time ago several schemes were identified, among them the Curran scheme, and I certainly supported the Government's action at the time to recoup tax evaded by these schemes. Even with respect to the Curran scheme I took a stand and voted against the retrospective element in that measure.

SPEECH.PARA: The so-called bottom-of-the-harbour scheme is, of course, the famous one that we are dealing with now. It worried me because it was first identified, to my knowledge, in 1973 when Senator Murphy was the Attorney-General in the Whitlam Government. But despite the fact that laws such as the Income Tax Assessment Act , sections of the companies Act and the Crimes Act, were in existence, no action was taken by the Whitlam Government at that time. I am glad that the Australian Labor Party now has a new found interest in recouping tax which has been evaded in this way.

Of course, the Fraser Government also neglected to act under the existing legislation that was available. Last year it introduced a measure which had a retrospective element in it; it went back 10 years. At that time I made the point, together with several of my colleagues in the House of Representatives and the Senate that we objected to the retrospective element as it affected innocent people and many of them were unwittingly caught up with this scheme perhaps on the advice of their accountants and lawyers. Perhaps they had inherited shares from deceased relatives. They would have had no idea that the company in which they had an interest had contemplated this tax evasion method. I am being quite consistent in my attitude with respect to retrospectivity and I am glad to see that the Liberal Opposition is taking that stand now. I hope that it will continue to adopt that principle that is enshrined in our platform. It might be interesting if I read what the Liberal Party platform has to say about taxation. I refer to page 37 of the document which was approved by the Federal Council of the Liberal Party in May 1982. Under the heading 'Taxation', the document states:

The key function of the tax system is to provide revenue to finance Government expenditure, but it also plays a significant role in relation to economic management. Overall, taxes should be kept at the lowest possible level compatible with responsible economic management and community needs. The system should be easy to understand, simple and inexpensive to administer, fair in appearance and in practice, and subject to continuing review.
The achievement of these objectives requires a tax system in which:
Taxation as between taxpayers in a similar position is equitable.
Initiative and enterprise are encouraged.
The tax responsibility of individuals has regard for their ability to pay.
Incentives are provided for individuals by ensuring personal income tax is not excessive and adjustment is made periodically for the effects of inflation.
Taxation is based on principles which protect the interests of taxpayers in low income groups particularly those with family responsibilities.

The rights of the taxpayer are safeguarded by minimising discretionary powers; assuring taxpayers of a fair hearing before judicial and administrative bodies; maintaining confidentiality of information; ensuring that taxation adjustments do not have retrospective effect.
I think that 'retrospective' is the operative word as far as I am concerned at the moment-
Taxation adjustments undertaken for general economic purposes take full account of the effects of resource allocation and income distribution.
There is continuity in application as it affects industry and commerce, to maintain stability and permit effective forward planning.
As far as possible there is neutrality in relation to investment and consumption decisions.
Both artificial schemes to avoid tax and tax evasion are serious offences against the whole Australian community and are, as far as possible, eliminated.

The legislation has caused a lot of public concern. I have received many letters and telegrams about this matter. In fact, I cannot remember an occasion on which I have received more. I would like to read a letter which I received today because it sums up the feelings of many people throughout the community:

I learned only last Friday of the precise provisions of the amendments the present Government is seeking to obtain to the Recoupment Tax Legislation introduced by the previous Government, and was appalled to learn that it had passed the Lower House. That is the reason for this letter.

I am a vendor shareholder of a target company under the above legislation who is being pilloried unjustly and unfairly by the politicians, bureaucrats and the media through being ''lumped'' into the category of ''Bottom of the Harbour'' operators, who blatantly and possibly illegally, dumped their companies.
I am not in this category. I acted totally within the existing laws at the time . The company I sold exists to-day and complies with all legal and statutory requirements.
I have an unblemished record as:
1. An officer of the N.S.W. Department of Government Transport from 1941 to 1957.
2. An RAAF pilot from 1943 to 1945.
3. A businessman engaged in various business ventures, employing at times in excess of 60 people, and averaging in excess of 30 people, from 1957 to the present day.
My record is now being tarnished by the implications that I have acted wrongfully because of the provisions of legislation that did not exist when I sold my business.

The bureaucrats of the Taxation Department have caused me great embarrassment, and considerable mental anguish to a very sick lady, by serving Taxation Assessment Notices on a former shareholder of my company who was in no way implicated, without the courtesy of enquiring into the facts, instead, in typical bureaucratic fashion, they acted on supposition and suspicion.
Let me outline the facts surrounding the disposal of my business in 1980.
In September 1979, I was approached by Pyrotek Incorporated, of Spokane, Washington, U.S.A. to purchase the business of my company, Glenco Products Pty Ltd, which was their distributor in this area.

I attended their office in Spokane during December 1979 and a written offer to purchase was made. I accepted this offer subject to approval of McNally & Partners, who are my professional financial advisers.

McNally and Partners rejected the offer as totally unacceptable. Acting upon their professional advice, and the professional advice of my legal advisers, I entered into the agreements for the disposal of my business and my shares in Glenco Products Pty Ltd, being assured and believing implicitly that my actions were completely legal and bona fide under the provisions of all existing legislation at that time.
All facets of the above are documentarily substantiated.
Had the provisions of the Retrospective Legislation applied then, I would not have entered into such an arrangement of sale. Instead, I would have either,
1. Negotiated a sale of the assets and Goodwill (Non taxable)
or
2. Retained the Business and still own it.

It seems most unjust that I can now be taxed retrospectively for a completely legal and bona fide transaction without having the same right to retrospectively adjust my affairs in light of the now applicable legislation.

There are one or two other paragraphs, which I choose not to read. If any honourable senator wants to see the letter he is welcome to see it. This letter is typical of a large number of letters that I have received showing that people acting in good faith, legally at the time, have been caught up with this legislation. I certainly support the Opposition's attitude to this retrospective legislation, as I have always done in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a Bill for an Act to amend the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Act 1982. One may be tempted to conclude from the title of this Bill that it is a Bill which seeks to vary slightly and amend the original Bill but, in fact, that is far from the truth. The proposals contained within the Bill are almost completely unrelated to the purpose and intent of the original legislation. The thrust and direction of the amendment now before us is quite separate, quite opposite, quite distinct and quite unrelated to last year's enactment. The most dishonest thing about the first section of the Bill is the title, because it refers to recoupment tax. It is not a recoupment tax, it is a new tax, it is a penal tax, it is a vicious tax and it is an unwarranted tax which seems to me to manifest all the anger, hatred and rage by some poor unfortunate people in the Australian Labor Party who think they are extracting their pound of flesh from the people who make this economy tick.

SPEECH.PARA: We have before us proposed legislation which is intended to raise retrospectively and collect from innocent vendor-shareholders new and punitive taxes primarily of a capital gains nature at exorbitantly high levels. Firstly, the Bill extends and widens the scope of the 1982 legislation so that people who , under the present 1982 Act, are liable for payment of unpaid company tax will now be liable for personal income tax on the hypothetical basis that the net assets of the company, including goodwill and capital assets-capital reserves have been combined with revenue reserves-and have been liquidated and distributed to the individual shareholders as dividends. Included in that theoretic distribution and liquidation of the company are not only revenue items but capital revenue as well. If the companies had been liquidated, wound up and, under normal circumstances, sold, the capital component of the companies would not, under any circumstances under the present Act and the Acts that have prevailed for very many generations, be attaching to any form of taxation.

The legislation now before us includes within its provisions liability for company tax and personal income tax by vendor shareholders of companies that were not bought by the purchasers for the purpose of fraudulently stripping the companies of their assets and thus rendering them unable to meet their taxation liabilities. The legislation further proposes to authorise the Commissioner of Taxation, in his annual report to be prepared for this Parliament, to name those people who have failed to pay an assessed recoupment tax liability in respect of unpaid company tax and unpaid personal income tax. That, of course, is an extension of section 14 of the present Income Tax Assessment Act which was designed, as I will demonstrate later, for quite different and separate reasons. The intention of that section was to report breaches of the Act and occasions where tax evasion took place. What are the major, insidiously camouflaged thrusts and the intention of this legislation need to be clearly understood. I refer to the 1982 Act to draw the distinction and the dichotomy between ' intention' and 'effect'. I remind honourable senators that that Act, which provided for the recoupment of taxation liability, was restricted to company taxation which had been fraudulently evaded by the purchasers of companies but from which the vendor shareholders unwittingly had received the majority of benefit. Of course, there is no suggestion that those vendor shareholders had the slightest idea of the intentions or the motives of the purchasers or that they had intended, by way of fraud, to strip the company of its capacity to pay its tax liability at the close of the full financial year as distinct from the artificial financial year that is imposed upon vendor shareholders by the 1982 Act and the proposed amendment.

The amount of taxation to be recouped from the vendor shareholders under that Act was the current year company taxation liability struck at the normal rate of 46c in the dollar together with undistributed company profits tax, again struck at the normal rate of 50c in the dollar. However, under the 1982 Act, the option is given to vendor shareholders to pay undistributed company tax as personal income tax based on what personal income tax they would have paid because they had legally sold their companies prior to 30 June, at which time the distribution of the companies current year profits was not required. In fact, those profits are not required to be distributed until 10 months after the close of the normal financial year. That distribution is based pragmatically upon the need of the company at the time to retain funds for current and future operations. In addition, of course, some practical wisdom has to be applied by shareholders to the distribution of profits and what is likely to attract at least a modest amount of taxation. Had the 1982 legislation not been introduced, and had assessments been sent out in the normal course for current year company tax, undistributed company profit taxes, or Division 7 taxes and personal income taxes, if any, which were attracted by the distribution of company profits, the new buyers and not the vendors would have been legally responsible. But because they did not have the money, they did not receive primarily the benefit of the funds-
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs inform the Senate to what particular instances she was referring in the Senate last week when, without provocation, she described Dame Leonie Kramer as an educational reactionary?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can answer that question. The comments attributed to Professor Leonie Kramer following the announcement that the Australian Education Council had decided not to proceed with a particular national assessments program, which was not proving of much use to anybody, were along the lines that the pursuit of standards for their own sake was of particular importance. But more specifically I was referring to her association with the Australian Council of Educational Standards which takes the view that the teaching methodology and curriculum of previous generations-the 1920s, I think, was the period that Professor Leonie Kramer mentioned-were much more successful than they are now. They were the kind of comments that I was alluding to.

ANSWER.PARA: In my view, it is literally accurate to say that if one believes that the way people were taught to read and write in the 1920s is better than now, then that is a reactionary view. One is saying that something that happened previously was more successful than what is happening now. I would say that I find those views rather mystifying, since we have no standard data of literacy or numeracy achievements by children going through school in the 1920s. Certainly it is true , as Professor Kramer has been reported as saying, that some children left school at 13 or 14 years of age in the 1920s able to read and write. But it is also true that many children did not. The only longitudinal data that we have available to us over generational periods is that available from the Army. When young men went into the Army in those years they were tested, and they showed a very high degree of illiteracy. I am not aware of any data which shows that the teaching methodology or the curriculum of the 1920s, the 1930s, the 1940s or the 1950s for that matter produced a higher proportion of numerate and literate school leavers.

I think it is not constructive to pretend that there was a golden age when we had no trouble in teaching all children how to read and write, having them all leave school at a high standard, when we have no evidence that that is true. It is very discouraging for teachers and educational planners who are trying to come to grips with the defects of our current education system to pretend that there was once a time when these problems did not exist and if we returned to those methodologies we would have no problems. It was in the context of the Government being very serious about assisting teachers and educators to find ways of achieving higher standards that I made the comment that Professor Leonie Kramer has adopted, according to media reports, a reactionary approach to this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has explained to us what she means by reactionary. Does she mean that anyone who was educated in the 1920s or the 1930s would automatically be reactionary? Would she classify the former Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, as a reactionary because he was educated during that period?
—I doubt that that is a supplementary question, but I will ask the Minister to respond, if she so desires.
—The answer to those several rather illogically connected questions is no.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of the resolutions passed by the ninety-eighth plenary session of the United Nations General Assembly requesting member states to cease any cultural collaboration with South Africa and appealing to writers, artists, musicians and other personalities to boycott South Africa? Did the Australian Council of Trade Unions approach the previous Government last year to ban the sale of television programs to South Africa in accordance with UN policy? Is the Government aware that recently Swaziland has been buying Australian television programs? Will the Minister investigate whether such sales abrogate the UN decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The United Nations, at its thirty-seventh session last year , passed several resolutions which refer to the role of writers, artists and sportsmen in opposing apartheid in South Africa. Resolution 37/69B on 'Concerted International Action for the Elimination of Apartheid', among other things, appealed to writers, artists, sportsmen and others 'To participate actively in the international campaign against apartheid in co-operation with the United Nations'. Resolution 37/69E on the 'Programme of Work of the Special Committee Against Apartheid' commended the Special Committee for giving special attention to a sports and cultural boycott against South Africa and to the participation by writers, artists, sportsmen, religious leaders and others in the international campaign against apartheid. Neither of these resolutions, however, specifically requests member states to cease any cultural collaboration with South Africa. I am instructed that the Australian delegation voted in favour of both resolutions. The Government would endorse those votes as being fully compatible with its position on apartheid. I do not have the facts to hand concerning any approach by the ACTU to the previous Government. I shall, however , ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs to look into this aspect of the question and to advise the honourable senator further accordingly.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the question of sales of televison programs to Swaziland, we are aware that Australian television programs have been sold to Swaziland and, indeed, we are pleased that this is so. There is no reason whatsoever for concern at such sales in that Swaziland, which achieved independence in 1968, is a member of the Commonwealth and the United Nations and continues to enjoy cordial relations with Australia.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TERTIARY EDUCATION COURSES: ACCESS BY WOMEN

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs to her answer to a question on 19 May when she told the Senate that she would be issuing guidelines to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission to encourage the enrolment of more women in certain specialist tertiary courses such as physics or computing. I ask the Minister: Will the proposal be for women to enter these courses solely on academic merit or is she proposing special advantage for the women she seeks to assist?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be issuing guidelines for the Tertiary Education Commission and the Schools Commission in early July, I expect. In the guidelines we will set out the Government's priorities in terms of the overall purpose of Commonwealth funding to education. It is certainly not for the Government to determine matters such as entry standards and to assess potential students for tertiary institutions. That is a matter for those institutions. But I think it is responsible of the Government to indicate where it would like to see changes and to start negotiations with individual institutions through the Tertiary Education Commission about certain areas of failure with regard to access by certain sections of the community. I consider that there would be no need to have any special kind of assessment or to lower any standards if some faculties, which have not been accessible to women, were to make themselves more accessible. It would improve the performance of the student body generally if university faculties, as a practice, took into account more factors than simply a tertiary education score.

ANSWER.PARA: For example, the University of Newcastle medical school has a much broader way of assessing potential students than have traditional medical schools. For example, it has more mature age students. I do not know what the proportion of women is. But it has students from a wider range of backgrounds than can be found in any traditional medical school. I understand, because I have been interested in the development of this medical school, that the performance of the students is at least equal to that of students in traditional medical schools.

It is certainly not my intention to ask faculties to lower their standards or to provide any special way of assessing women, but it is a matter for them to consider that we would like women to have more access to courses in the same way as we would like university faculties, for example, to give, over time, much greater access to Aboriginal students than they have managed to achieve till now .

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to the report of the Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council on British nuclear tests in Australia, which found in part:

QUESTION.PARA: No Australian present at the ranges is shown as having received a radiation dose in excess of that permissible under the then ICRP Recommendations . . . .
The precuations taken to ensure that Aboriginals living in the area were not endangered by the nuclear tests were carefully planned and executed . . . .

In the light of those claims will the Minister inform the Senate how the Government will now treat the claims of the Australian Nuclear Veterans Association and others for compensation for alleged ill effects as a result of exposure to radiation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question raised by Senator Coleman about the British nuclear tests which were conducted in our country more than 20 years ago at Maralinga, Monte Bello and Emu is a matter which has been considered by the Government and which largely comes within the province of my colleague the Minister for Resources and Energy, although both the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the Honourable Clyde Holding, and I have more than a passing interest in this matter, which is the subject of a campaign which has been waged by British veterans as well as the Australian Nuclear Veterans Association.

ANSWER.PARA: As the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, I am naturally involved in the claims that have been put forward by that organisation for a widening of the Repatriation Act to grant compensation to veterans as a result of what they believe-prima facie there is some evidence of this-has affected them in those atomic tests. The Government has not yet made a decision on the issue of radiation, although I can tell the Senate that a working party between our three departments is dealing with this matter. Obviously in our negotiations with the United Kingdom we have to find out just who is culpable in respect of this issue .

The Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council's report, which has been presented to the Parliament, deals with only a part of that necessary investigation. When that report was tabled by the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment it was made clear that it was to be regarded as an interim report and that there would be need therefore for a further study to be commissioned by the Department of Health. The Minister for Health has already authorised that. I believe it will shed further light on this whole question of what took place in the 1950s.

My colleague, who we have agreed should share the major responsibility for this matter-the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh-may like to supplement what I have said, but I think I have answered the question sufficiently for Senator Coleman.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Social Security: Is the Government considering resurrecting the extraordinarily innovative and successful Australian Assistance Plan, the dismantling of which was one of the first acts of the Fraser Government in 1976? Is it true that the plan encouraged the real involvement of ordinary people in solving local health and social problems, improving their ability to handle their own lives and giving them access to a wide range of self-help and self-education measures?

QUESTION.PARA: Is it also true that the Plan brought a feeling of hope and achievement within each community and that the voluntary unpaid contributions made to local community welfare significantly increased the gross national product of the nation at a minimal additional cost of the Plan? In light of this, will the Government contemplate initiating a pilot scheme in each State and Territory, extending the scope of the Plan to include the generation of realistic long term employment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the history of the Australian Assistance Plan. I am sure Senator Chipp is very much aware of it because this program, as he says, was introduced by the previous Labor Government and stopped without notice by the incoming Fraser Government. It caused considerable pain to Senator Chipp at the time, as he had been the shadow Minister for Social Security in the previous Liberal Opposition and had assured the people participating in the Australian Assistance Plan that nothing would be done to it without proper consultation.
—With the full backing of the caretaker Government.

—With the full backing of the Government, as Senator Chipp says. The program was introduced to create an increase in community facilities, particularly in the welfare area, and especially to encourage local communities to have a say in the setting of priorities and the planning and administration of programs in their areas. If it demonstrated nothing else, it certainly demonstrated a willingness, capacity and desire in the community for people to use the skills they have to assist those who are less advantaged in our society.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the problems, as Senator Chipp knows, is that because of the structure of the Australian Assistance Plan the development was much more rapid in the more articulate and, if one could use the term, more middle class areas where there was greater social cohesion and a greater ability to cope with bureaucracy and government. In some of the more deprived areas it was very difficult to get the Plan off the ground, but I think that was a problem of planning as much as anything. The Government is certainly considering community works programs; some statements on them have been made by my colleague the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. We are looking at proposals put forward by local government and by groups in the community which wish to assist in this way.

It was also Government policy to foster community development through the development of community services which are essentially controlled, planned and administered at the local level. I have spoken in this place before about the possibility of having a department of services which would include community services. While I agree that there is this great scope for mobilising community resources, one of the problems with the Australian Assistance Plan was that it was introduced in a way which created rivalry between the different areas. It created an expectation in some areas that there would be a follow on of the flow of funds that originally came from the Australian Assistance Plan. One of the difficulties with introducing a pilot program such as that in certain areas is that perhaps all areas in the country would not accept that they were pilot programs. There would again be this expectation of expansion which may or may not be able to be fulfilled.

TALK.START.PARA: —It could be upheld by the High Court, of course.

—What I believe is that we should learn from the very valuable experience we gained from the Australian Assistance Plan, improve on its administration and learn particularly from those projects which started with the Australian Assistance Plan and are still going, despite the withdrawal of government funds and government support.
—Will you reintroduce it?

—The economic statement makes it clear that the community works program and community development in general have a high priority for us. Although we have been in government only 11 weeks, Senator Baume persists in nitpicking and wanting to know why we have not done everything in that time. I suspect that at the end of 11 months many of our programs will be in place and the Opposition will have to look at something else to criticise. We are certainly not about to do what the previous Government did; that is, while in opposition claim that it would support a program such as the Australian Assistance Plan and have its shadow Minister say that it supported a program such as this and then, in government, have its Minister walk into a meeting in Darwin and announce to the State Ministers that as from that minute the whole show was over. That is the wrong way to go about it. We will plan and properly consult with the local community and develop a worthwhile program.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen the article in the Business and Investment section of the 24 May issue of the Bulletin entitled 'The market's high, but it can go higher yet'? Is the Minister aware that the article reported an exceedingly optimistic view of the stock market by a number of Australia's leading brokers, a view epitomised by hopes of an international recovery, as well as and importantly, the view of Mr Ken Ayles of Potter Partners? It stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Ayles believes that if the government maintains this confidence, the market will continue to rise through the remainder of 1983, subject to periods of consolidation, particularly pre-budget.
Do these comments reflect a justifiable confidence in the economic management of the Hawke Government?

TALK.START.PARA: —The last part of Senator Cook's question asked: Does the state of the market reflect justifiable confidence in the Hawke Government? The answer to that is clearly yes. The people-if that is what they are-who sit opposite normally place great importance upon the state of the stock market, particularly the all ordinaries index. I do not want to place complete importance on those factors. The state of the stock market and the all ordinaries index are two of many indicators of the state of the economy and likely future movements. But the people opposite normally place great importance on that index. So it is interesting to note that on 1 February, before the turkey called the early Christmas, the all ordinaries index stood at 543. In the uncertainty of the election period it declined and it stood at 490 on 1 March. But by 4 March, by which time nobody seriously doubted that there would be a change of government and that the discredited former Prime Minister and his discredited Deputy Leader -who is still the Deputy Leader of his party-would be ignominiously swept from office, the index rose to 512. I am not sure just where it stands at the moment- I have not looked at it for a week or so-but last week's figure was above 600 and, as Senator Cook has suggested, it has probably gone somewhat higher than that.
—Mr President, I ask that the Minister table the paper from which he quoted.
—I table the document.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, concerns the independent Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. What is the recent advice that the Minister has received from that Commission on the question of amalgamations of certain tertiary institutions?

—The advice I received from the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission on the question of amalgamations was probably very similar to the advice that Senator Baume received on that matter when he was Minister for Education. The advice was that the amalgamation of institutions would in the long term mean a more rational use of resources and provide a better range of courses to students. That advice is being considered by the Government in light of other advice from the institutions themselves and from people in the communities which the institutions serve. I expect to be making an announcement next week about the Government's final intentions with regard to the future development of the four institutions-the two in Armidale and the two in Newcastle-which have not yet been fully amalgamated.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question, just to be quite clear. Did not the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission recommend in essence that the amalgamations should stand?

—I would say yes, the advice of the Tertiary Education Commission was that the reasons it gave for recommending the amalgamations in the first place still stood and it was still giving that advice. However, I might say that in my negotiations with the Tertiary Education Commission on this matter it did agree and acknowledge that the pace at which the previous Government enforced the amalgamations and the way in which it caused them to be handled had been very disruptive and had prevented the overall purpose-better planning and more rational use of resources-from being achieved as satisfactorily as could have been the case. In essence, yes, the Tertiary Education Commission is still of the view that the future of these institutions would be better served by a closer relationship than they currently have.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. What is the current situation regarding the entry of foreign banks to the Australian market? Will any consideration be given by the Government, in the event of foreign banks being admitted to Australia, to selling licences for the right of entry? If that possibility is rejected, what alternative criteria would the Government intend to employ in granting entry to foreign banks?

—The Treasurer did announce, I think about three days ago, that this matter would be reviewed. I am afraid I do not have with me a briefing note on it and cannot recall the precise details. I believe that the options raised by Senator Ray were among those likely to be considered. However, I will seek a definitive answer from the Treasurer and supply it as soon as possible. For the benefit of Senator Chaney I say that I do not have anything written down here, but if he would like an autograph I would be quite happy to supply one.

—I ask a question of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. When the Minister said, as was published in the Sydney Sun on 29 March this year, that public funding for certain schools should be less readily available, did this include schools which identify themselves as Christian, which she attacked so violently in the Senate last year? I refer her to page 3009 of the Senate Hansard of 1 December 1982. What I would like the Minister to do is explain to the Senate, very succinctly and explicitly, what tests as to the belief or philosophy of a properly registered non-government school she has in mind.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the last part of the honourable senator's question, I would say none. I should explain the Government's approach to the funding of small independent schools, some of which are fundamentalist Christian. It is this: The registration of these schools is a matter for State authorities and, I expect, will remain so. There has been a long-standing concern that schools are being registered by some State authorities without proper investigation as to the educational standards, facilities and so forth that are available to children in them. In other words, there is really no way in which the State governments can guarantee that the educational opportunities of students attending such schools are being properly accommodated.
—Who is protecting the children's rights?

—I am pleased to hear Senator Jack Evans intervene in such a way. The attitude of the Commonwealth Government is that we are interested in the educational opportunities of children. We give a higher priority to that than to expressions of views which parents might have. We have a primary responsibility for the educational opportunities of children.

QUESTION.PARA: The process of registration which the States have followed in recent years has not been such that the States are able to give the Commonwealth Government assurances about the educational standards of those schools. This has been a matter of concern to the State Education Ministers for some time. As Senator Baume, my predecessor in this portfolio, knows, the matter has been an agenda item of the Australian Education Council for some time. It was certainly an agenda item at the AEC meeting which I chaired recently. The reservations expressed by the Commonwealth about the near automatic registration of new schools was shared, I think, by all Ministers present. A working party is reviewing the registration procedures and it will report to the next AEC meeting which will be held in Adelaide. At that time the Commonwealth and the States will decide together whether those registration procedures are adequate in view of the Commonwealth's responsibility for the overall education of children.

The other aspect about which I am concerned is that once schools are registered by States they are automatically entitled to receive Commonwealth funding at whatever level the Schools Commission determines they need. The Commonwealth is now funding to a very significant extent a number of schools throughout Australia about which it can say nothing in terms of their educational standards . I do not find that a satisfactory situation. I am discussing with my State colleagues-as I said, it will be an agenda item at the next AEC meeting-ways in which we can ensure, firstly, that funds are provided on a basis of need and, secondly, that schools which are funded by the Commonwealth have satisfactory educational standards. The other criterion in which I am interested is that there should be some guarantee of viability. A school with 20 or 25 children should not open, receive Commonwealth funds and then close a year later because the backup in terms of parent, community and professional support was not available. That is the way in which we are approaching the question of the very large number of small schools which have come on to the scene in recent years.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you would accept any beliefs?
—The question of any particular beliefs that are taught in a school is not one in which the Commonwealth should involve itself.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. In light of the dramatic increase in the number of unemployed people over the last seven years, in particular during the last year, and the need for better matching of unemployed people to possible jobs, a proposal was made to establish a computer system to address this problem. Can the Minister advise what progress has been made in implementing the system known as Job Bank within the Commonwealth Employment Service? Is the system, which was expected to be introduced in Adelaide in its first phase earlier this year, proving successful? If not, what problems have occurred in implementing the system?

—Senator Crowley's question referred to a computer system. I will answer the last part of the question first by saying that the only defects which have emerged in the scheme occurred in the computer. It is true that the Job Bank program was implemented in its first phase in South Australia in February this year. The foreshadowed program is to have the scheme operating in its first phase in all regions during 1983 and in its second phase during 1984. I am advised that the initial implementation of the scheme in South Australia is regarded as a success. It is popular both with the staff of the CES and with the users of the scheme, who might be described as clients. There have been some difficulties with equipment, but I understand that they have now been ironed out . The first phase of the scheme, as it is operating in South Australia, is regarded as a success. It is now being implemented in Victoria.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, refers to an announced inquiry into the proposed Radford College. Why was the question of fee levels included in the terms of reference of the inquiry which the Minister set up recently to inquire into this new non- government school in the Australian Capital Territory? Does the Minister intend to change the right of non-government schools to determine for themselves the fees they need to charge?

—The Government does not intend to change the right of non- government schools to determine the fees they will charge. However, when the Schools Commission assesses the needs of schools and the priority of their claims for Commonwealth recurrent funds, obviously the fees that the schools are able to charge, and therefore the income that the schools will receive from those fees, will be taken into account by the Schools Commission. The reason the matter of fee levels was included in the inquiry into Radford College is that there has been something of a debate about what sort of families the new Radford College will serve. If Radford College is to be a high fee charging school, such as the Canberra Grammar School, obviously it will be serving a different section of the community from the one it will serve if it is able to or wishes to set fees at a much lower level, perhaps similar to the fees charged by Catholic systemic schools in the Australian Capital Territory.
—Good heavens! You are limiting them.
—Order! Senator Ryan is answering a question from Senator Collard.

—Quite clearly, the level of fees which the school is aiming at and that section of the community which it is aiming to serve will determine what subsequent level of Commonwealth support it is justified in claiming. I should repeat, for the benefit of honourable senators, that the present Government's policy is that funding of non-government schools is on the basis of need, and the need of a non-government school obviously is determined by many factors, including the capacity of the particular community which supports it to pay fees . This is not new. It is a system under which the Schools Commission has been making decisions about the level of funding. But the criterion of the need of the school is something which will be strengthened and made more significant in the determination by the Commission in future years of the access of a particular non-government school to Commonwealth funds. I hope that that clarifies the matter for the honourable senator.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Why have the Minister and her Department bought into this subject through the inquiry? Is she not satisfied with the way in which the Schools Commission does its job?

—I do not presume that this Federal Government was elected to run everything in exactly the same fashion as it was previously run. The Senate will be aware that the present Commonwealth Government has very different priorities in the area of schooling from those of its predecessor. We are much more concerned than our predecessors were that all children will have access to the highest possible standard of education. We are much more concerned to see a fair and rational distribution of resources between the government and non-government sectors. In my view, the information available to the Schools Commission to make rational and fair decisions with regard to the allocation of funds has been inadequate. We are taking a number of steps which will mean that the Commission will have available to it much more extensive information about proposed new schools, what sort of effect they will have on existing schools in the area, and what sort of effect they will have on the overall educational offerings of an area. There are many matters on which, in my view, the Schools Commission needs better information if it is to make better and fairer decisions about the funding of all schools in Australia.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Communications explain how the funding levels for the Special Broadcasting Service are arrived at, bearing in mind that for the 1982-83 financial year the Special Broadcasting Service was allocated over $400,000 for ethnic broadcasting but only $40,000 for Aboriginal broadcasting? Does the Minister agree that the disparity in these funding levels is exacerbated because of the wealth of the cultural resources that some what are called ethnic communities can draw upon, such as community language newspapers, community sponsorship, well established overseas networks, and so on?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The funding levels arrived at for the Special Broadcasting Service are determined by the same Estimates process as for other statutory authorities. Under the previous Government, subsidies for ethnic radio broadcasting were provided outside the normal budgetary allocations for the Special Broadcasting Service. In fact, last year $650,000 was provided in total for ethnic broadcasting on public broadcasting stations. My recollection is that some $4m was provided in respect of the two government run stations-2EA and 3EA. Of the $650,000, $48,000 was allocated to Aboriginal broadcasting. Those matters are determined by the SBS according to a formula-the secret of which I am not entirely familiar with-for allocating funds to particular interest groups in respect of broadcasting. It may be that the formula has some population component which provides a pro rata allocation of funds according to the size of particular ethnic communities and so on; I do not know.

ANSWER.PARA: However, in relation to Aboriginal broadcasting and the amount allocated for Aboriginal broadcasting, I make the point that the Australian Broadcasting Commission, much to its credit, has done a considerable amount of work in the area of broadcasting and access broadcasting for Aboriginals, particularly in Alice Springs and north Queensland. That is to the great credit of the ABC. It is a marvellous function for that Commission to perform. I think that has to be taken into consideration in the course of answering the honourable senator's question. The other matter which I should mention and which is of relevance is that in the Budget context the Minister is reviewing the system of allocation of funds for ethnic broadcasting.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COUNCIL OF EGG MARKETING AUTHORITIES OF AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry aware that the Council of Egg Marketing Authorities of Australia is alleged to be preparing to support, co-ordinate or fund a public campaign against a group called Animal Liberation? Does the Government consider this to be an appropriate function of the egg marketing authorities? In view of the taxpayers' money which is used to assist the egg industry, will the Minister, by direction or other means, have the Council desist from organising or supporting campaigns which are not directly related to egg marketing?

—I was not aware of any such report. I will refer the question to the Minister for Primary Industry to see what is his response to it. However, I will make one comment at this stage. Although the thrust of Senator Evans's question is not disputed, I cannot recall any taxpayers' money actually going into the Council of Egg Marketing Authorities. It could certainly be argued that because of those marketing authorities', monopoly position in the market consumer prices are higher than they would otherwise be. But I do not believe that any taxpayers' funds per se are going into the Council.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce and Leader of the Government in the Senate. In view of the Prime Minister's speech to the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia this week, can the Minister inform the Senate as to what plans the Government has to ensure the long term job security of steel workers in Port Kembla, Wollongong, Newcastle and Whyalla?

—I suppose that the short answer to the honourable senator's question is no; that is to say, I cannot inform the Senate because I am not prepared to do so in great detail at this stage. But let me say that the Government is continuing to have a series of negotiations with the steel industry and particularly with the company, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, in relation to the future of the industry in those specific towns or cities which were mentioned in the honourable senator's question. I simply make the point that between the middle of 1981 and March of this year 16,000 jobs were shed by BHP in those cities. That is having an enormous impact on the economies of those regions and there are enormous social impacts as a result. In the city of Wollongong, some 33 per cent of the population is directly dependent on the steel industry in respect of employment and, in the city of Newcastle, 12 per cent of the population is directly dependent on the steel industry in respect of employment. Since the Government began negotiations with BHP regarding this matter, I believe that we have been successful in persuading the company that there are to be no further retrenchments in this industry and that any job shedding which might take place should be accommodated by so-called voluntary retirement schemes. I say 'so-called' because they are not as voluntary as one might like them to be; but at least the impact of a voluntary retirement scheme is that the employee retires with a much higher benefit than if he or she is retrenched.
—You will take a super tax from such people.

—No, Senator, you are quite wrong about that. Those benefits are specifically excluded. If I might continue, I believe the Government has also been successful in negotiations in resolving a very important issue which was not resolved until four weeks ago. That was the question of BHP's commitment to continuing in the steel industry in Australia. That commitment has now been made and it has alleviated a great deal of the anxiety which existed in those cities which Senator Richardson mentioned. As the Senate will be aware, the Industries Assistance Commission has presented a final report to the Government in relation to the steel industry. I am not able to comment in the Senate on the IAC's recommendations relating to that industry, but I say that the IAC report will be only one factor which is taken into account by the Government in consideration of an assistance package which might be offered to BHP. Prior to the election, the Government made a commitment to introduce a plan for the steel industry within 100 days of being elected to government. We might overshoot that by a few weeks.
—Oh!

—I suppose we will be accused of breaking a promise. The future of the steel industry is a very serious matter. Of course, Senator Durack, who interjects, should know that his colleague the shadow Minister for Industry and Commerce, who I notice is very shadowy at Question Time, said yesterday that he thought that it was a good approach by the Government not to stick with precision to that commitment which was made prior to the election. I am in a position to say that we believe that a plan for the steel industry which will ensure its future in those cities will be announced on or about 30 June.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Finance whether Medibank Private has confirmed the order for upgraded computer systems to enable it to implement the administration of Medicare from 1 February next year? If so, at what cost? Who will bear the cost if the Senate does not approve Medibank as the sole agent for the Government's arrangement and the computer system is not required?
—The answer as far as I am concerned is that I do not know whether that is the position. I will refer the question to the Minister for Finance.
—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question.
—He said that he does not know.
—Would the honourable senator allow me to ask my supplementary question? Seeing that the answer is just a telephone call away, I ask: Could we have the answer tomorrow?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters has never sat on the front bench and is never likely to do so, but she might know that there is no general telephone here. It is a telephone which goes to my office or to the offices of the various people who sit here.

ANSWER.PARA: Although the original question asked whether I could confirm something and the answer was no, I think on reflection I could make a comment about the latter part of it in which Senator Walters forecast that the Liberal Party, at least in the Senate, would continue the obstructive role which it established for itself in the period of the last Labor Government. I understand, however, that there is a view around that in the particular matter to which Senator Walters referred the Senate will not get the opportunity to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of a proposed visit to Australia by Professor Vidovic, a Croatian emigre, and the concern that this visit is causing to certain sections of the Australian community? Can the Minister explain to the Senate the actions of the Government in permitting this visit?

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that the proposed visit to Australia by Professor Vidovic, a Croatian emigre resident in France, has received some attention recently in the media. I am also aware that the prospect of this visit may well be distasteful to certain sections of the community. I wish to make it clear that the Government, by granting a visa to Professor Vidovic, in no way endorses the political views which he espouses. Approval for the issue of a visa to the gentleman in question was given to him as an individual and not as a representative of a particular organisation, as is the normal case in these matters. To the extent that Professor Vidovic or other individuals or organisations call for the dismemberment of the federal state of Yugoslavia, the Government considers such views to be abhorrent and dissociates itself completely from them. Australia has a long-standing and friendly relationship with Yugoslavia and the Government intends to pursue that relationship actively.

QUESTION.PARA: However, we do not intend to deny individuals entry to Australia solely on the grounds that they are likely to express controversial views while they are here. My colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs, whom I represent here, has discussed this matter with the Prime Minister, I am told, and their conviction, which I fully share, is that the strength of a democratic society derives from a willingness to allow the free expression of opinions provided that they observe the laws of Australia which, of course, prohibit incitement to violence, including violence directed against other countries. People such as Professor Vidovic accordingly may come to this country. The Government, of course, reserves the right to disagree categorically and publicly with them, as I now do .

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney-General a question concerning the censorship of a film proposed to be shown at the Melbourne Film Festival. The film is called Genius Is Lying and was made at the Swinburne Institute of Technology, an institution renowned for the quality of the work by its film students. Are there separate provisions relating to the screening of Australian films and imported films at film festivals? Are there any inconsistencies in this policy? If so, does the Attorney-General plan to take any steps to resolve these anomalies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate Senator Hamer's interest in this matter because of his well-known and long-standing interest in film censorship, both as a senator and as Chairman of the Australian Film Institute, in which capacity he has demonstrated a continuing small 'l' liberal voice-and there are not too many of them left. Described as simply as possible, the situation is that films which are specially imported for approved film festivals are now, as a result of the recently promulgated regulations, exempted from screening by the Film Censorship Board and are automatically registered for limited screenings to subscription audiences at those festivals. Australian-made films are submitted for censorship to the Film Censorship Board which acts on behalf of the States and by arrangement with them. The States insist that no film may be advertised or screened unless it has been registered and classified by the Film Censorship Board. The so- called controversy that was reported last week by the National Times had its genesis as follows: In the first place, the film Genius is Lying was, I am advised, submitted for censorship by Swinburne Institute prior to Swinburne's annual screenings in December 1982. The Film Censorship Board refused to register the film until a particular scene was removed. Parliament being a family program, I shall not stop to describe the scene in question. In making this decision--
—Are you censoring it?

—The only description I can offer is that-no, I will not. Apparently, it involved a portion of someone's anatomy described by one critic as demonstrating 'an appearance of vague interest'. But I will proceed. In making this decision, the Film Censorship Board was fulfilling the arrangement it has with the States for the censorship of Australian films. There is a right of appeal against the decision to the Films Board of Review in the case of any such decision by the Film Censorship Board. That right has not been exercised. It appears, for reasons I am not sure about, that Swinburne is reluctant to exercise that right of appeal. It appears in turn that this reluctance prompted the film maker to submit the film to the Melbourne Film Festival in the hope that the Festival would screen it uncut. The film was included on a list submitted for registration by the Film Festival, but now it appears that the Festival has not in any event decided to show the film, although that application has not been withdrawn. If the application is pursued, the film will be included on the list of films forwarded to the Victorian Government which are exempted by the Governor-in-Council from prior screening for the purpose of screening at the Festival without cuts. If this occurs it is then up to the Victorian Government-not the national Goverment-to decide whether it wishes to permit the film to be screened without any cuts. That is the situation with respect to that film.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the larger policy issues raised by Senator Hamer and future action to resolve such anomalies and inconsistencies as can arise through this now essentially dual system, I think I can quickly say this: I propose to seek the views of the States as to the possibility of there being a consistent approach between imported films which are handled under Customs regulations and Australian-made films which are ultimately the responsibility of the States. I want to seek the Festival's own views on these matters. Having received these views, I think it would be an appropriate matter to pursue at one of the forthcoming meetings of Federal and State censorship Ministers so that, I hope, we can develop, in harmony with the States, a uniform and consistent system of film censorship, at least so far as the festivals are concerned.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TRADING HOURS IN THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Territories and Local Government. My question relates to section 90 of the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Act 1981. This section deals with trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory. Has this section of the Act been proclaimed? If not, does the Government intend to proclaim it, to take no action on it or to repeal the legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the interest of and the question from Senator Colston. He spent some time as a member of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory looking at the question of trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory. Section 90 of the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Act 1981 has not been proclaimed. At the moment it is not the Government's intention to do so. If it were proclaimed it would repeal the Australian Capital Territory trading hours ordinance. Of course, the Government's view on this was, I think, fairly well canvassed in the Senate in 1982. During the debate on that Act the previous Government agreed to refer the deregulation of trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory for inquiry and report by the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory. That report was tabled in both Houses of Parliament on 21 October last year. Honorable senators probably remember that there were two minority reports as well as a majority report. As I recall, those reports did not favour complete deregulation as envisaged in the Review of Commonwealth Functions, which was the subject of a lot of controversy, both in the Australian Capital Territory and in the Parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: An election undertaking was given by the Government to provide for a two-year moratorium on the deregulation of trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory so that we could determine the effect on the employees and small traders. I think our philosophical position is that we do not substantially favour deregulation.

Whilst it probably is accepted by the Government that there are too many shops in the Australian Capital Territory, the Government does not believe that the problem would be resolved by extending hours because what is required if we are to get any sort of revival in the retail sector of the economy is to put more money in pay packets and not open up shops for longer periods to suit the requirements of the major retailers. That is why both the small shopkeepers and the employees have a common position on this matter.

However, I am advised by the Minister for Territories and Local Government that the Government is considering the report of the Joint Committee. After it has had consultation with the appropriate authorities it will be reporting on the matter to Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- Last night during the adjournment debate Senator Kilgariff incorporated a document which he had taken good care not to show me beforehand. The document in question was an adjournment speech by the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory which was delivered, I think, a couple of days ago. This Standing Order does not allow me to make a comprehensive critique of that document, but it contains one quite crucial error of fact. The Chief Minister described some facts given to the Senate by me as a slander and then said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . what was done in 1977 apparently in accordance with Sir Victor Garland's instructions was to divest himself of private interests after he was elected to the national Parliament and whatever steps were taken were perfectly in accord with the law.

To set the record straight I wish it to be noted that Sir Victor Garland was elected to the Parliament in 1969 and became a Minister in 1971. Eight and six years after those respective events he divested himself of the assets to which my statement and the statement of the Chief Minister referred. The date given, 1977, is the correct date for the winding up of the companies. When read in context it is obviously the date which is intended. The argument put by the Chief Minister is spurious and the alibi he concocted falls to the ground.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-The Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, said that yesterday I deliberately did not show him a document which I incorporated during the adjournment debate. I think the Minister sees everything that is done as being done in a sinister way. What really did happen was that the Government Whip approached the Minister on duty in the Senate, Senator Walsh, and asked who would be the Minister on duty during the adjournment debate. The answer was that Senator Evans would be on duty. The Whip then took the document to Senator Evans as he was to be on duty during the adjournment debate. May I say that I would not do such a thing as Senator Walsh hinted at. If I wished to do something I would do it straight out. In this case that was the way it was done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am in a dilemma. I want to seek leave to ask Senator Walsh a question as to what he meant by an answer he gave to Senator Walters at Question Time. If I am refused leave I will be forced to move to suspend Standing Orders. I am reminded that between one o' clock and two o'clock we are not supposed to raise anything controversial. I seek your guidance, Mr President.
—I am in the Senate's hands. If you seek leave I will put that question to the Senate.
—I seek leave to make a brief statement and to ask Senator Walsh a question.
—Is leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted.

—I am sorry, I have not paid Senator Walsh or Senator Button the courtesy of informing them about this matter. It arose only a couple of moments ago. Senator Walsh gave an answer to a supplementary question by Senator Walters which bothers me, particularly as this is the second last day of the session. Tomorrow might be a truncated sitting day and Senator Walsh will have only the time between Question Time and the rising of the Parliament to answer my question. As I understand it, the inference of Senator Walters's question was: Why is the Government spending money on a computer for Medicare if the Senate might reject the centralisation of Medicare authorities in the Health Insurance Commission? Senator Walsh, on refletion, when answering a supplementary question , said that it may well be that the inference in Senator Walters's question might not come about because the Senate may not get an opportunity even to debate the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, have expressed interest in the centralisation of authority. What concerns me-this is what I want amplified by Senator Walsh now-is: Is it the Government's intention during the coming parliamentary recess to spend as much of the money that it has-I think it is $ 43m-on facilities and machinery so as to make it an egg that cannot be unscrambled when the Budget Session commences? I would appreciate an answer from Senator Walsh on what he actually meant by that. Am I reading too much into it at this stage?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy-by leave- Senator Chipp has asked several questions, one of which concerns the opportunity to debate the matter. I do not believe that I gave any indication that there would be no opportunity to debate this matter. If I gave that indication I certainly did not intend to. As to the last part of his question about whether the Government aims, in effect, to commit so much money to this project that it becomes irreversible, I do not believe that that is the Government's intention but I will check that with the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett)

SPEECH.PARA: On the other matter to which I referred-whether legislation would be required to do this-a legal view has come to me, not from government sources but from other sources, that this move may not require legislation. That is what I was referring to in that context.

TALK.START.PARA: —Legislation or regulations?
—I do not know about regulations.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1983CUSTOMS TARIFF (COAL EXPORT DUTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1983EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 May, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bills be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.
