TALK.START.PARA: —Last week in another place my colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), to use a well-known phrase, tipped a bucket over me; a matter not unnoticed by some of my other colleagues who have expressed some concern over his action. Be that as it may, it is not the first time that I have had a bucket tipped over me and probably it will not be the last. Quite frankly, I believe that Mr Hayden was very much misled by his Department of Foreign Affairs, indeed by some of the very men who I allege are guilty of serious crimes, in making the statement he made. Let me be perfectly frank. I have been a member of the Australian Labor Party since 1955 or 1956. I have been active in both this chamber and other chambers since that time.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat for the record that if I believe I have truth on my side I follow an argument to the bitter end, as I intend to do with my argument with the Department of Foreign Affairs over what started off as the Tehran embezzlement matter and has since grown to encompass further matters. This week I have placed on the Notice Paper more questions on what I believe could be Foreign Affairs corruption. My resolve to carry on does not arise only from my conscience but also because of the support I have received over the last 15 months from many people throughout the community on this issue. Only last Sunday, at the annual meeting of my Federal electoral assembly, this matter came up briefly for discussion and all delegates present urged me to hold my stance on it. On page 1043 of the House of Representatives Hansard Mr Hayden is reported to have said:

I do not in any way impugn the character, nor indeed the motivation, of Senator Primmer. I am sure that his motivation, as is his character, is the best, but I do deplore his actions and his persistence with those actions in the light of an extensive explanation I have given to him about investigations which have been made into his complaints and the findings of those investigations.

Let me be completely frank. The extensive explanation that Mr Hayden gave me lasted no longer than, at the outside, three minutes. During that time he explained that he had read two police reports and agreed with them. I informed him that I still intended to put questions on the Notice Paper and to follow up the issue. Honourable senators might ask me why I said that to him. Perhaps it was as a result of an experience I had some years ago in this place. I will quote from the House of Representatives Hansard of 8 March 1978 a letter to the then Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Sinclair, from Mr R. H. Gillespie, Acting Chief Superintendent, Officer in Charge, District of Victoria, Commonwealth Police. This letter relates back to the meat scandals which I had mentioned the previous day, 7 March 1978. The police report stated:
To date, enquiries made and surveillance duties performed on suspect vehicles have failed to adduce sufficient evidence to warrant a prosecution.

That is exactly what the two police reports thus far on corruption-as I claim it to be-in the Foreign Affairs Department have said. They have said that there is insufficient evidence. On this occasion I knew the evidence was there; other people knew the evidence was there. When the truth was out-unfortunately, it took a royal commission to bring it out-it was proved that the evidence was there as at the date the police signed the letter. I am very sceptical about the powers of the Australian Federal Police or our police forces in general to cope properly with white collar crime. It seems to me that all too often they do not have the necessary expertise, the techniques or the wherewithal. I must add that these two police reports referred to by Mr Hayden are apparently so super secret that very few people appear to have access to them-but more about that later.

Mr Hayden, in his speech, went on to describe Messrs Henderson, Smith, Bowden, Loveday and Parkinson-all Foreign Affairs officers-as honourable, upright and proper people. I have challenged that assertion and continue to do so. I make no apology for placing on the Notice Paper the mass of questions that I have. Most of them have been on the Notice Paper, off it and on it again since last year. If the officers referred to earlier are honest and upright, why have these questions not been answered? Are they too hard or what? If my persistence is seriously damaging to these people answers to my questions may well get them off the hook. Why do they not give it a go? I do not want to have them socially embarrassed, but I believe the remedy is in their own hands. Mr Hayden has, as is his nature, expressed sympathy for these men and their families. My concern spreads also to those other officers of the Department who, along with their familes, on this issue have been kicked around for years.

Some people get promotions, others get the boot. Is it a fact, as rumour has it , that Mr Bowden will be given a posting as Ambassador to the Netherlands? Other officers and families have been harassed by security officers and police and have been criticised under privilege by Mr Henderson. I understand that one of these officers even had his home searched by police at Mr Henderson's request. Mr Hayden, in his speech, sought to give the impression that only one Foreign Affairs officer, namely, Mr Witheford, has contributed to the widespread allegations and other misconduct. Anyone who has followed this saga through the Hansard would know that such is not the case.

I have had and do have quite a number of sources both inside and outside the Department of Foreign Affairs both here in Canberra and elsewhere and only last weekend a new informant came to my notice. For the record again, sources have been available to at least one other senator, namely, my colleague Senator McIntosh, who received last September written information from Messrs Witheford and Henne and oral information from another source, but so far as I am aware no action has been taken on that either. This pretence that only one Foreign Affairs officer and one parliamentarian are involved is in my view a crude attempt to downgrade the force of the vast array of allegations that has built up over time.

Last week I referred to the retirement of Sir Nicholas Parkinson and the way it was arranged so that it probably cost the taxpayers a quarter of a million dollars extra. This week I have had allegations of another such retirement. An officer who had apparently earnt the ire of the previous Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, and although as fit as a trout at the time according to medical officers , was subsequently retired on a cooked up medical report under pressure from Mr Henderson and Sir Nicholas Parkinson. If that is the case the recipe for Sir Nicholas Parkinson's lucrative departure was already there.

Mr Hayden went on to talk of the impartiality, sense of propriety and justice of the Department of Finance report last year into the first instalment of Mr Bowden's activities while in Tehran. That, in my view, is rubbish. As it told the Senate last September, Mr Witheford and Mr Henne together with Mr R. E. Johns and another officer were critical of the Finance Department report which, I must add, was leaked to the Press before either Mr Johns or Mr Witheford was interviewed. I also made the following points: Firstly, several misleading draft records of interview with witnesses prepared by Finance were heavily biased in Mr Bowden's favour. Secondly, there was a total lack of investigation of the cover up. Thirdly, Mr Henderson refused to let honest officers involved have access to any Tehran documents. Fourthly, I referred to the loss by Foreign Affairs of important files including a letter received by Mr Alan Renouf from Mr Witheford in 1975. Fifthly, I believe these were obvious leads which the investigating team failed to follow. Sixthly, there were occasional instances of hostility by one of the team members apparently designed to daunt interviewees.

That report was then forwarded to the police at Mr Henderson's request and subsequently the police produced their report which Mr Hayden has praised and wherein Mr Bowden was deemed cleared. The conduct of the police officers involved was such that three people-not just Mr Witheford-complained to the Commonwealth Ombudsman whose report we are still awaiting. Both Mr Witheford and Mr Henne have subsequently alleged that some, but by no means all, of the objectionable conduct is not on the police tapes held by the Ombudsman. I can say that some of the material on the tapes leaves something to be desired, to put it mildly.

Mr Hayden told us that the second police report-again a secret one-has cleared Messrs Henderson, Bowden, Parkinson and Loveday and that according to that report there was no evidence of wrong doing. I know for a fact that several people with information to offer have not even been questioned. Mr Hayden went on further in his speech to mention the fact that Mr Witheford has under way a Public Service Board inquiry. The inference an outsider could get from that reference is that that inquiry has something to do with investigations into the question of what officers got away with what and where. The Public Service Board inquiry was initiated by Mr Street to try to measure the amount of damage done by Mr Henderson and others to the careers of both Mr Witheford and Mr Henne as a result of the Tehran affair. It is only marginal to the general case and my concerns.

In his speech Mr Hayden laid quite some stress on the costs to the taxpayer of the past investigation of this issue. The amount is put as a six figure sum. That I cannot accept, because it infers that the officers conducting the investigation would not have been receiving their weekly salary were they not doing this particular job. In any event, the amounts that could and should be recouped from Messrs Parkinson and Bowden would more than cover the cost of the investigation.

A claim is made in Mr Hayden's speech on page 1045 of Hansard that Mr Witheford appealed against all provisional departmental promotions to level 1 gazetted in August 1982 for the purpose of delaying the promotions of others and disrupting the Department. Whilst I note in the Canberra Times of 19 December last that there are thousands of appeals every year in the Department of Foreign Affairs, the fact is that Mr Witheford, unlike some others, did not appeal against all promotions at his level. I suggest to Mr Hayden that he might check the facts relating to these points and make some apology to Mr Witheford. In fact, because I understand that neither Mr Witheford nor any of the other honest officers have yet been able to meet with either Mr Hayden or his staff, such a meeting might well be arranged, and I hope it will bear fruit relative to this issue. Failing that it seems to me that, as with the meat industry, only a royal commission will get to the facts of the matter. Perhaps my Senate colleague the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans), could plant that seed in his ministerial colleague's mind so that the matter can be, to use his words, 'fiercely and aggressively pursued'.

I finish on this note: Despite all the inquiries held so far into the issue I have raised, I am not satisfied that the truth has come out and my conscience dictates that, in the interest of justice, I should continue to pursue the matter much further. If matters are not properly and vigorously pursued without delay I assure the Senate that I shall be in action on this subject when we convene after the winter recess.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot really allow this opportunity to pass, having listened to the previous speaker, Senator Primmer, without saying that the Opposition regrets the use of the forms and privileges of this place for character assassination of reputable public servants such as Mr Henderson. I believe that Mr Hayden's comments in the House of Representatives on 26 May summarise the situation. Mr Hayden said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we are witnessing, effectively, trial by Hansard, conviction by innuendo and I believe, an inexcusable smudging of the character of the people to whom I have referred.
In conclusion Mr Hayden said:

It is a matter of great melancholy for me that people who are reputable servants of this community, who in my dealings have discharged their responsibilities to the community and government regardless of its political colour in a very proper and competent way, have been subjected to this unrelenting campaign.
I will leave the matter at that.

I now wish to pursue another matter. I was not able to speak during the debate last week on the annual report of the Australian National Gallery. Therefore, I wish to take a few minutes of the time of the Senate to make a plea that the design and character of major public buildings reflect the age or philosophy of the period in which their construction took place. Accompanying the report of the Australian National Gallery was an account of the ceremonial opening. Several speeches drew attention to the architecture of the new building. The Chairman of the Australian National Gallery, Mr Gordon Darling, referred to the building as 'a work of art; one which displays the might of design and the majesty of colour, and one whose sublime spaces and surprising corners take the visitor on a voyage of endless discovery'. On the other hand, the then Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, agreed that whilst its entrance was imposing, 'some may judge that from certain angles, it is not the most beautiful building in the world, but when the trees already planted around it grow, the lines of concrete will soften'. In Canberra, the national capital, we are surrounded with many monuments and grandiose buildings. Some of those buildings are living monuments to their creators.

Today I wish to make the observation that the architecture reflects the philosophy of the age in which the construction took place. After viewing many local structures I think that serious thought should be given to the image that we are projecting through architecture. We are living in an age when we are valuing size above beauty. As the then Prime Minister said at the opening: 'The building is big and has some harsh angles.' Many visitors to the national capital have their first view of the National Gallery from the Kings Avenue Bridge. I use that route to Parliament House. From that perspective in the morning, as one witnesses smoke billowing from a chimney, the National Gallery looks more like a factory than a National Gallery. It epitomises an age when big is beautiful and the only way to be influential is to be large.

After passing through a quite imposing entrance one is overwhelmed by tall, stark walls. Many of the paintings look like postage stamps on the walls. Admittedly, upstairs, there is a greater feeling of it being a gallery. There does not appear to be very much grace about the place. I commend the attempt to assist the disabled to move easily around the building, but this has been achieved with a lack of subtlety and attention to detail. Somebody with a primary production background could say cynically that some of these corridors reflect an oversized sheep race. Similarly next door, to use the terminology of body language, the High Court of Australia gives the impression that it lords over all. It hints that it is very expensive in terms of litigation and resort to it is beyond the reach of most ordinary Australians, because of the architecture, the grand scale on which it is built. Again, its massive, exposed steel work exudes a feeling of coldness and lack of charity. While the Gallery aspires to greatness, its physical size is not matched by the size of its collection. Maybe the architects have tended to overbuild.

On the other hand, I welcome the plan for the development of the Museum of Australia. The report of the interim council indicates that the building will not dominate the surroundings, that it will complement, not overwhelm, the contents and that the environment will be welcoming, rather than massive and daunting. In conclusion, I believe that we must ensure that by our architecture, particularly in this national capital, we do not further the criticism that we are a brash young country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some remarks about the Government's decision to grant an additional $115m to Trans Australia Airlines and $60m to Qantas Airways Ltd. This financial commitment by the Australian Government proves to the Australian public, and to the world, our confidence in the future of these two great Australian institutions. Thee is no doubt that TAA and Qantas have received a battering over the last seven years not only because of the severe economic recession, but also because of the short sighted and unsympathetic policies of the previous Government. At last TAA and Qantas will have the opportunity to work out their economic difficulties.

SPEECH.PARA: The grants being made available to TAA and Qantas are not being made in an attempt to prop up failing enterprises. The $60m capital will provide Qantas with a better debt-equity ratio. In the short term, the capital will help Qantas to remain competitive with foreign airlines which fly to Australia. The money to both organisations will be used as equity capital; that is, shareholders' funds. While Qantas and TAA will not have to pay interest on these amounts they will, it is hoped, provide a dividend to the Australian community-the shareholders. The grants are comparable to the provision of additional funds by shareholders in the private sector so that a company can expand or improve its research capabilities.

The Government's decision must be seen in the light of the difficulties currently being experienced by the international airline industry. That industry has been experiencing the most severe financial and trading difficulties in its history, largely because of the world-wide economic recession which has led, in turn, to a marked decline in tourism and, consequently, in international air travel. The International Air Transport Association-IATA-has estimated the total losses of its member airlines as about $US2 billion in 1983. Qantas's losses on its airline operations are not as great as those experienced by many other international airlines.

In a speech which I made to the Senate last year I read, from a then current Newsweek article, the statement that Pan Am had a total debt of over $US11 billion. The article also pointed out that Continental Airlines Inc. had a debt of between $US4 billion and $US5 billion. I mention these two airlines again today because both operate into Australia and both have to be looked at as possible failures in the future. Already we have seen Laker Airlines, which was championed by honourable senators opposite as the airline that brought about deregulation in the industry. It was said that it had opened a new era in world airline travel. We have seen that airline collapse. Also, last year, Braniff International Airlines collapsed. It was not, by any stretch of the imagination, a small airline. It had 10,000 employees and 50 aircraft operating throughout the world.

It is also pertinent to note that a number of Qantas major rivals for passengers, including Singapore Airlines Ltd, British Airways and Air New Zealand Ltd have received from their governments more support than has Qantas from previous Australian governments. For instance, Singapore Airlines received a capital injection of $200m. Air New Zealand received $68m in 1982 and between 1975 and 1982 the British Government increased the capital base of British Airways by $265m. During the same period the capital injection provided to Qantas was a paltry $25m. The total paid up capital of Air New Zealand is $120m, which is $38 per head of the New Zealand population. Singapore Airlines has a capital base of $261m, which is equivalent to $107 per head of population. On the other hand, the capital base of Qantas is now $149.4m or only $10 per head of the Australian population. Furthermore, these airlines are equivalent to Qantas in size and areas served. It is also worthwhile to study Qantas losses on airline operations for the period 1981-82 in comparison with those of other large airlines. While Qantas reported a loss of $24m, Air New Zealand lost $67m, British Airways lost a massive $880m, Continental lost $45m and Pan Am lost $ 367m.

The Government's decision will ensure that at last Qantas and TAA will have adequate working capital and thus the freedom to improve their services and provide innovative fare deals and air routes. Until these recent increases were granted TAA's capital had since 1960-61 remained unchanged. Tragically, the former Government allowed Qantas and TAA to depend too much on borrowings to finance operations. Both faced horrendous interest problems. Furthermore, both organisations were unable to be flexible, which is imperative for th efficient running of any large airline organisation.

TAA's ability to operate as a viable and profit making organisation was also undermined by the previous Government's policies, which took 90 per cent of TAA' s net profits between 1975 and 1981. Not only was it not permitted to build up its reserves, it was also forced to operate uneconomical services which the private airlines would not touch. Any honourable senator from Queensland would realise that the majority of airline routes in north Queensland are uneconomical and no private airline would touch them. The policies undertaken by the former Government added to the uncertainty of TAA's future. It is not surprising that staff morale has been very low indeed. The previous government had vowed to sell off TAA; naturally, this Government has reversed the decision. It is worth noting that TAA was originally brought into existence to compete against private interests and prevent undesirable, economic and social effects which occur when any industry is controlled by a monopoly of private interests. On a number of occasions in the past TAA has initiated fare cuts. Through its links with the Government it has been able to push through these fare cuts. On occasions it has forced Ansett Airlines of Australia to follow suit.

It should be pointed out that both TAA and Qantas have been taking drastic measures to improve their economic position. Qantas has sold a number of major properties, such as the Wentworth Hotel in Sydney, to build up its cash reserves . Qantas has reduced its work force through voluntary retirements with a total world-wide reduction of about 2,000. It has cut back services and rationalised remaining services where there has been a decline in demand, for example, in Europe and the United Kingdom, and it has increased services in growing markets such as Asia and the United States of America. TAA has also reduced staff numbers from 9,000 in 1980-81 to about 8,000 at present. It has rationalised services while introducing innovatory fares which have been successful in increasing its share of the domestic airline market. Further, TAA has rationalised its F27 services, withdrawn from the loss-making airport to city bus services and disposed of surplus assets including aircraft and property.

TAA's serious financial position has been exacerbated by the decision in 1979 to acquire wide-bodied aircraft. Unfortunately, there has been a substantial downturn in traffic that was unforeseen in 1979 when the A300 aircraft came into service. But this position is not unique to TAA and will have to be faced by Ansett in the months ahead as it takes delivery of its new wide-bodied Boeing 767 aircraft. I am glad to say that this Government is ending the inefficiency shown towards TAA and Qantas by previous governments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity provided by the first reading debate on the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1983 and associated Bills to raise a matter on which the Government clearly has made a bad decision. I refer to the deletion of the Wynyard Airport from the list of works to be undertaken. I am convinced that this arose as a result of incomplete advice, a lack of knowledge of the situation, inadequate representation and political inexperience . However, at this stage, I congratulate the Government on the way in which it has so readily changed the decisions that it has made when it has been shown to be wrong. It is on that basis that I now ask for similar treatment in this matter. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that he had no knowledge of the situation and the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) said that he has never been to north-western Tasmania. So it is understandable that they would not really know the actual position upon which the decisions have been made.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been involved in the Aerodrome Local Ownership Plan for about six years. I support the Government's view and my party's view on the Plan. Whilst the history of the Wynyard Airport is important I will not take time to cover it now . However, in December, after considerable negotiation had gone on for some years, an undertaking to manage the airport was obtained through the Burnie Marine Board. Agreement for funding was reached with the Commonwealth Government and the go-ahead was given.

I will now state why the decision was so clearly wrong. I will number the points that I am about to make so that we can look at them individually. First, the original decision is totally in line with the Government's policy, as stated in the Australian Labor Party's transport policy document, a copy of which I have before me. Second, the arrangements were concluded about six months ago and considerable work and investment has already been undertaken. Third, this was a promise that was made at the election. Fourth, Wynyard Airport is the third major airport in Tasmania, both for the number of movements and the number of passengers.

The air transport statistics that hit honourable senators' desks only a day or two ago show, for instance, that Wynyard had 80,000 passengers and 5,185 aircraft movements in the period to 30 June 1982. On the other hand, Devonport, which is the next biggest Tasmanian airport, had 77,500 passengers and 4,106 aircraft movements. On those statistics, Wynyard is thirteenth on the list of airports in Australia with the largest number of aircraft movements and twentieth on the list for passenger movements. Of course, the important thing is that both Wynyard Airport and Devonport Airport operate very closely together.

Fifth, geographically, Wynyard serves the largest portion of Tasmania-larger than any of the other regular airports. Sixth, it serves that part of Tasmania which produces the largest part of its natural wealth in minerals, agriculture and timber products. Seventh, without upgrading, the development already carried out at Devonport will not be appropriately utilised. The airlines need both airports before that development can be profitably utilised. Eighth, the Federal Government's policy is to create employment. Better and more regular transport is vital to Tasmania for getting new jobs. Ninth, tourism is recognised as Tasmania's best potential development area, with the west coast mountains, rivers and so on as the centre of this increase. Of course, Wynyard is the point of entry for medium jets. Medium jets are essential to maximise that part of the development.

Tenth, the airport's construction will involve on-site employment of about 110 people. If we add off-site employment as well, the figure would be between 150 and 180 for a period of 18 months with lesser numbers both before and after that period. In addition, 85 per cent of the entire money being spent on the development will be spent locally on equipment, labour and subcontracts.

Eleventh, as a long term development I can think of only one more project in the capital line in Tasmania that could be more important than this. Twelfth, it came out in evidence taken recently that, in the Burnie employment region, unemployment has doubled in the last six months.

In summary, to accept the deplorable advice before the Government would involve the loss of a most necessary, long term capital investment; curtailment of a work and capital oriented tourism development; actual probable contraction to this part of Tasmania; the loss of time and money already invested; a breakdown in the viability of the planned two-airport medium jet service to north-western Tasmania and the breaking of two promises-one made by this Government and one by the previous Government. I see the case as one in which there is a total lack of knowledge, inadequate advice and a failure to take an overview of all the social , industrial and developmental aspects of the decision that has been taken. I am accusing no one. I am not debating what anyone has, or has not, done. I just ask the Government to look at all the facts and to take the appropriate steps to go ahead with the airport as planned. The development of Wynyard Airport to medium jet standard is of great importance to Tasmania.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a Queensland senator I take this opportunity to bring to the attention of the Senate matters that pertain to one of the most controversial issues ever raised in my home State. The issue surrounds the Government tenders for the Stanwell powerhouse in central Queensland. As I said, the issue has become extremely controversial because of allegations suggesting that the assessment of the tenders was not carried out in a proper way. On information provided to me the chronological order of events is as follows: The Queensland State Government called separate tenders for the boilers and the turbo-generators at the proposed Stanwell powerhouse. International and Australian firms submitted tender prices. These tender prices were announced at the public opening on 29 September 1982. However, following release of those separate tender prices, secret negotiations took place between people associated with the Government and with the Japanese company, C. Itoh and Co. (Australia) Ltd.

SPEECH.PARA: Following those negotiations, C. Itoh submitted a combined tender price for the boilers and generators. It is believed that C. Itoh's submission of the combined tender price was made at the request of a person or persons associated with the QEGB- that is, the Queensland Electricity Generating Board-or with the Government. It was made after it became known that both technical and commercial evaluations of the other tenders showed that CESO Canada would win the turbo- generator tender. It is also pertinent to mention that CESO became aware that C. Itoh had made a mistake in its boiler price, in that the boilers offered in its tender were too small in size. CESO subsequently drew this to the attention of the Queensland Electricity Generating Board assessors expecting that the tender of C. Itoh would then be rejected as a non-conforming tender. This, however, was not to be so. At some later date, in an apparent move to save C. Itoh, contact was made with C. Itoh by people associated with the Government and an invitation was extended to the company to submit re-bids or a second submission by 1 March, which allowed C. Itoh to offer a bigger boiler. C. Itoh subsequently did this at no additional cost. It should be pointed out that the offer to change the technical items was not made to all tenderers. C. Itoh not only changed the boiler size but it is believed that following further discussions with Government personnel it also offered a discounted combined tender price for both boilers and generators.

It needs to be mentioned that this combined price offer was made only after C. Itoh knew the bids of all other tenderers. It is now evident that C. Itoh also agreed to a number of concessions concerning problem areas or problems that have arisen in relation to the Tarong power house. These problems apparently included the computer coal control system and simulators. These concessions were made during discussions held in Japan with people associated with the Government of the electricity industry. Secret discussions were also held with C. Itoh in which the company was warned that it needed to review the small size of its local content. It must be appreciated that one of the rules in Queensland is that special preference should be given to those companies that create employment for the State by ensuring that contracts contain a major local content. C. Itoh was advised also that Clyde-Riley Dodds Pty Ltd, an Australian firm, and CESO were offering 75 per cent local content. As a direct result of this special advice, C. Itoh lifted its local content to 62 per cent compared with the local content of 40 per cent which it had previously used in its involvement at Tarong and Callide B.

The issue then extends further, and involves the Queensland Cabinet. The information submitted to Cabinet was rushed through in only 10 minutes even though the contracts were worth in the vicinity of $330m. Documents available show that in relation to the tender for the boilers by Clyde-Riley Dodds, Cabinet was informed that 'the tendered technical proposal from CRD is not technically acceptable'. No reasons were given for this unacceptability and the claim is believed to have been challenged by Clyde-Riley Dodds. I point out that Clyde-Riley Dodds, believing that it was being discriminated against and would lose the tender prior to the Cabinet decision, submitted a brief to a number of Queensland Ministers. A copy of that brief details the original read-out prices and other information as regards advantages of an Australian firm being awarded the tender.

The document presented to Cabinet, to which I refer, in effect downgraded and criticised the Clyde-Riley Dodds tender. It also claimed that the C. Itoh boilers included $82.2m in components from Japan. This is now challenged, Mr Deputy President, and it is claimed that it would have been more like $90m in imported components. Naturally, the smaller apparent value of the imported components would make the C. Itoh tender appear more favourable. As honourable senators would therefore appreciate, the difference in figures was to the advantage of the C. Itoh contract and upgraded the contract in comparison with others.

The information given to Cabinet also claimed that the Clyde-Riley Dodds offer included overseas components to the value of $62.8m 'mainly from Korea'. After the disaster with gates supplied by Korea for the Wivenhoe Dam, the suggestion of Korean components would have detracted from the Clyde-Riley Dodds tender. However, this information about Korean components is completely false. Firstly, the overseas components were to come mainly from Japan and from the United States of America and not from Korea as stated. But more importantly, the amount of those components was not $62.8m as claimed in the document but instead closer to $52m. This misleading information was given to Cabinet Ministers for one purpose and one purpose only. That purpose was to downgrade the Clyde-Riley Dodds tender and thus in comparison significantly upgrade the C. Itoh tender.

In the read-out prices for the turbo-generators, the C. Itoh price was $113m while the lowest tender, from Mitsubishi Westinghouse, was of the order of $99, 880,326-a difference in excess of $13m. The information that was provided to Cabinet totally conflicts with that submitted by a tenderer-in this instance, the Australian company, Clyde-Riley Dodds. It needs to be remembered also that while private, secret negotiations or discussions were held with C. Itoh regarding any problems with its tender in relation to boiler size, neither Clyde -Riley Dodds nor Mitsubishi Westinghouse nor any other tenderer were told whether their tenders were or were not technically acceptable during any tender discussions. In contrast, a senior representative of Clyde-Riley Dodds was invited to come to Brisbane by the Minister for Mines and Energy, Mr Gibbs. When he arrived in Brisbane, he was handed a Press release showing that the Cabinet decision awarding the combined contract to C. Itoh had already been made.

Secret discussions took place with C. Itoh not only in Australia but also in Japan. Some discussions took place in early May, particularly on 12 May, after all other tenderers were told that no such talks would be undertaken with any parties. It is clear from the information available that C. Itoh has been given special treatment by the Queensland Government or by persons associated with that Government. It is also clear that once the tender prices were known, the company C. Itoh was given the opportunity to change its price. It is believed that because the individual tenders would have gone to companies other than C. Itoh, the ploy was used to get the company to submit a combined tender price. It is possible as well that because even the combined tender price was not as low as it should be in comparison with other prices, and because of the desire to have Australian involvement, the company then not only gave a special discount on a combined price but also, secondly, gave concessions regarding problems that had arisen in Tarong in relation to the computer control system and simulators.

The seriousness of false information going to Cabinet obviously cannot be resolved by Federal Parliament. It is clear that the Queensland Government wants to cover up and confuse this issue. The facts of the matter are that given the information available a company has been given special treatment. By whom? I am not in a position to say. But I believe that an investigation must be carried out to prove or disprove the points that have been made. Cabinet documents and other information also made known to me show that other tenders were eliminated and this was a carefully considered process to ensure that C. Itoh was awarded the contract. Answers must be given.

I am aware from media reports that the Leader of the Opposition in Queensland, Mr Keith Wright, sent 25 questions to the Queensland Minister for Mines and Energy, Mr Gibbs, but Mr Gibbs has refused to answer those questions. If the Government has nothing to hide, why does it refuse to produce that facts and figures it holds? I also understand from media reports that Mr Wright has challenged Mr Gibbs to debate the issue publicly. Again that challenge has not been taken up. Answers must be given as to why, for instance, the non-conforming tender was accepted; why discussions were allowed to be held and deals to be negotiated after other tender prices were known; and why C. Itoh was given special advantages over all tenderers. I agree with Mr Wright's assertion that a judicial inquiry is needed into what could be described as the elimination process used to guarantee that C. Itoh would be successful and that all other tenderers would be eliminated.

I also believe that an inquiry should be held into the role played by QEGB and Treasury officials or anyone else associated with the Government and this company. This inquiry should cover discussions which have been held in Japan as well as in Queensland. Moreover, the investigation ought to involve those persons involved in hospitality activities in Japan earlier this year. Mr Deputy President, the issue is a very important one and a highly controversial one in the State that I represent. The matter must be pursued and, as a Queensland senator, I now call on the Queensland Attorney-General to act responsibly on this matter, to have an immediate investigation carried out and also to initiate a judicial inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to enter the debate that must take place in this place on the Articles of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women, before the present Government moves to ratify this Convention. I ask the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) whether he will make sure that this chamber has the opportunity to debate the Convention, as I believe it is most important.

SPEECH.PARA: The history is that the United Nations General Assembly adopted the Convention in 1979. Most of the countries present at that meeting in Copenhagen at that time later signed the Convention in principle. But since that time more than half of those countries, having had time to scrutinise it more closely, have not moved to ratify the Convention. Many of them have serious reservations and Australia, under the former Government, was amongst that group. I will read the list of countries that have failed to ratify the Convention. They are countries with which we have very close ties and with which we are closely identified. They are: The United States of America, the United Kingdom, New Zealand, the Netherlands, Japan, Greece, West Germany, France, Finland, Denmark and Belgium.

Under the previous Government, Australia had grave reservations but this is not the case under this Government. To begin with, the Convention interferes with our Australian federation because not all the State Attorneys-General have agreed with it. They must agree because, according to the Convention, it must be introduced nationally. I believe the Convention is a formidable threat to the freedom of religion and the protection of women and the family in this country. On a quick reading of it, people would say: 'Well, there is not a great deal wrong with it'. But, as has happened with some of the countries who originally supported it, when one gives it closer scrutiny one begins to understand the dangers involved.

We may well ask ourselves why so many of these countries with which we associate have not signed it. I believe that the fault lies in the various interpretations of the word 'discrimination'. Article 1 states:
'discrimination against women' shall mean any distinction, exclusion or restriction made on the basis of sex . . .

Mr Deputy President, I am sure that you will agree with me that women are distinct from men as men are from women. As I have said, many countries have grave reservations, and have expressed those reservations, about the Convention. Countries which have ratified it have expressed their reservations. Many countries expressed reservations when they signed it originally. For instance, Austria has stated that it will not be forced to send its women into the armed forces as could be required under Article 7 (b). Austria has also said it will not be associated with Article 11 which states that women would not be protected in their work place.

I believe that Egypt has made a complete farce of the whole Convention by saying that it will have nothing to do with the Convention if it involves any detrimental effect on the Islamic religious laws and customs of its country. India and other countries with the Islamic religion have stated likewise. This points out to Australian women more than anything else can do that, if countries with an Islamic religion can sign this Convention, really the whole Convention is a farce and must be considered so. Mexico has stated that it will not ratify the Convention if any of its legislation is at variance with the Convention. One can begin to understand how ludicrous it would be for us to sign the Convention.

Article 2 (b) states that, if we ratify it, we must adopt appropriate legislation and other measures, including sanctions where appropriate, to prohibit all discrimination against women. Article 2 (f) states that we must take all appropriate measures including legislation to modify or abolish existing laws, regulations, customs and practices which constitute discrimination against women. This provision would interfere with our religious freedom. I mention two religions that are very popular in Australia-the Roman Catholic religion and the Jewish religion. The Roman Catholic church would be forced to take women into its heirarchy. Under the Jewish religion, women are required to sit at the back of the church. This Convention would insist that women sit up at the front of the church. Although I believe some synagogues allow this to happen, not all of them do.

Article 3 states that there should be no discrimination in the economic or cultural fields. In the economic field, in Australia we have discrimination against men because women can retire at 60 and receive the age pension while men cannot do so until they are 65. Does this mean that we would alter our pension system so that women would not receive the pension until the age of 65? The Convention does not really state what will happen. Article 6 states that we must abolish prostitution and that is one with which I agree. Senator Chipp informed us in this place the other night that he does not agree with this provision. Mr Wran has also moved in that direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean?

—He has suggested that he would think of legalising prostitution in New South Wales. Article 9 is a tricky one. Many of the countries, such as Jordan, France, Egypt, et cetera, have reservations about this Article which states that women will have equal rights with men in respect of the nationality of their children. I now turn to Article 10 (c) which disturbs a number of people. This is an area in which it eliminates any stereotyped concepts of the role of men and women at all levels and in all forms of education by encouraging co-education and other types of education which will help to achieve this aim and, in particular, by the revision of textbooks and school programs and the adaptation of teaching methods. What is wrong with primary school children's textbooks having a picture of a mother with a baby in her arms waving goodbye to the father who is going out to earn money for the security of that family? Must we abolish this concept and say that it is a stereotyped role that makes women distinct from men? Good heavens, women are distinct from men.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Gareth Evans[Some of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no way that the honourable senator-whether he would have it otherwise or not-could overcome that biological fact. This is a ludicrous interpretation that has been put upon discrimination against women. Article 11.2 (b) concerns maternity leave and states:

SPEECH.PARA: To introduce maternity leave with pay or with comparable social benefits without loss of former employment, seniority or social allowances;

How can we maintain the seniority of a woman who leaves the workforce when she decides to have her children and stays out of it for perhaps four, five or six years? When she comes back do we say that over that time she would have reached such and such a stage, perhaps in the Public Service or elsewhere, and her new seniority must be maintained? Many of the countries have withdrawn from that article. They say it is too expensive for their particular form of government and it is an impractical way of running government. Article 14.2 (h) states that rural women must not be disadvantaged in any way. If honourable senators look at the reading of that they will see it states that the rural women must:
. . . enjoy adequate living conditions, particularly in relation to housing, sanitation, electricity and water supply, transport and communications.

Whilst I believe that is a wonderful objective for every country, it is not practical, particularly in a country the size of ours; it is a vast continent. Women in the outback realise that their sanitation, electricity, water supply, transport and communications are not always equivalent to those of their colleagues in the capital cities. The fact that it is suggested that we move to this immediately is really quite extraordinary.

Many countries have also withdrawn from Article 16.1 (e), which states that women must have the same rights to have as many children as they like, with access to information and education as well as the means to enable them to exercise these rights. Whilst we have that in Australia, I wonder whether the article also includes abortion. It could well do so. Article 16.1 (g) is one from which Brazil, Jordan, France and other countries have moved since they have ratified it. That article states:
The same personal rights as husband and wife, including the right to choose a family name . . .

Mr President, we could have a situation in Australia where, if we departed from the traditional method of family names, we could have children in the same family with different family names. The first child could take the husband's family name and the second child could take the mother's family name. I believe that would really present all sorts of legal and social problems within the family structure. Article 29.1 enforces all countries to abide by the Convention . It states that should there be any dispute between countries, when one is not abiding by the articles and when others believe it should be, negotiations should be carried out for a special time. If those negotiations have not been successful within six months then one of the countries can take the other to the International Court of Justice. If we did not give our women the appropriate seniority in the work place after they had been at home for six or seven years, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, Cuba, Brazil or any other country which has ratified the Convention could take us to the International Court of Justice.

I will read out the names of the countries which have withdrawn from this article because that will give the people of Australia a rough idea of which countries have ratified this Convention. I have already indicated the countries that have not ratified it and these are some that have: El Salvador, Ethiopia, Romania, China, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Brazil, Bulgaria, the USSR, Mongolia, Egypt, France, the German Democratic Republic, Poland, India and the Ukraine. If Senator Evans ratifies this while the Parliament is in recess and denies us a proper debate in this place I, for one, will be extremely disappointed. As he is in the chamber I ask him again: Will he allow a full debate on the articles of the Convention, especially on the ones that this country-if he insists upon going ahead with the ratification-can move reservations against? So many petitions opposing the ratification have been brought into this chamber that I believe he should at least give us the opportunity of that debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Senator Gareth Evans, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I appreciate that this is a somewhat unusual course to follow for a Bill of major significance being introduced into the Parliament for the first time, but for reasons of time I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Mr President, the Freedom of Information Act has now been in operation for 6 months. It commenced on 1 December 1982. Although that is a comparatively short period of operation within which to judge how the legislation is working, some things have become clear-

The number of requests for access to documents which have been made under the Act is only a small fraction of the numbers feared by departments and authorities when the Bill was before the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs;

As was expected, most of the requests have been for documents related to the personal affairs of the applicant and have been made to the large client- oriented agencies such as the Department of Social Security, the Taxation Office and the Department of Veterans' Affairs;

Most of the requests are being dealt with well within the 60 day time limit specified in section 19 of the Act, although there is no doubt that most departments and authorities might be described as still being in the learning stage in handling requests.

The Government came to office with a commitment to review the Freedom of Information Act. The starting point for that review has been the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee which were not taken up by the previous Government and which were moved unsuccessfully both in this place and in the House of Representatives during the debate on the Freedom of Information Act. It will be remembered that there were three principal areas of contention-

First, the lack of substantial retrospectivity except in respect of documents relating to the personal affairs of the applicant, and even in that case only documents up to 5 years old at the date of commencement of the Act;
Secondly, the power given to Ministers to issue conclusive certificates having the effect that claims to exemption might only be examined by a special tribunal to be set up for that purpose;
Thirdly, the undue width of a number of exemptions due to the lack of a proper test of public interest in the release of the documents concerned.

The present Bill tackles all three aspects. In the first place, it provides that the generality of records up to 5 years old at the date of commencement of the Freedom of Information Act will be subject to the legislation. That means that documents which came into the possession of Ministers and agencies on or after 1 December 1977 will be available for access subject, of course, to the exemption provisions of the Act. In the case of documents containing personal information about the application there will be no limit on the retrospectivity. I would add that a number of agencies are already dealing with requests for documents containing personal information on this basis. The retrospectivity thus given will cover most of the document which are the subject of current interest to applicants and will represent a very substantial expansion of the scope of the legislation.

In addition, the legal protection given by sections 91 and 92 to the disclosure under the Act of non-exempt documents will be extended to the disclosure of non- exempt documents beyond the 5 year period. This will encourage agencies to give access to prior documents beyond the 5 year period.

In the second place, the special Document Review Tribunal is to be abolished. Although the Government has considered it premature to take the further step of abolishing the system of conclusive certificates under the Act, it does not consider that there is any justification for retaining a special tribunal to deal with these matters. It believes that they can be adequately and properly considered by the presidential members of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal who, in the context of the other jurisdictions of the Tribunal, are building up a considerable body of expertise in the handling of administrative matters.

All questions conerning claims of exemption where certificates have been issued will be dealt with by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. That Tribunal, constituted by presidential members of the Tribunal, will be empowered to consider whether there are reasonable grounds for claiming that a document is exempt in any case where a certificate has been issued and to recommend accordingly. The Tribunal will be empowered, if it is not otherwise satisfied as to the nature of the document, to require a document which is the subject of a certificate to be produced to the Tribunal. Under the Act as it stands, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is not permitted to examine for itself a document which is the subject of a certificate. This has proved to be a particular problem in the case where a document is claimed to be exempt as an internal working document and a certificate is given in respect of that document . Although the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is empowered to consider whether a document is one of a deliberative type, which would bring it within section 36 of the Act, it is not permitted to look at the document for that purpose where a certificate has been issued. It must determine the question without the benefit of seeing the document. This deficiency will be cured by the Bill.

Furthermore, the Bill will amend the Act to require the relevant Minister, in a case where the Tribunal has found that there are no reasonable grounds for claiming that a document is exempt, positively to decide whether to revoke the certificate or not. If he decides not to do so, he will be required to give a statement of reasons for that decision so far as can be done consistently with not disclosing exempt matter, and to table that statement in the Parliament.

In the third place, three of the exemption provisions of the Act will be made subject to an overriding public interest test. This will give effect to relevant recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee, particularly in the case of Commonwealth/State documents. The first of these exemptions concerns Commonwealth/State documents, that is, documents the disclosure of which may cause damage to Commonwealth/State relations or disclose information communicated in confidence by a State Government or authority to the Commonwealth. The Bill will provide, in a new section 33A to be inserted in the Freedom of Information Act, that a document will not be exempt on this ground if the disclosure of the document under the Act would, on balance, be in the public interest. That is, a document cannot be withheld under the Commonwealth/State exemption if the disclosure of the document would serve the public interest. Thus, for example, a document cannot be withheld merely because it contains information communicated in confidence by a State if there is a public interest in having access to that information. Since the Freedom of Information Act was enacted, at least one State has made a practice of designating most of its communications in writing with the Commonwealth as confidential, presumably to bring all of those documents within the scope of the Commonwealth/ State exemption. It was never intended that the exemption would operate in that way. The addition of the overriding public interest test will ensure that documents cannot be withheld where they ought to be released.

The public interest test so expressed will operate somewhat differently to the public interest test in section 36 of the Act in respect of internal working documents. In that case, the question is whether the disclosure of a document containing advice, recommendation, opinion or other deliberative material would be contrary to the public interest. A document is not exempt on the basis of its content unless it can be shown that the disclosure of those contents would be contrary to the public interest. In the case of the Commonwealth/State documents , harm or likely harm to Commonwealth/State relations or the disclosure of a confidential communication will be sufficient to make a document exempt unless, as I have said, there is an overriding public interest in the disclosure of that document.

In the area of Commonwealth/State documents the Bill also picks up two recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee which were rejected by the previous Government. They are, first, that a State should be entitled to be consulted before the release of a document which might fall within the Commonwealth/State exemption provisions. Secondly, a State having been so consulted, should be entitled to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal against a Commonwealth decision to release the document as one which is not exempt. The State concerned will be entitled to appeal to the Tribunal on the ground that the document would be exempt under the Commonwealth/State exemption provision. The Bill provides that these consultations would take place in accordance with arrangements to be entered into between the Commonwealth and the States.

I should add that the Prime Minister has written to the State Premiers and to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory to repeat assurances given by the previous Government that a State could be expected to be consulted before there is disclosure of a document the release of which might harm the interests of the State or the Northern Territory, as the case may be. I would also add that the provisions relating to States all apply equally to the Northern Territory.

The exemptions contained in sections 39 and 40 of the Act are to be restricted in their scope by the addition of an overriding public interest test, of the kind I have already described in relation to Commonwealth/State documents. These two exemptions relate to documents the disclosure of which would adversely affect the financial or property interests of the Commonwealth or its agencies and documents the disclosure of which would prejudice certain agency operations. In addition, the latter exemption has been re-drafted to clarify its scope.

The Bill contains a number of other measures to widen the scope of the Freedom of Information Act. First, the exemption for Cabinet and Executive Council documents has been narrowed to exclude from its scope documents of a purely factual character the disclosure of the Cabinet. This means that, after a Cabinet decision is announced, purely factual documents produced for submission to Cabinet in connection with that decision will no longer be subject to the Cabinet document exemption.

Secondly, there is to be a progressive reduction in the 60 day period allowed by section 19 of the Act for dealing with requests under the Act. From 1 December 1984, the period will be reduced to 45 days. It will be further reduced to 30 days from 1 December 1986. This staged reduction of the response time corresponds to the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee. It means that departments and authorities will have had 2 years' experience under the 60 day time limit before it is reduced to 45 days and 4 years' experience of the Act before the response time is reduced to 30 days.

Thirdly, the Act will be amended to require a statement of reasons to be given under section 26 of the Act in respect of all decisions under the Act relating to a refusal of access. In particular, this means that reasons will have to be given for decisions to issue conclusive certificates and, as I have already explained, for a refusal to revoke a certificate to give effect to a recommendation of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. This will avoid an applicant having to resort to the mechanism of the Administrative Decisions ( Judicial Review) Act to seek the reasons for decisions in such cases. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal is to be empowered to decide whether the statement of reasons given in a particular case is an adequate statement.

Fourthly, where an applicant is refused access to documents in circumstances in which he would be entitled to complain to the Ombudsman about that refusal, the agency concerned will be required to inform the applicant of the right to complain to the Ombudsman.

Fifthly, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is to be empowered to recommend to the Attorney-General, in appropriate cases, that the costs of a successful applicant before the Tribunal be paid by the Commonwealth.

Sixthly, the Bill makes two changes of significance to section 9 of the Act, which provides for the publication of departmental manuals and the like. In the first place, an updating of the list of manuals will be required, so far as practicable, to be made every three months, instead of every year as at present. In the second place, the dispensing power granted by the Act to the Attorney- General to modify the application of section 9 to an agency is to be limited to the special case of the Commissioner of Taxation for which it was originally intended.
The Government believes that all these changes, widening in various ways the scope of the Act, will bring marked advantages to the public in the working of the legislation.
There are some other changes of substance made by the Bill to clarify or improve the practical operation of the Act.

The definition of the term 'official document of a Minister' will be amended to make clear the intention that it extends only to documents which a Minister has in his capacity as Minister and not to documents which he holds in his capacity as a member of the Parliament. This is regarded as implicit in the existing definition, but some doubts have been expressed.

There are two changes relating to security matters. In the first place, it is to be made clear that references in section 33 of the Act to the security of the Commonwealth are to include measures taken outside the Commonwealth, particularly in relation to the security of overseas posts and of our communications network.

Secondly, some anomalies have arisen by virtue of the fact that the intelligence agencies of the Commonwealth are excluded from the operation of the Act, but their documents in the hands of other agencies are not so excluded. Accordingly, section 7 of the Act is to be amended to remove these anomalies, by providing that documents received by an agency from an intelligence organisation will be excluded from the operation of the Act.

Some problems in the application of the Act have arisen out of the changes in administrative arrangements made when the present Government came into office. New sub-sections (6) and (7) to be inserted in section 4 of the Act are intended to avoid these problems in the future.

As well as providing for the staged reduction of response time under section 19 of the Act which I have already mentioned, clause 10 of the Bill provides for the addresses of agencies to which applications are to be sent to be specified in the future by notice in the Gazette rather than by regulation. This will make it administratively easier to notify changes of agency addresses in the future as they occur and so keep the list up to date.

Obviously, the Bill cannot be passed through the Pariament during the present sittings. It is the Government's intention that it should remain over until the Budget sittings and this will give ample opportunity for public comment on it. The expectation is that the Bill will proceed through the Parliament during the Budget sittings and will be brought into force as soon as possible. As an interim measure, it will still be necessary to constitute the Document Review Tribunal to deal with a number of certificates which have already been given and with any others which might be given before the new arrangements come into force . The Document Review Tribunal will be set up as soon as practicable.

In the second place, the Government has approved a policy of administering the Freedom of Information Act in accordance with the spirit of the amendments pending the enactments of those amendments and, in particular, a policy of not reviewing access to a document solely on the ground of it being a prior document except in accordance with the proposed amendment to section 12 of the Act. There will, however, be cases in which they may not be able to be given effect because the extended protection which will be afforded by the proposed amendments of sections 91 and 92 will not be available until the present Bill becomes law.

Apart from the legislative changes there are some administrative matters which have been the subject of consideration by the Government. My Department engaged in a very considerable training program last year for officers of Commonwealth agencies and the staff of Ministers. That training program will need to be an ongoing one and my Department will be undertaking further training this year with the assistance of the Public Service Board to acquaint officers of agencies and the staff of Ministers with the proposed amendments to the Act.

Much more publicity needs to be given to the rights conferred by the Freedom of Information Act and the brochure issued by my Department last year will be revised and reissued. It is also intended that that brochure should be issued in the principal ethnic languages. The Freedom of Information Memoranda issued last year will be continued and existing memoranda will be revised in the light of experience. It is still intended to issue a Freedom of Information handbook, but that is a long term project and work on it has been deferred pending the settlement of the proposed amendments to the Act.

The Senate Committee recommended that, in the decision-making arrangements adopted by agencies for the handling of FOI requests, the general principles to be applied should be that authority to clear requests be delegated downward as far as realistically possible, while authority to deny requests should be confined to a small group of officers of at least Second Division status. All agencies have or should have made arrangements under section 23 of the Freedom of Information Act with regard to the delegation of decision-making powers. My Department has asked all agencies to provide it with details of these arrangements and they will be revised by my Department for consistency with the Senate Committee's recommendation. In addition, my Department will be drawing to the attention of agencies the recommendation by the Senate Committee that where practicable reading rooms to assist the public to peruse manuals, indexes and other information required to be made available should be provided where the number and nature of requests for this kind of material would justify the cost of establishing the reading rooms.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Senator Gareth Evans, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The current situation relating to the management of Commonwealth records can no longer be regarded as acceptable in today's political climate. The Australian Public Service is operating in an environment which is increasingly demanding and searching. Quality of Government and reform of administration are live issues. Processes of Government are under greater scrutiny than ever before, and management practices must be able to withstand public review. Concepts of openness, privacy and redress at law are permeating public administration. Records, and the information which they contain have a crucial part to play in enabling the agencies of Government to respond to these changes and to meet community expectations. The Government must therefore take appropriate action.

As part of the general concern to achieve adequate management processes within the Public Service, there is scope for the development of a coherent policy in relation to the management of Commonwealth records. Such a policy must have clear objectives which can be explained, accounted for, and if necessary, reviewed. It must provide for arrangements to cover the whole of the Public Service and in relation to which agencies have defined roles and objectives as users and managers. Such a step can be justified on the grounds of furthering efficiency and effective use of resources. It is also necessary as a means of assisting the public towards an understanding of what can and, equally importantly, cannot be achieved in managing so vast and diverse a body of records. Openness about records as a commodity is an essential element in the growing degree of contact between the community and the agencies of Government.

Furthermore, there must be an adequate system of public access to the records generated by departments and authorities. Such a system must provide a clear statement of rights and objectives both of agencies and the public. It must deal with all categories of Commonwealth records since their creation.
The Bill currently before the House contributes substantially towards meeting these two objectives.

The Bill institutes arrangements for the proper management and disposition of the vast body of records generated by Commonwealth agencies. While it breaks some new ground, it is chiefly designed to replace existing ad hoc decisions and conventions which have been relied upon for the last thirty years, with a coherent framework within which comprehensive and accountable arrangements can be made. It provides a statutory basis for the activities of the Australian Archives and confirms that organisation as the agency chiefly responsible for developing and implementing the broad management action which will be necessary.

In relation to the management of records, the Bill provides for action in a number of key areas. For example, the Australian Archives is to gather for its own purposes and for use as appropriate by other Commonwealth agencies and the public, a wide variety of management information about Commonwealth records, including data about their identity, content, format, age, whereabouts, value and functional relationships with agencies past and present. This activity is particularly important in providing a basis for the effective physical management of records. In addition, it provides for an analysis of the effects of successive administrative changes on the responsibilities of agencies and for clarification of the distribution of related records from Federation to the present day. By doing these things it provides an essential basis for both the physical and intellectual management of the stock of Commonwealth records.

Not all records, of course, can be or need to be kept. But while destruction of records can be justified quite properly, on the grounds of efficiency and economy, it is in the interests of the agencies and the public alike that decisions concerning destruction are made with the greatest care, are fully recorded and follow carefully designed and widely-known processes. Accordingly, the Bill establishes appropriate machinery with a central role for the Australian Archives. It also prohibits the disposal, destruction or transfer of custody or ownership of Commonwealth records unless these procedures meet certain criteria, with the proviso that there is no interference with the requirements of other laws and of the normal processes of administration.

The Bill makes specific provisions covering the transfer, custody and storage of Commonwealth records. In essence, the records are to be transferred to bulk storage repositories as soon as they fall out of current use in agencies and in general no record more than 25 years old is to remain in the custody of the agency. The Australian Archives is empowered to establish and control the necessary repositories; however, where the Director-General considers it to be more effective or efficient or for other reasons appropriate to do so, the Archives may enter into arrangements for the storage of non current Commonwealth records in other repositories.

The Australian Archives is empowered to provide advice and guidance on issues related to the management and use of Commonwealth records. This process will include assistance to agencies, either individually or as a whole, in developing policies and procedures which will improve their response to the new demands which are being made on their records resources.

Information about the structure and working of Government, the allocation of functions and the distribution of related records, will be made available for public use as appropriate. Under proper guidance and instruction, this advice will be of the greatest practical assistance to members of the public in identifying which records of which agencies are relevant to their particular concerns. It will also help to develop a general awareness of the way in which the machinery of Government functions and its implications for records. Access to advice and guidance of this sort will help the public to approach the body of Commonwealth records with a greater hope of success, whatever the nature or period of their inquiry.

Much of the Bill is concerned with a matter of special interest to the Government, that is, with the question of public access to Commonwealth records. The relevant provisions of the Archives Bill and the measures contained in Freedom of Information legislation have been carefully co-ordinated in order that together they constitute comprehensive arrangements covering the public accessibility of the widest range of Commonwealth documentation. Broadly speaking, freedom of information covers material which is thirty years old or less, while the arrangements under Archives legislation relate to records more than thirty years old.

Access under Archives legislation is designed to meet the needs not only of those who wish to consult single, specific documents but also of those who wish to search through a large number of records in order to find the information which they desire. In other words, the arrangements are intended to meet the needs of comprehensive research and general inquiry, as well as to cater for those who already know which records they are looking for.

It is expected that under these arrangements the great majority of Commonwealth records more than thirty years old will become available for such purposes. Under the proposed Archives legislation there is also provision for special access to and accelerated release of records less than thirty years old. Inevitably, however, in the interests of personal privacy, good government and security, some exemptions will have to be applied and these will be very similar in principle to those provided for under Freedom of Information legislation. However, it is expected that relatively fewer records will be withheld under Archives legislation because this deals, in the main, with older records.

Particulars of records examined for the purpose of public release except in the case of exempt records in respect of which a certificate has been made, will be entered in the National Guide to Archival Material, an updated copy of which will be maintained in all Regional Offices of the Australian Archives. This will allow the public to ascertain which records are open for use and which have been closed.

The Bill provides a right of appeal. Administrative decisions to close all or part of a record which is in the open access period, except material covered by a certificate or where it has been determined that access to a record would physically jeopardise that record, can be challenged by the public. This is to be done through an internal process of review or reconsideration and then, if necessary, by an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The application is to receive all reasonable assistance in identifying the record in question and the onus of establishing that the record is an exempt record lies with the party claiming the exemption.

The body of records to which these measures apply is large, increasing in volume, varied in physical type and diverse in subject matter. Essentially it is the body of records which Commonwealth agencies have been generating since Federation in pursuit of their day by day business.

A 'Commonwealth record' is defined as any record which is the property of the Commonwealth, but the term does not extend to such material in a collection maintained by the Australian War Memorial, the National Library of Australia or the Australian National Gallery.

The Australian Archives will have the power to seek the deposit in its custody of other records closely associated with the origin, history and functioning of the Commonwealth Government and to take steps to ensure that such material is properly preserved.
