Special provision is made for certain Commonwealth records separate from those of the Public Service and associated Government agencies. The provisions of the legislation will apply to the records of the official establishment of the Governor-General, but not to his private or personal records. Records of both the Cabinet and the Executive Council are covered by the Bill except for the class of records known as 'Cabinet Notebooks', which contain notes of discussions or deliberations of Cabinet or a Cabinet committee. Special arrangements have been made in order that the provisions of the legislation can be applied to records of the Parliament and the courts by means of regulations, in terms consistent with the constitutional relationship between the Executive Government and the Parliament and the courts.

While the general management provisions of the Bill apply to the intelligence organisations, these bodies have discretion in the matter of the extent to which their records shall be subject to the control of the Director-General of the Australian Archives.

Communications received by the Commonwealth from State governments will be the subject of consultation where release of such material might reasonably be expected adversely to affect the interests of a State.

Known financial costs arising directly from the Bill are those associated with the Advisory Council and some additional staff. While there are Service-wide staffing implications, as the Bill makes statutory provisions for the managements storage and disposal of records, it is difficult to assess this except in broad terms. For the Australian Archives the staffing needs estimated to be required to meet the provisions of the Bill, have been assessed as 9 staff Australia-wide. This number is in addition to those currently being sought from the Public Service Board to enable existing backlogs to be reduced, and existing levels of service to be improved.

Quite clearly, the measures which I have outlined relating to the management and accessibility of Commonwealth records will have the effect of vastly improving the quality of what is being done by way of identifying, servicing and making available for research and general public use a valuable and unique aspect of our national heritage.

However, the type of work which the Bill authorises the Australian Archives to undertake in relation to the management of records throughout the Public Service will do much more than benefit only those who professionally or from personal interest are concerned with what the Government and its machinery were doing 30 or 40 years ago. It will provide valuable and continuing support to the Service in coming to terms with the new circumstances in which all agencies, and not just the Australian Archives, now have significant responsibilities for identifying, describing and locating records; for arriving at access decisions about them and for making them physically available for public purposes. In this way it will benefit those members of the public who, for a variety of reasons, are concerned with today's records.

The Bill does not establish the Australian Archives as a statutory authority; such action was not felt to be appropriate at this time. However, the office of Director-General is to be a statutory position, and the Australian Archives is to have the benefit of an Advisory Council whose members will include parliamentarians and representatives of users, both Commonwealth institutions and the public. The Council will be able to advise the Minister and the Director -General as requested, or on its own motion, on all matters relating to the functions of the Australian Archives.

The Australian Archives has recently been the subject of a Joint Management Review, as a result of which its management practices and systems are being completely overhauled and modernised. Its capacity in relation to systems, automatic data processes and the development of policy have been greatly strengthened as an organisation. It is becoming increasingly capable of playing a central management role in a changing administrative and information environment. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Senator Gareth Evans, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill is consequential upon the Archives Bill 1983. Its purpose is to provide for the Australian Archives to be the depository of certain material under the Copyright Act. The Bill will amend the Copyright Act 1968 to enable broadcasting and television organisations to deposit with the Australian Archives the so-called ephemeral records which the Director-General of the Australian Archives certifies as being of exceptional documentary character. The present provisions of the Copyright Act provide for deposit of these records with the National Library.

An ephemeral record is a record-whether videotape, cinematograph film or sound record-made by a radio or television broadcaster for the purposes of broadcasting a copyright work. The Copyright Act entitles a broadcaster, who has a licence to broadcast a copyright work, to make such a recording without further permission, so long as the record is either destroyed within twelve months, or such longer period as is agreed to, or delivered to the National Library for archival retention. The Berne Copyright Convention requires the destruction of such records unless they are preserved in official archives on the ground of their exceptional documentary character. Now that the Archives is to be established on a statutory basis, with rights of access to be defined, it is appropriate that the Archives, rather than the National Library, be entitled to receive this material, and that its Director-General be responsible for its certification as material of exceptional documentary character.

Particulars of all ephemeral records received by the Archives will be kept, under the provisions of the Archives Bill, in the Australian National Register of Records established by that Bill. Records received from government-funded broadcasters will be kept as appropriate in one of the repositories maintained by the Archives around Australia. With the consent of the National Librarian, records received from private broadcasters will be lodged by the Archives, under the provisions of the Archives Bill, with the National Library of Australia where they will be kept together with like material deposited by non-government bodies.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Senator Ryan, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
Like my colleague Senator Gareth Evans, because of the restrictions of the timetable facing the Senate, I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
I am delighted that I am able to move the introduction of a major piece of legislation on a matter which so deeply affects the rights of women and men.

The objects of the Bill are to give effect to certain provisions of the U.N. Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women which the Government plans to ratify in the near future; to eliminate discrimination on the ground of sex, marital status or pregnancy in the areas of employment, education, accommodation, the provision of goods, facilities and services, the disposal of land, the activities of clubs and the administration of Commonwealth laws and programs, and discrimination involving sexual harassment in the work- place and in educational institutions; and to promote recognition and acceptance within the community of the principle of the equality of men and women.

The Bill closely resembles the Sex Discrimination Bill 1981 which I introduced into the Senate as a private member's Bill in November 1981. Following introduction of that Bill I held extensive consultations on it. The present Bill incorporates a number of very useful suggestions made to me during these consultations.

The need for such a law is now widely understood and accepted. Throughout Australia women experience discrimination on the basis of their sex and their marital status. In three States there are avenues for redress of infringements of women's rights. In other States and in the range of areas which are the responsibility of the Commonwealth there is no remedy. The result is economic and social disadvantage and a significant impediment to the exercise by Australians of fundamental rights and freedoms.
The statistics give clear evidence of deeply embedded structural inequalities in our society:
Unemployment rates amongst women, (11.2 per cent in February 1983) particularly young women (29.7 per cent), remain considerably higher than amongst men (9.9 per cent and 24.7 per cent).
87.6 per cent of discouraged workers are women (September 1982).

Nearly two-thirds of women are employed in only three occupational groupings: Clerical; sales and services; sport and recreation. Even within occupations where women predominate they are seldom found in key decision-making positions.
Occupations in which women are concentrated are amongst those most likely to contract with the introduction of new computer technology.

Although the number of women in administrative, executive and a managerial positions increased by 40 per cent in the 10 years to 1980, women filled only 14 per cent of these positions in February 1983.
36 per cent of employed women work part-time. 78.4 per cent of part-time workers are women.
Only 5 per cent of all apprentices are female; if hairdressing apprentices are excluded, young women comprise less than 2 per cent of apprentices.
Average weekly full-time earnings for Australian women were 76.4 per cent of male earnings in 1981.
Female average weekly earnings at December 1982 (latest available) were $283.30 . The corresponding male rate was $352.10.
This Bill offers an opportunity to combat some of these inequalities.
I turn now to a more detailed description of the Bill.

The Bill will cover both direct and indirect discrimination on the ground of sex, marital status or pregnancy. Direct discrimination occurs when there is a specifically directed policy or action which treats one group less favourably than another. Indirect discrimination occurs when a policy or practice which on the face of it appears to be neutral or non-discriminatory, by its operations results in discrimination against one particular group of persons.

The Bill is to apply throughout Australia and in this regard relies on all available and appropriate heads of Commonwealth constitutional power. Thus for example the provisions of the Bill prohibiting discrimination will apply to the Commonwealth and all its instrumentalities; to discrimination by a foreign corporation, or a trading or financial corporation formed within the limits of the Commonwealth; to discrimination in the carrying on of the business of banking, other than State banking not extending beyond the limits of the State concerned and insurance other than State insurance not extending beyond the limits of the State concerned; and to discrimination in the course of or in relation to trade and commerce inside Australia. The Bill is not to apply to persons employed by State Government instrumentalities; however, it will have some application to persons employed by universities, colleges of advanced education and other tertiary education institutions. In addition, certain provisions of the Bill have effect in relation to discrimination against women to the extent that they give effect to the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women.

In the preparation of this Bill, as in the preparation of the 1981 Bill, the Government has been particularly conscious of State sex discrimination legislation and of the role played by State anti-discrimination machinery in eliminating discrimination.

New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia all have laws prohibiting discrimination on the ground of sex or marital status, and the present Bill closely follows the substantive provisions of that State legislation. These Acts have clearly succeeded in establishing individual rights and remedies which are now readily understood within the community. For this reason the present Bill is designed to complement and preserve the concurrent operation of existing State legislation.

In the preparation of the provisions preserving State legislation the Government has had before it the recent decision of the High Court in Viskauskas v. Niland. In that case the Court held that the provisions of the New South Wales Anti-Discrimination Act dealing with racial discrimination were inconsistent with the Commonwealth Racial Discrimination Act and accordingly were invalid by virtue of section 109 of the Constitution. Senators will be aware that in the Racial Discrimination Amendment Bill the Government has already moved to preserve State legislation dealing with racial discrimination. Provisions of the Sex Discrimination Bill being introduced today will operate to ensure the preservation of State sex discrimination legislation and enable that legislation to operate concurrently with the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Act .

I will now describe the areas in which the Bill proscribes discrimination on the ground of sex, marital status or pregnancy. Commonwealth and State experience has shown that most discrimination occurs in the area of employment. The Bill makes unlawful discrimination against applicants for jobs and employees generally and also against persons who are commission agents or contract workers . The Bill will extend to afford protection throughout Australia as far as is constitutionally possible and in this regard will provide protection not only to the Commonwealth's own employees or applicants but to employees of other institutions such as trading or financial corporations.

Persons who propose to form or who have formed partnerships of 6 or more, licensing and qualifying bodies, trade unions and other organisations registered under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and employment agencies are similarly prohibited from discriminating on the ground of sex, marital status or pregnancy .

With regard to education, it will be unlawful for an educational authority to discriminate on the grounds of sex, marital status or pregnancy against a person applying for admission as a student or against a student. Single sex educational institutions are exempted from the legislation.

The Bill also makes unlawful discrimination in the provision of goods and services, including services relating to banking, insurance and the provision of loans, credit or finance, and services of the kind provided by government authorities or local government bodies.

The Bill makes it unlawful for a club, the committee of management of a club or a committee member to discriminate on the ground of sex, marital status or pregnancy in relation to members or applicants for membership. A club is defined as an association of not less than 30 persons which provides and maintains its facilities from its funds and which sells or supplies liquor for consumption on its premises.

It will also be unlawful for a person who performs functions or exercises powers under Commonwealth laws or for the purposes of a Commonwealth program to discriminate on the ground of sex, marital status or pregnancy in carrying out such functions or powers.

The Bill provides for a number of exemptions and in this regard closely follows the State sex discrimination legislation with respect to the provisions of exemptions from the legislation. I need mention only the exemption for acts done to achieve equal opportunities for persons of a particular sex or marital status with persons of the opposite sex or another marital status. An exemption which will be of particular interest to senators is that it is not to be unlawful for a person to discriminate against a woman on the ground of her sex in connection with employment, engagement in or appointment to the Defence Force in a position involving performance of combat or combat-related duties. Honourable senators should however know that a review is at present being undertaken of employment practices, with a view to opening more positions to women in the Defence Force.

In respect to sport, the legislation covers sporting facilities. It will not apply to participation in sporting activities as such, although this is a matter on which the Government wishes to receive comment.

Provision is also made for applications to the Human Rights Commission for a temporary exemption from the operation of the legislation. Exemptions will be able to be granted for periods not exceeding 5 years.

The Bill specifically makes unlawful discrimination involving sexual harassment in employment by employers or by co-workers and in education by members of staff . The Commonwealth is the first jurisdiction to introduce such provisions, although I understand that Victoria, New South Wales and South Australia are considering similar provisions.

The Bill does not attempt to deal with all forms of sexual harassment but only with sexual harassment which can be characterised as discriminatory in nature, in the sense that it is linked to a belief that a rejection of an unwelcome sexual advance, and unwelcome request for sexual favours or other unwelcome sexual conduct would disadvantage the person in relation to employment or educational studies. The Government will be considering how best to deal with other forms of sexual harassment and will be seeking the views of women's organisations on this matter.

Administration of the Bill is vested in the Human Rights Commission. The functions of the Commission will include holding inquiries into and making determinations on complaints; hearing applications for exemption from the Act; undertaking research and educational programs; and examination of existing and proposed legislation to ensure its consistency with the provisions of this Act.

The Bill establishes a Sex Discrimination Commissioner who is required to investigate and conciliate complaints of discrimination. The Commissioner will be empowered to obtain information and documents and to direct specified persons to attend a compulsory conference. Where the Commissioner is unable to resolve a complaint by conciliation, he or she will refer the matter to the Human Rights Commission. The Human Rights Commission is required to inquire into the complaint. To this end the Commission can summon people to appear before it and may take evidence and retain documents. Provision is made for counsel to appear at an inquiry to assist the Commission. Persons appearing before the Commission will be required to answer questions, but the Bill provides that no answer is admissible in evidence against the person in any civil or criminal proceeding before a court.

After holding an inquiry, the Commissioner may either dismiss the complaint or, if it finds the complaint substantiated, make a determination, which may include a declaration that the respondent to the complaint should not continue or repeat the unlawful conduct; or that the respondent should redress any loss or damage suffered by the complainant; or that the respondent should pay to the complainant damages by way of compensation for any loss or damage suffered by the complainant as a result of the act of discrimination. While such determinations are not binding on the parties, on the basis of the experience with the State legislation, we anticipate that the majority of them will be accepted by the parties and acted upon in most instances. Where this does not happen the complainant or the Commision may seek an order from the Federal Court to enforce the Commission's determination.

In order to ensure that complainants are not prevented from proceeding with complaints by reason of cost, the Bill makes provision for the Human Rights Commission to recommend to the Attorney-General that assistance be given to a person in respect of costs incurred in proceedings before the Commission. Application may also be made to the Attorney-General for assistance before the Federal Court.

The Bill provides for the Commission to delegate all or any of its powers to a member of the Commission, a member of staff of the Commission or another person or body of persons. A similar power of delegation is conferred on the Sex Discrimination Commissioner in relation to inquiry into and conciliation of complaints. This delegation power will make it possible for the Government to work towards the establishment of co-operative arrangements with the existing anti-discrimination bodies in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia and other States which enact suitable legislation.

In all States we will ensure that advice is available about the range of rights and remedies so that every complainant will be able to make an informed choice about the course of action most appropriate to his or her circumstances.

Honourable senators will be aware that a major part of my earlier private member's Bill-the Part concerning affirmative action-is not included here. The Government will issue a Green Paper setting out options for further legislation providing for the introduction and implementation of affirmative action programs in employment. Recognising the need for employers, employees, unions and the community generally to be better informed, the Government has decided that it is more appropriate to generate public discussion and understanding of its proposals and to have wide ranging consultations in advance of the introduction of legislation.

The introduction of this Bill represents the initial step towards the fulfilment of the Government's major election commitment to women. The Bill will be debated early in the Budget sitting. Preliminary consultations with the ACTU and the National Labour Consultative Council have taken place and the Government hopes that trade unions, employer and women's organisations and other interested persons will use the time between now and the Budget sittings to familiarise themselves with its provisions.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1983TAXATION (UNPAID INCOME TAX-DIVIDENDS) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Had not the 1982 taxation legislation been introduced and assessments sent out in the normal course of events for current year company tax, the new buyers and not the vendors would have been legally responsible for the undistributed company profits tax and personal income tax which may have been attracted as a result of those distributions. But because the buyers did not have the funds to pay their taxation, that assessment was visited upon the vendor shareholders. Any reasonable person would agree that if we were retrospectively to apply to vendor shareholders the responsibility for somebody else's unpaid company tax, it would not be at all unreasonable to allow that person the opportunity to arrange the theoretical financial affairs of the company that was taken from him by the sale . In other words, if the vendor has to pay somebody else's company bills he should, for the purposes of taxation, be reinstated with control of the financial arrangements of the company, inasmuch as everything is theoretic because the financial year was artificially set at the time of the sale. Otherwise, we are visiting upon the vendor the responsibilities and the liabilities of the company and none of the decision-making rights which ultimately led to the level of the assessment.

SPEECH.PARA: If the vendor is to be visited retrospectively with a liability for the company which arose after he was legally responsible for that company, he should be entitled to a consideration as to how the affairs of the company theoretically would have been managed had it not passed from his hands. To that extent, the 1982 legislation allowed a notional distribution of current year profits by the vendor shareholder. That, of course, allowed him the opportunity to make a judgment as to what might have been commercially reasonable and responsible had he had the company to 30 June, the end of the financial year.

However, the legislation now before us not only removes any perogative or discretion by the vendor, but also has the effect of demanding from the vendor shareholders current year company tax and assumes that a company's total net accumulated assets are liquidated and distributed in totality to the shareholders. Vendor-shareholders are then to be taxed individually at the personal income tax rate, ranging from 60c to 69.62c in the dollar, upon the deemed value of the deemed assets which have been deemed to have been distributed to the shareholders. Of course, almost without exception, no such dividend was ever received and was retained by the individual shareholders.

As I said from the outset, the proposal contained in this Bill does not seek to recoup revenue that was lost to the Government by fraud, but seeks by special and punitive legislation to overturn retrospectively the laws of this land which have been confirmed by the High Court of Australia, the Full Bench of the High Court, as I recall. The vendor shareholders have in the past been asked to repay revenue previously lost to the Government, to pay current year company profits tax which was defrauded by those to whom the vendor-shareholders sold their companies. That is the only tax that has been lost to revenue of which the vendor-shareholders ultimately received the benefit. The fact of the matter is that the vendors sold their companies under existing laws. Chief Justice Barwick , in Slutzkin v. Commissioner of Taxation case, stated:

It was no more than a realisation by them of the benefit of their shareholders in a way which would not attract tax. It may be granted that a purchaser of the shares could not have been found willing to pay the price in cash which in fact was agreed to be paid unless the company had made its assets liquid and itself free of debt, and that all the shareholders were willing to sell their shares.

. . . But the choice of the former transaction by which a taxpayer obtains the benefit of his assets is a matter for him; he is quite entitled to choose that form of taxation which will not subject him to tax, or subject him only to less tax than some other form of transaction might do.

Vendor-shareholders have sold their shares in a tax-free, legitimate fashion and now the Government seeks retrospectively to create a new and penal taxation. It is not a taxation previously lost to revenue which the Government seeks to recoup, but a new tax which is not only artificial and retrospective but also is of a capital gains nature. The revenue received by vendors for their shares was of a capital nature, as has been clearly demonstrated by the Slutzkin case to which I referred a moment ago. Yet now that capital gain is to be taxed at levels, as I have said, between 60c and 69.2c in the dollar. That is on top of the 46c in the dollar which has already been paid on the same money by way of company tax, and, presumably, Division 7 tax.

I give the Senate a simple example to demonstrate the threatening position into which this legislation places many businesses in Australia. A company may have been operating for 20 years as a family concern. Over those years it may have acquired, net of tax, capital profits of, let us say, $200,000, together with revenue profits of $100,000. Under this iniquitous law proposed by the Labor Government, notwithstanding the fact that the company is still operating, the family will now find itself liable for a taxation bill of about $210,000. By way of example, I refer the Senate to a real case. A family in this position has said:

We are currently paying taxes of $2,800,000. If this new piece of legislation is enacted, we will be faced with penalty taxes of $5,148,000. Irrespective of ' time to pay' concessions we cannot hope to raise this sum. Who could? $2,169,000 of this penalty relates to 'goodwill'-which has zero cash actuality and has never before been taxed-and is still not taxed in Australia or in any other country.

That is what makes this legislation so vastly different from that which we have experienced in the past. Many of these companies in which the shares have been sold are old family companies. The purchasers who assumed responsibility for the shares were not interested in carrying on the business of the company but the family was. Accordingly, the business was sold to another company in which the family had ownership of the shares and the business continued on as it did prior to the sale. The only way in which the company could afford to buy the business back was to use the funds that were received from the sale of the original shares. Hence there was no cash surplus and, for all practical purposes, no cash profit. In fact, there was a net loss because promoter's fees and legal fees have had to be subtracted from the purchase price.

The net result of all this is that a family business remained in the family but simply changed from one family company to another family company. In the meantime, thanks to this diabolical legislation, the transaction is likely to attract a capital gains tax of between 60c and 69.2c in the dollar. As I hypothesised earlier, a business worth $300,000 which changed from one family company to another without any real cash benefit will now, under the Labor Government's proposal, be liable for a tax bill of over $200,000 and a penalty rate of 20 per cent per annum if the family cannot afford to pay. That is a further provision of the legislation. As I have said, in such circumstances the company must become insolvent and go into bankruptcy. That, in stark terms, is the effect of the Labor Party's new capital gains tax. Let us take, for example, a man who bought a company for $100,000, traded it for 12 months without success , made a modest profit and sold it. Now he will find himself subject to this 60 per cent tax. He had a capital outlay in the first place of $100,000, he sold the company for approximately the same amount and he now finds as a result of that activity that he is left with 40 per cent of his original outlay.

The Bill proposes, amongst other things, the omission from the principal Act of sub-section 3 (12), which has been described by some as the innocence clause. It is quite different from the innocence clause that I sought to have inserted in the legislation before us last year, which I ultimately voted against. It presently applies where, after a stripped company was sold to a promoter, it entered into a scheme which, though ultimately found to be unsuccessful, at the time it was entered into could reasonably have been expected to be effective for tax avoidance purposes. In that case, provided such a scheme was not connected with the arrangement which rendered the company unable to pay its tax, and the arrangement which had that effect had not been entered into for that purpose, liability to recoupment tax was ascertained as if the scheme had been affective in reducing or eliminating the amount of company tax payable.

The object of this section in the principal Act of 1982 was to ensure that recoupment tax was collected only from those companies that had been sold, however innocently, to a promoter who, to use a colloquialism, put them at the bottom of the harbour, thereby extinguishing the company's capacity to pay its tax. In other words, where an arrangement was entered into between the vendor shareholders and the purchaser and where the purchaser upon acquiring the company used or sought to use a legal scheme for mitigating taxation, the vendor shareholder was not held liable for the company's tax. If the scheme is ultimately found to fail in its attempt to reduce the company's tax, the normal provision of the Income Tax Assessment Act will prevail and the receipt of the tax will be pursued by the Commissioner of Taxation in the normal course. Whatever tax is due and payable by the responsible company or shareholders will be recouped as best as possible within the provisions of the present Act.

Let us not forget for a moment the role, the purpose and the intention of this recoupment taxation legislation. It is a special and unique piece of legislation designed to recoup from vendor shareholders taxation, a major part of the benefit of which they have ultimately received as a result of the fraudulent activities of those to whom they sold the shares in their company, notwithstanding the fact that the vendor-shareholders had no knowledge or could not have been expected to have any knowledge of the fraudulent activities of the buyers.

The Government now intends that this Bill is to be widened to collect new taxes from people who acted completely within the law and who in no way have received the benefit of evaded taxation. Included in this Bill is provision for the Commissioner of Taxation to name in his annual report for presentation to Parliament those people who under this Bill fail to pay their recoupment tax. The words 'fail to pay' simply mean that those people do not pay. It does not matter whether they cannot pay or whether they have lodged an objection. It simply means that if they have not paid their taxation on the basis of the assessment that is sent out their name ignominiously will be entered into the report of the Commissioner of Taxation. That is an extension of the present section 14 of the the Income Tax Assessment Act, which provides:
In the report the Commissioner shall-
Shall, not may-
draw attention to any breaches or evasions of this Act which have come under his notice.

I ask honourable senators to note the words 'breaches or evasions'. The section makes no reference to those poor souls who simply cannot pay their bills. It is argued that at present, the Commissioner of Taxation uses certain guidelines. The fact of the matter is that section 14 says he 'shall'. There is no discretion. With respect, I ask: What is his yardstick? What are the guidelines he will use when he makes a determination, under the wording of this Act, in the event that people fail to pay their taxes, that their names shall be inserted in the report? There is no yardstick; the names of all those people will be included in the report. I must say that those people already receive publicity through the appropriate court actions when the Commissioner of Taxation files for bankruptcy or when he files the appropriate legal documents seeking to recover, through the courts, taxation which he believes is owing to the Crown. Those people receive all the publicity they need.

I remind the Senate that when the 1982 legislation was being debated that clause was in the Bill originally. When the then Treasurer, John Howard, and officials of the Australian Taxation Office were asked to state clearly, unequivocally, unambiguously and categorically the object, intention and purpose of putting in that provision they made it quite clear that it was to intimidate people, to blackmail people, to force people out of fear of adverse and unfair community criticism and public exposure into not objecting and not using their democratic rights within the Income Tax Assessment Act; it was simply to force them to pay their bills whether they liked it or not, or suffer the ignominy of having their names dragged through this Parliament as if they were tax evaders or had been party to some sort of breach, which was the original intention of section 14 of the original Act. People will not draw a distinction between the two.

In the moments left to me in this debate I wish to touch upon a couple of matters. What I find terribly evil about this legislation is that it matters not what the relationship is between the amount of failed company tax and the amount of assets of the company. A company could fail to pay a taxation assessment of $ 250, have assets of both a capital and a revenue nature of $1m and then find itself subject to a theoretic distribution of its assets. As a result of that company owing $250 in revenue to the Crown it would be liable to pay personal income tax on $1m. Let us remember that the accumulated profits of a company are nothing more than the net benefit, the net profits, of that company that has paid its taxation at the present rate of 46c in the dollar and 50c in the dollar for Division 7 tax. What is left over is the body of the company. If that is assessed at betwen 60 and 70 per cent there is no company. One cannot sell assets these days. One cannot sell plant and equipment. One cannot give them away. One could not raffle them in a backwater hotel in Fremantle. The Government is guaranteeing the bankruptcy of many employers and the destruction of many jobs.

I turn to the other provision which is now included in this legislation; that is, the provision to reduce the number of former owners on whom the Commissioner of Taxation is required to serve copies of a stripped company's assessment notice. As I understand it, under the new provision the assessment is required to be sent only to the principal shareholder. I understand the rationale and the logic put forward by the Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins, in that it makes for greater efficiency and prevents delays in collecting the money. I just ask the Government: What is more important-expediency or principle? We have a situation in which there is a new tax, in my view probably an illegal tax, a punitive tax-

TALK.START.PARA: —How can you say that is illegal?

—We will establish that in due course. It may well be challenged in the High Court of Australia-I did say 'may well be'. Under this provision people are assessed, a penalty of 20 per cent, which they cannot afford to pay, is added, and an assessment is sent out to only one person. Fifty people could be involved. Under this legislation all of them are found culpable. All are subject to assessments. All of them are subject to legal action if they do not pay the tax. Under this provision they are not even allowed to know that they are responsible. A tax is imposed, of which notice is not given, and if those people do not pay the Government ensures that their names are put in a report which is presented to Parliament. To say the least, this is a diabolical piece of legislation. Without question it ought to be defeated.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a real need in this debate to return to the core of the issue. There is a real need to get away from some of the spurious technicalities that people, such as Senator Crichton-Browne, have put to this chamber.
—And faulty.
—And faulty representations. There is a real need to get away from the pleading humbug from the corporate crooks' friend from Western Australia. There is a real need to get back to the--
—I beg your pardon! Say that again, slowly.

—My mind does not think slowly enough for Senator Crichton-Browne 's brain. There is a real need to get back to the basic issues of this campaign. There is a real need to get to the cancer that is basic to the system of revenue raising in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: This Labor Government is intent on destroying the tax avoidance industry. These measures are an integral step towards the destruction of that industry. It is an industry which has been highlighted time and again in this Parliament by Labor spokespeople. But it is one that had not been brought to the attention of the previous Government sufficiently until the interim report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union which was presented approximately 12 months ago. It is worth going back to that time, to that report, to see what Royal Commissioner Costigan said.
He talked of the one industry that blossomed under Fraserism; that is, the tax avoidance industry. He said:

The industry has developed in Australia, particularly over the last five years, at a rate far in excess of any other industry and has brought with it profits comparable only to the heady days of the Victorian gold rush . . .
In which the former Prime Minister's antecedents were involved. Royal Commissioner Costigan continued:
the impact on the community has been very serious.

That is the context in which we are looking at this debate and these measures. When one looks at official reports, reports which the previous Government was not prepared to recognise, one sees the magnitude of the problem. If one looks at the reports of the Commissioner of Taxation one will see that there has been an increase of over 2,500 per cent in identified participants in tax avoidance between the 1975-76 financial year and the financial year 1980-81. That is a massive increase. That was allowed to continue under the eyes of the Government of the current Opposition. It took absolutely no cognisance of it.

What was the former Government's response? While tax avoidance was increasing and blossoming we had a rather scandalous situation in that the Fraser Government's response, through the implementation of the razor gang proposals, was actually to decrease the number of people working for government in implementing tax laws. When one looks at some of the sections of the current taxation Act one sees that because of a lack of resources some of the proposals have not been implemented.

But it was not only the Costigan report which highlighted the problem. It had been in existence for some time and had been brought to the Government's attention for some time. The root of the problem also is related to one of the demagogues of the current Opposition-former Chief Justice Barwick. On 18 October 1982 David Solomon, in an article in the Australian Financial Review stated:
Tax avoidance as an industry is a comparatively recent phenomenon.
We agree with that statement. He goes on to sheet home the blame for the blossoming of the industry to Chief Justice Barwick. He stated:
. . . and it was able to blossom-
He is referring to the industry-

because of the destruction of section 260 of the Act by the Barwick Court. The Barwick High Court during the 70s effectively put a time bomb under both the Australian taxation system and the Liberal Party.

As we found out last year, this is very true. We saw the Liberal Party in this Parliament trying to act in some effective way to protect public revenue. It is interesting to note, when one looks at the performance of the Barwick High Court , some of the comments made by Chief Justice Barwick. In a rather amoral statement from the bench he stated:

. . . the choice of the form of transaction by which a taxpayer obtains a benefit of his assets is a matter for him; he is quite entitled to choose that form of transaction which will not be subject to tax, or subject him only to less tax than some other form of transaction might do.
That is a rather curious amoral statement from the bench of the High Court of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. The honourable senator is not reflecting on ex-Chief Justice Barwick; he is reflecting, contrary to Standing Orders, on the entire bench of the High Court.
—There is no point of order.

—I thank the honourable senator for giving me time to collect my thoughts. As I said, the problem has gone on for some time. Yet, despite public opposition, we still have a continuation of the cancer of tax avoidance. This week's financial Press contains the most recent advertisement from Peter Clyne, in which he states:

SPEECH.PARA: Tax avoidance is alive and well in Australia!!!
A complete four-cassette recording (6-hours) is now available of what was said at my recent tax survival congress. Hard-core, practical methods . . .
One wonders what he is talking about. The advertisement continues:

. . . how to delay your tax claims at least five years . . . how to salvage your assets in the meanwhile . . . Twelve new, proven, Hawke-proof ways to earn a tax -free income. How to kill a tax investigation.

This advertisement shows the morality of the sorts of people we are talking about. It is the type of immorality that needs to be prevented by concrete and comprehensive government action. Professor Mathews is a person whom I have quoted a number of times in this place. I will do so once more for the benefit of people such as Senator Crichton-Browne. In a speech in 1980 he made a point which quite adequately summed up the Australian taxation system at the time. He stated:
Personal income tax is a voluntary tax for the rich non-salary earner.

That statement explains effectively the injustice that is being perpetrated at the moment. Those wage and salary earners who are in most need of financial assistance are the ones not being represented by the Opposition in this place.

I have mentioned part of the previous Government's record. I will not refer to it much more, except to note that a report of the Commissioner for Taxation during the mid-1970s highlighted the problem. In May 1978 the Taxation Commissioner stated:
I recommend that a new criminal offence be created to catch those involved in current year profit strips.
In 1979, in his report to the Treasurer, he stated:
The problem of straw companies, straw trust evasion, is already very serious and growing. It is my considered advice that the situation needs to be remedied urgently and with stern measures.

Advice was always being given to the previous Government. It was never really acted on. That is the context of the problem we are facing today. The other part of that context is that we have been elected to government on the basis of one of the important parts of our policy-that is, to put an end to tax avoidance and to redistribute the tax cake fairly and equitably. These measures are important because they will raise $590m over the next couple of financial years.

What is the principle of this legislation? What is the Government trying to do? It can be spelt out in very simple terms. The Government's intention is embodied in the Bills which we are discussing at the moment. The principle is that those who benefited from the sale of shares in companies that were stripped of pre-tax profits should not be limited to the tax that ought to have been paid by the companies concerned. They should also pay the tax that, as shareholders or other former owners, they escaped through receipt in a non-taxable capital form of accumulated after tax profits which, if the companies had continued to operate as going concerns, would have been taxable dividends in their hands. There is nothing new about this principle. Essentially, we are asking this Parliament to endorse a system whereby tax avoided should now be paid.

Let us look at what the former Liberal Prime Minister had to say about the sorts of mechanisms we are attacking at the moment. In a speech which the former Prime Minister delivered at a meeting during the Kingston election campaign- obviously, it was a very unsuccessful meeting, I am pleased to say, because we have had a change in representation of the Kingston electorate since the speech was made-on Monday 30 August 1982, he said:

. . . special legislation will be introduced to recover the funds that would otherwise have been paid as tax over past years. That is not creating a new liability, it is collecting the funds that should have been paid in any case. In a real sense, the recipients of those funds have in their hands stolen funds, whether you want to say stolen from the Commonwealth or stolen from other taxpayers it doesn't matter very much.

Today we are extending the ambit of the legislation put into effect by the previous Government. There is nothing radical in what we are doing. It is an extension to cover the field, rather than half the field. The Opposition in this place cannot at the moment cop the fact that mechanisms which it initiated in this place are being used by this Government to do the job that it did not do adequately.

In implementing this sort of principle, we are inserting recoupment tax laws in the legislation. We fix the liability of former owners of stripped companies for personal income tax on accumulated profits received by them as part of the price received for the sale of their shares. This entails a mechanism providing that the former owner of a stripped company will pay income tax on the basis that that company had paid a dividend to the former owner at the time of the sale of the shares and that the amount of the imputed dividend will be that same proportion of the company's total after tax accumulated profits as a sale consideration received by the owner. It is not fair to say, as previous speakers from the Opposition have said, that it is a totally unbridled approach. There are concessions and safeguards. I am sure that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) representing the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) in summing up will adequately deal with those safeguards. Essentially, some of the safeguards provide that the amount to be collected allows for concessions for unpaid company tax which will be recouped under existing legislation. The amount will also provide that a dividend can be deemed to have been paid where the former owner is liable to make good unpaid company tax. These Bills will return to public revenue money that should have been there in the first place. That is one point of the argument to which the Opposition will not address itself.

The Opposition has raised a number of points in opposing these Bills. It has claimed that no tax has been evaded because the persons involved would not have had to pay personal tax on the capital profits. That is a rather interesting argument. It is one which, in its simplicity, can be pursued with empty rhetoric . But the Opposition moves away from the basic facts involved in this sort of approach. The facts are that the companies involved were, in essence, ongoing concerns. The existing law provides that revenue and capital profits distributed by an ongoing company should be taxed in full. It is not a new initiative. The former Government last year did exactly the same sort of thing in respect of another area by inserting Part IVA into the current income tax legislation. The current Minister for Finance referring to the discredited former Treasurer and current Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, stated:

He knew what he was doing when he introduced and successfully passed through this Parliament Part IVA of the current income tax law. He knew what he was doing then, and he knows full well that if any company went to the bottom-of-the -harbour after Part IVA was in operation exactly the same kind of taxes would be collected as are intended to be collected as a result of this legislation. He knows that Part IVA goes beyond the collection of unpaid company tax and goes to the point of collecting the unpaid income tax which would have been paid had the benefits been received by the shareholders in the form of dividends and been taxed in the normal way.
Mr Dawkins goes on to say:
On this occasion we are simply extending the principles that he--
That is, the previous Government-
introduced quite properly in relation to Part IVA to the areas which he retrospectively acted against late last year.

So much for the spurious humbug about radical socialist initiatives on the part of the Labor Government. What we are doing is extending provisions that were made in the Act by the current Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

Another point that has been raised time and again relates to the rate of taxation. There is opposition to the imposition of taxation at marginal rates for the year of income in which the shares were sold. But one cannot escape the fact that this is so because it is taxation at that rate that has effectively been avoided. It is the rate of taxation which would have been levied had the money been transferred, both morally and legally, at the time of operation. It is the rate of taxation which this Government now seeks to collect.

The third and final point is one that the Opposition has been harping on for quite some time in respect of this matter. I refer to retrospectivity. The Liberal Party has never been shy to use retrospectivity when it has wanted to do so. In 1950, in introducing the Communist Party Dissolution Bill, Mr Menzies had some comments to make about retrospectivity. He justified the use of retrospective legislation at that time by the enormity of the problem that he foresaw. He said:
Our Communist enemies are known; they have been active at least since the selected date-
Which was over two years beforehand. That Bill, with retrospective effect, labelled people as at least two years previous to its passage.

I need only also turn to the Age of Monday 22 November 1982 and quote a comment from Mr Hunt, the Leader of the Liberal Party in the Upper House in Victoria. Let us see what he had to say about retrospective legislation and contrast it with the bleatings that we have been hearing over the last week or so from the Opposition. He said:

If anyone tells me that it is not Liberal or contrary to principle, I say we don't belong to the same party. It is nonsense to create an overall principle where none exists. There is no principle that all retrospective legislation is contrary to the principles of the party. What has happened this time is that someone who did not like bottom-of-the-harbour legislation has sought to raise a principle and use it to criticise the then Government by innuendo.

So much for the lie, then. The Bench also has recognised that retrospective legislation can be useful, and need not be illegal, as Senator Crichton-Browne has indicated. My colleague Senator Tate yesterday made a couple of references and cited a couple of cases. I need not do the same, but I shall refer to a statement by Mr Justice Adam who, as is recorded in 1960 Victorian Law Reports, in the case of D'Oro and the Victorian Railways Commissioner, said:

The strength of the presumption against retrospectivity in any particular case, and accordingly the ease or difficulty with which it may be overcome, must, I would think, depend on the nature and degree of the injustice which would result from giving the statute a retrospective operation.
He went on to say that if it was clearly required--
to rectify a manifest injustice to others, there would, on principle, seem little reason for giving much weight to the presumption.

He was referring to the presumption against the operation of retrospective legislation. So we have to look at the detriment to the community. In doing so, we look at the magnitude of the problem, which I have mentioned earlier. It is not unreasonable to argue that $7,000m has been lost to revenue because of tax avoidance schemes. In the Parliament last week figures were given in another place that, in the last financial year, the payment of $2.7 billion could very well have been avoided by this sort of operation. It is the Government's responsibility to act firmly and responsibly, and in the way in which it is acting now.

We have reached almost the end of the second reading debate. We are now coming fairly close to a vote on this matter. I should like to address my comments to the magnitude of the vote that we are about to take. The revenue to be gathered under this legislation amounts to about $590m-of previously avoided taxation liability. When Opposition senators, Australian Democrats, and individual senators make up their minds on the matter they need to ask themselves how, if this money is lost to revenue, that loss will be compensated? How will the Government be able to put into effect measures that have been promised, that have already been committed, if, because of Opposition action it cannot raise this revenue?

Will the Government have to resort to the raising of indirect taxation? In answer to a question asked in this chamber yesterday, Senator Walsh gave a number of facts on the cost of defeating this sort of measure, the cost of lining the pockets of those who have avoided taxation liabilities in the past. The cost to the pockets of those who can least afford it could very well be over $100 for each Australian taxpayer. It could be a 7 per cent across the board increase in sales tax, whether on beer, cigarettes, or goods of necessity. Let me note here that the Democrats is one party that, over the last couple of years at least, has rejected the imposition of sales taxes on goods that have been labelled goods of necessity.

Would it lead to an increase in the consumer price index? Let us look at some of the individual responsiblities that we, as senators, have to our own States. In respect of South Australia, would it lead to the imposition of a wine tax, a tax which our State has opposed time and again? What options does the Government have if this revenue is not available to it? As regards Tasmania, will the Government, because of the lack of revenue-and it is ironical in this case that the amounts are the same-be able sufficiently to compensate Tasmania if and when it loses the proceedings in the High Court? Tasmanian senators should think about that. In respect to some of the comments of Senator Kilgariff yesterday, it is curious to note that the cost of the Alice Springs-Darwin railway line would be about $570m to $590m. What sort of capacity will we then have to contribute the 60 per cent that we are prepared to give towards the building of that line?

It is those sorts of measures that ought to be considered when we are talking of redistributing expected government revenue from the pockets of those that we as a parliament decide need it, to the pockets of those who have illegally and amorally misappropriated government revenue over the last 10 years. It is those sorts of responsibilities that we should be looking at. I, for one, do not want to see a wine tax imposed in South Australia, and I shall be fighting against that, but I hope that that sort of consideration is in the minds of South Australian senators, whether of the Australian Democrats party or of the Liberal Party.

The other matter I should like to raise in closing this debate is in respect to the pressures that have been placed on members of parliament during it. Luckily, I suppose, I am one of those whose decision has been anticipated and I have received only about 100 telegrams. But it is curious to note, in respect of that , that when a matter affecting the rights of wage and salary earners arises for debate here, such people do not have the means and money to make that sort of lobbying effort against measures which may affect them detrimentally. But in this case people are sending telegrams from the Lakeside Hotel. In some cases, people are sending at least half a dozen telegrams from the same address.

However, what is more scandalous is the matter that was raised by Senator Chipp a couple of days ago. I congratulate him for raising it publicly and courageously. Senator Chipp made public the offer of bribes to the Democrats in respect of this taxation vote. He said that several people had offered substantial contributions to the Democrats' finances if the five Democrats senators would vote against the legislation. Apart from its being a breach of privilege to my mind, I suggest that that sort of activity, in doing no good for the cause of those perpetrating it, also raises a problem which we have identified in the past. It is one that I would expect the Government to act on urgently. I refer to the need for a register of pecuniary interests. When matters of this sort of magnitude are involved, when billions of dollars are involved, when the decision rests on individual members, the public needs to know what sorts of considerations are being taken into account. In this respect I am not saying that anyone in this place has been influenced. I am glad to see that Senator Chipp and the Democrats have rejected that sort of bribery, as I believe would other senators. I need only turn to a comment made in November last year by former Senator Thomas from Western Australia. He said:
Libs took evaders' cash . . .
He went on to say that the amount involved was 'hundreds rather than thousands' of dollars. The former honourable senator made that statement and about 24 hours later he was forced to retract it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The preselection committee stood over him.

—As Senator Walsh says, preselection might have had something to do with it, but those sorts of pressures have been around for quite a considerable time. Until we do have legislation which will make public the interests of members of parliament we, as a parliament, and the community as a whole, will not have adequate protection against these sorts of pressures. I wish to say no more in respect of this legislation other than to reiterate that final point-that the cost to revenue of this legislation being defeated is immense. I hope sanity can prevail in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate we are talking about very large sums of money-over half a billion dollars-which the Government estimates are due to the national revenue as income tax from people who took part in the notorious bottom-of-the-harbour tax dodge schemes. To get the matter into some kind of proportion, it is interesting and important to notice that if that amount were lost to revenue through the failure to pass this legislation it would represent considerably more than the entire cost of the major job creation schemes recently announced by the Government as part of the so-called mini- Budget. I think that in itself is a matter of concern to the community of this country and especially to the young unemployed and their families. The use of money in societies like our own is a matter of priority and, as we in this place know, those priorities are very hard to establish. There are always cases everywhere for more money. I believe that in itself-to state a first principle- is an argument for as much government revenue as is reasonably, morally and legally due to be paid by the people who are due to pay it.

SPEECH.PARA: The $570m at stake is, as I have said, very big money. It has also attracted a very heavy volume of lobbying from people. I must say that I share the comment of the last speaker, Senator Bolkus, that the lobbying seems to be coming from people who have big money. This is instanced by their ability to flood this place with enormous quantities of telegrams to the extent, I gather, that even the telegram service is complaining about some obstruction in some areas because of the sheer volume of this material. I refer to the large amounts of paper circulating and, of course, to these people's ability to buy full page advertisements in national newspapers. They do not come cheaply, as all honourable senators would know. I have tried to understand and read what these people are on about. I have spoken to a considerable number of them and as a result I have come to certain conclusions. But I fairly ought to add that I have also had numerous representations which have urged me to vote for the legislation. Many of those representations have come from people I know well and who are, indeed, very successful business men and women. I trust and respect their opinions. All those points in fact apply to a person from whose telegram to me I will now quote. That person stated:

There is no more effective way of scotching the tax avoidance industry-as it is euphemistically referred to-than to establish the principle that tax evasion loopholes may be plugged retrospectively. Over many years dealing with several top accounting firms who proposed bottom of the harbour and other devices be used by them in dealing with my affairs, I can clearly state that they always made it known that such schemes were of questionable legality, and therefore I rejected them.

I will repeat that statement because it is of great importance. I also repeat that it comes from a person who is very well qualified to know this and who is in contact with other people who would be well qualified to know this. I repeat that he said:
. . . I can clearly state that they always made it known that such schemes were of questionable legality, and therefore I rejected them.
He concluded by stating:
Any hurt that would be done to true innocents by the legislation is minimal.

I add that this statement comes from a person who I know to be of the highest integrity and who is not given to overstatement. I believe that his statement to me is honest and direct and that I can take it at its full face value. I commend that statement as such to honourable senators.

The bottom-of-the-harbour schemes were simple, even crude, in their basic approach. As I understand them, a company with a tax liability was sold to persons who could not be traced-to criminals and the like who assumed false names-at a figure greater than the company was really worth when its tax liability was taken into account. The new owners simply disappeared, having sent all the company records-to use the picturesque phrase which I think has now become a part of the ethos of this country-to the bottom of the harbour, thereby allowing the old owners to avoid paying tax on the accumulated profits of the company disposed of.

We are told that this is good clean fun, that it is definitely part of the rights of the citizen and that probably many people used such schemes not knowing that they were doing anything wrong. I simply cannot believe that. I cannot believe that people who used such a scheme did not know what they were doing. They must have been fully aware that they were depriving the state of revenue which would have to be replaced by higher taxation of their fellow citizens or, alternatively, not replaced at all, thereby placing a great hardship on the poor and vulnerable in this society who, heaven knows, are numerous enough and growing and whose problems are much greater with every day that passes. Indeed, it is a fact that because of the huge deficit we now face in this country and the general tightness of government funds, it is not possible to deal with and solve the problems of the poor and disadvantaged in this country in the way they should be.

Every night in Sydney, which is part of my electorate, hundreds of people sleep in the open. I have seen people going through the shopping centres at lunch time , picking through garbage bins to get food to eat. A while ago I spoke to one of these people. He was a very cultured and educated man who had lost his job. These people are desperate. I cannot believe that the representations we have had over the last week about this legislation causing so-called hardship to people who indulge in the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes are in anywhere near the same class. Rather, I would say that those people who benefited from the bottom- of-the-harbour schemes cannot evade a clear share of the responsibility for such shameful occurrences in this country which is supposed to be an egalitarian country capable of providing a decent way of life and a decent means of survival for all its people.

I take the old-fashioned view that those who share the protection and assets of the state, as we all do, have the strongest possible moral obligation to contribute to the cost of those things. Of course, this is the purpose of taxation. That is what it is about and what it has always been about. Whilst I can see that the desparately poor could have the incentives of poverty and deprivation to avoid this obligation, I cannot see that those who can well afford to pay should feel morally entitled not to pay. I do not believe they should come and seek sympathy from us and from the community on the basis that they have been hardly done by.

This seems to me to be a symptom of a serious and very dangerous national disease. One would have thought, as was once the case in decent societies and democracies, that the successful and enterprising people-the leaders of the community in many respects-also would take a lead in supporting reasonable public morality, especially in public affairs. If we lose that we have lost a great deal. I feel we are in grave danger of losing it. Of course, that is basically what this legislation is all about. This is not merely an airy-fairy idealistic concept. It is one of the most basic practicalities. If enough people who can afford to pay instead elect to take and not to give, the national structure must become dangerously weakened. I would have thought that it would not be a matter of very great perception to see that. Of course it is true that tax dodging schemes have greatly weakened the national structure of this country . I believe it is a prime responsibility of honourable senators to correct that quickly and effectively and not to allow themselves to be dissuaded from that task.

Last year the Liberal Government's legislation extracted unpaid company tax from people who used these bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. Much of the present lobbying against these Bills is based-we have heard this frequently in this debate in the Senate-on the fact that the call is for tax to be paid on money which has already been taxed. I find that a strange, hollow thing to be saying because there is nothing unusual about it. Any of us who have shares in a company-the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd or whatever-receive dividends on profits on which company tax has been paid. We know full well we also have to pay income tax on it. We cannot put it into another company and employ people without paying that income tax. We may not like it but that is the law.

On what basis then do these bottom-of-the- harbour people claim exemption from this process that applies to all law abiding and responsible citizens? Of course , the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes are only some of a variety of schemes, all based on our rickety gimcrack income tax law which is a disgrace to our country and all of us in this place. It urgently needs reform and is wide open to abuse. It appears to have been left that way, for whatever reasons may be divined. Such law has guaranteed that schemes are brought forward regularly to ensure that the rich pay little or no tax while the poor and those on limited incomes, especially wage and salary earners, in effect subsidise them. This has been going on for years to the tune of millions, even billions, of dollars. Nobody denies it. It is important to consider the situation in which we can allow such a monstrous thing to happen and yet say there is some argument against doing anything about it.

That brings me to the vital principle at stake in this debate-not so-called retrospectivity but tax equity. What use is any society, any democracy or any government if it cannot guarantee its citizens reasonable equity in the way they are taxed and burdened, especially one which can look with complacency at the people who are poor and less well off and say: 'No, we have to have a system where those who can afford to employ snide lawyers and accountants'-I use those words with malice aforethought-'can get away with murder and will not pay tax'? They batten on this community like leeches and it is time they understood that they are so regarded by the majority of the people of this society. Rightly so.

To me, the gross injustice of this situation is of much greater weight than attacks on the so-called retrospective nature in this legislation. To sanctify the principle of non-retrospectivity is to give a licence to those people to go on milking the community to the tune of millions, even billions, of dollars and to give that licence to anyone who wants to set up any kind of discreditable, shonky, immoral scheme to get out of paying tax. As all honourable senators know , it is a fact that these schemes first have to be identified and that seems to take an unconscionable amount of time. They have to be isolated and the facts about them have to be established. Legislation has to be got together, introduced into this place and then debated and passed. We see now how long a process that can be. It can take a year, 18 months or even longer. We know that from experience. I repeat that the people who oppose this legislation and who would like to sanctify the principle of non-retrospectivity should clearly understand-I would be very glad to hear them controvert it-that they are sanctifying a principle that creates for tax avoiders an open season on the community at large into the indefinite future. To an enormous extent it would authorise these people to keep money which should propertly have been paid as tax and so ensure that other people have to pay more tax.

How often in political affairs can one afford the luxury of the unqualified support of a single principle especially if it is in clear conflict with another principle, as it is certainly acknowledged this one is in conflict with the principle of tax equity. As an example I would say that we all respect the principle of civil liberties, yet we accept limitations to our civil liberties in that we abide by laws which are decided by parliaments to be in the common good. We would agree that it is reasonable to limit our civil liberties to the extent that we would not drive our cars on the right hand side of the road. On the other hand, we might feel it was an unjustifiable infringement of our rights if we had to report our movements to the police, in writing, once a week.

These things are matters of judgment and degree, as indeed this matter is. When we look at history, it is sickening to see that probably most of the hardship, cruelty and suffering of this world has been due directly to making one principle or another a god applicable without reference to surrounding circumstances. It was on this basis that the Spanish Inquisition burned hundreds of people at the stake. Those who carried out those acts did so in the absolute belief that it was right and just, and even in the interests of the people actually burned. There are people now who happily and with good conscience allow their children to bleed to death because of principles in which they firmly believe.

I am not canvassing either of those things; I merely make the point that there are dangers in espousing-as indeed the Liberal Party has done-opposition to this legislation simply on the grounds that it is retrospective and therefore it is bad. However, I can at least respect an honest and consistent conviction in this matter. Indeed, I respect that honest conviction by members of my party, and also from members of the Liberal Party who have held it for a long time. They have that view and I have no right to deride it. I can question it but I can at least respect it. I address these comments especially to the many members of the Liberal Party who apparently propose to vote differently from how they voted last year on this matter. Those people probably voted for the Fraser Government' s Bill for the very reasons I have outlined. By some strange process of mind all members of the conservative parties in the Senate seem to have gone through a process wherein now they will indeed make a god of the principle of retrospectivity.

TALK.START.PARA: —There isn't an election coming up.

—In fact they have had a miraculous conversion. Such is their missionary zeal that they now propose to sacrifice the Australian people at the feet of that god. I ask them to examine their consciences and perhaps think more clearly about the effect of what they might be doing. Of course, the irony is that when we look at the legislation we find it is not retrospective at all. So the ground on which these people stand is revealed as even more shaky. Every company pays company tax and then distributes some of its profits as dividends to its shareholders and they pay income tax on that sum. Companies, so they can have reasonable liquidity of operating funds, and for other reasons, are allowed by the tax laws to retain some of their profits year after year. That is what this legislation is all about. This is the money that the Government proposes to tax. The law has always said that if this money is ever shared out in the form of dividends income tax must be paid on it. It does not matter whether these accumulated funds date back three years or 30 years; it is money on which tax has not been paid and accordingly should be paid. There is nothing retrospective about asking for this tax to be paid, particularly when one takes into account the immoral if not illegal circumstances under which bottom-of-the-harbour schemes and others like it were carried out.

SPEECH.PARA: Two existing provisions in the Act state, firstly, that where those retained funds are distributed as dividends tax has to be paid on both major elements in them. Those major elements are, of course, accumulated profits and capital gains . Secondly, however, the Act also says that when a company is liquidated income tax is due only on the accumulated profits and not on the capital gains. I certainly believe that on the paper profits, which do not represent actual money or assets, there would be some justice in withdrawing the provisions of this legislation. I will deal with this in a little more detail later when I deal with my proposed amendment on the matter.

Meanwhile I wish to talk briefly about the question of mandate. The Hawke Labor Government was elected less than three months ago with a mandate to do certain things. One, of which it gave clear notice, was to introduce legislation of the kind we are debating now. It can be presumed then that the Government has a mandate from the Australian people for these Bills. Indeed, I am in no doubt whatsoever that the majority of the Australian people approve of them.

As I said, the proposal involves a great deal of money-more than half a billion dollars-accruing to the revenue at a time when we are as a nation very short of money and face a horrendous deficit in the next financial year. I would have thought a case could be made for the Government being given a reasonable chance to pursue its objectives. I do not necessarily say that all members of the Senate have to approve or subscribe to what it does. Surely that is the whole point of opposition. Many of us do not necessarily subscribe to the things a government does. If that means that at no time can the Government carry out its mandate this nation will collapse into a state of sheer anarchy. We will have no right of any reasonable or stable government at all. I do not think any good citizens want that. So I ask: Did the people give the Liberal Party or the Australian Democrats a mandate to go directly against the Government's mandate in this regard? I have examined my conscience on this matter and I suggest the only possible answer is that we have no such mandate.
