I am concerned at the effects of the Senate's treatment of this legislation on the Senate itself. That is a major point I would like to make to honourable senators. Over recent years, the Senate has demonstrated its usefulness to the Australian people in many ways-its committee system, which has been of enormous service to the country, its examination of legislation, and its delay of legislation of certain types. I think that difficult task has been acknowledged in the most eloquent way possible by the people to have been of value. I refer to the results of the May 1983 election in which, I think all honourable senators would agree, the Senate took a rather higher posture than certainly would have been the case 10 or 15 years ago. I believe there was considerable recognition by the Australian people of the potential values of the Senate. I believe that the Australian people require of the Senate not only wisdom and decisive action when it is needed, but also an impartiality and a viewing of matters with moderation and some restraint.

I must say that I campaigned during the last election on the general statement that I did not believe that I, as one of five Democrats senators, had any mandate to run the country. I stated that I saw my mandate as being to obstruct, if necessary, legislation which breached election promises without good reason, such as genuinely altered circumstances, and to resist extremist or unduly confrontative legislation. Beyond that, I undertook-I think rightly, perhaps wrongly, I do not know; but at least I gave the undertaking-to support whichever government was elected to carry out its program for which it had a clear mandate from the people. I regard those undertakings as election promises and I have no intention of breaking them now.

A great deal of intrigue and jockeying for position has gone on over these Bills in the last 48 hours. I want to speak briefly about that because I am a great believer in the facts being on the line in all respects. My colleague Senator Chipp and I share that view very strongly, and that is why I approve completely of his revelation in this place of attempts to pass money to the Democrats over this matter. It cuts all ways. I have been concerned about suggestions that Senator Jack Evans and I had heavied the Government over possible further amendments in this regard. I state absolutely clearly that the amendments which have been discussed in the media and which would remove the effects of these Bills on the capital gains element of the retained income due to be taxed were sponsored by me-I am sure that Senator Jack Evans can speak for himself-on the clearest possible understanding that the Government would accept them provided the Bill then had the numbers to pass the Senate. I require that to be put on the record. Indeed, the concern expressed by Senator Jack Evans and me to the Finance Minister, Mr Dawkins, at a meeting we had with him last Tuesday evening was over a proposed income tax on purely paper capital gains, book entries not actually represented by cash for assets, such as goodwill valuations, at completely unnatural levels. We believed then, and I still believe, that it is rather unjust that such illusory funds should attract tax. Accordingly, I foreshadow that, at the appropriate stage, I shall move the following amendment:

At the end of motion, add: ', but in the opinion of the Senate the Bill should be amended to remove its effect on purely paper capital gains of affected companies and to provide for an effective anomalies organisation empowered to decide whether tax assessments arising from this legislation should be withdrawn or reduced in cases of demonstrable injustice.'
I commend the Bill and the amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to follow Senator Mason because many of the things he said in his address to the Senate this afternoon need to be emphasised and underlined. I reserve my comments on his amendment but the principles he enunciated are solid ones; and I think that deserves to be acknowledged. Because of the matter of public importance brought forward earlier today concerning the Government's alleged broken promises-a matter of public importance which was devastatingly defeated-it is appropriate that I commence my address by reasserting the mandate that the Government has for this legislation. I think that mandate is clear and unequovical.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year, during the disclosures on tax avoidance, the Australian Labor Party published a document entitled 'A Fairer Taxation System-ALP Policy on Tax Avoidance'. For those who are interested in the year, it was August 1982. The commitment in that document stated:
A Labor Government would:
1. Selectively introduce fully retrospective legislation against blatant tax avoidance schemes, so as to cancel their operation back to the time of first known use.

That was in August last year-well before the election. In our policy speech leading up to the election the then Leader of the Opposition, now the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in the address at the Sydney Opera House, when speaking of tax relief and tax reforms, used these words:

The present economic crisis cannot be separated from the operation of the tax system under the Fraser Government. As a foremost expert on taxation and Australian public finances, Professor Russell Mathews has pointed out, the system has become a major instrument for redistributing income from wages and salaries to other incomes, a major cause of budgetary problems, and a source of growing social business and economic instability.
Later in that speech he said that he would commit an incoming Labor government to:
. . . end the loss of untold millions of dollars through the tax evasion and avoidance industry.
He said:
We will wipe out the tax evasion and avoidance industry in this country.
Under the Fraser Government it has become Australia's main growth industry.
He then went on to quote from the Costigan report. I think that excerpt should be put on the Hansard record this afternoon. It reads:

This industry has developed in Australia, particularly over the last five years , at a rate far in excess of any other industry and has brought with it profits comparable only to the heady days of the Victorian gold rush.
Mr Hawke also said:
And the blame lies not so much with individuals, but with the Government that allowed it to happen . . .
The important point there is that, if governments allow this to happen, they cannot attack individuals; they are guilty of assisting massive tax avoidance and fraud.

Lest anyone challenge the mandate, this Government has not been lacking in principles or courage. The Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins), when talking to the assembled business and union community of Australia at the National Economic Summit Conference, said:

In reforming the tax system the Government's approach will essentially be guided by its determination to restore equity to the system and redress the tax burden by applying the principle of ability to pay. In this context there can be no doubting our determination to stamp out tax avoidance and tax evasion.

He went on to talk about the legislation that he would introduce. Many of the speakers at the National Economic Summit referred in their addresses to tax avoidance and evasion. So it was not surprising that item 29 of its communique, representing the views of the assembled State governments, the national Government, major employer organisations, trade unions and welfare organisations , concurred on this principle:

All parties believe that there is a special obligation in the current environment to ensure that artificial tax avoidance and tax evasion is removed, including in the cash economy, and for the further development of a general understanding to this effect.

I have taken time to quote exhaustively in order to establish clearly that well before the election the Labor Party had trumpeted its concern and its intention. In the policy speech which opened the election campaign we made a direct promise . After being returned to government we announced at the Summit, and had endorsed by the Summit, our move in this area. The conclusion is undeniably that a mandate exists for this Government to introduce this legislation. It is not merely a narrow political mandate; it is a mandate which has been endorsed by the National Economic Summit, the greatest gathering of the economic community in modern times. I think the question of a mandate, our right to proceed, cannot be challenged.

However, these Bills go to the matter of unpaid bottom-of-the-harbour taxes. If we want to gauge the amount of tax avoidance that goes on and to try to put in perspective what these Bills are trying to do, we ought to look not so much at what politicians have said but at what a number of key figures in the Australian community have said. In the pubication I referred to earlier, the President of the Australian Society of Accountants, Mr John Miller, is quoted as saying the following words:

The present position in Australia, where employed Australians are paying an increasing share of the tax revenue and the 'tax privileged' less, cannot be tolerated. Inflation, the present steps in the individual tax scale, and the flagrant breaches of desired objectives by permission of the present legislation and other practices, make tax justice a myth in contemporary Australia. The shrewd and well-advised build up wealth on a tax-deductible basis-and the rest pay their P.A.Y.E. taxes at increased rates!
Of course, Mr Miller's is not a lone voice. We are familiar-it has been quoted many times in this forum-with the statement of Professor Russell Mathews who, in 1980, said:
. . . tax authorities, governments and the Courts have allowed tax avoidance to flourish on such a scale as to make personal income tax a voluntary tax for the rich non-salary earner.

We know as well that Eric Risstrom, of the Australian Taxpayers Association, has estimated that $7 billion has been lost to the economy by virtue of tax avoidance schemes, an amount which, when computed on a per head basis, comes down to $30 a week extra for the average Australian household to subsidise the tax cheating that goes on. The dimensions of the problem are undeniable. When confronted with such overt practices as bottom-of-the-harbour schemes-the most notorious tax avoidance instrument to come forward-no government can deal too softly or lightly with that matter or can risk any accusation that it is not strongly concerned about tax avoidance and evasion. No government, of whatever political stripe, can be seen to tolerate tax evasion.

I think it is significant and important that this Bill incorporate the element of retrospectivity, because the greatest device that will prevent tax avoidance schemes-of whatever type-flourishing in the community in the future will be the sure knowledge by all those who might choose or wish to engage in tax avoidance that when their little tricks are discovered a government acting in the community interest will legislate retrospectively to ensure that proper taxation is recovered. If that fact is known, if it is understood that a government is prepared to act retrospectively, there is no profit in encouraging avoidance schemes. On that basis, since the election, the Australian Labor Party has committed itself, should further schemes be uncovered in the future, to legislate retrospectively and, in the case of the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, to go back and legislate in that area as well. That is an essential element in dealing with the whole question of tax avoidance, because once it is known and understood that that is the firm intention of the Government, there will be no profit in the industry of tax avoidance.

I turn to the other matter that I think underpins the whole debate; that of equity. At the National Economic Summit and since, we have heard much rhetoric and argument about the need for sacrifices to be made in the community to ensure that the economy re-emerges and becomes healthy again. In this place and in others we have had a general call for wage restraint. We have all the strong argument from the Opposition that real wages should fall. We have had a number of propositions devoted to reducing the take-home wages of ordinary wage and salary earners. All of those suggestions are made on the basis that sacrifices should be borne by wage and salary earners. But in terms of pursuing economic recovery, national reconciliation and reconstruction it needs to be clearly perceived by those who are asked to bear the brunt of the sacrifice that that sacrifice is across the board; it is not something that merely applies to them. It is not something that merely applies to those who happen to earn income in the form of wages and salaries every month or week.

At the National Economic Summit this point was made quite clear by unions who committed themselves to a program of wage restraint on the understanding that there would be equity across the board. Speakers such as Cliff Dolan, Bill Kelty and Charles Fitzgibbon constantly referred to the need for governments to be clear in stamping out tax avoidance and ensuring that while workers are being asked to sacrifice wages and salaries in real terms tax cheats do not escape scot-free and to the principle of, 'whatever I can get away with I will get away with', which is enshrined in the community. If the business community sets the example, 'we can sponge, we can cheat and we can divert', it sets an example to wage and salary earners to try to do the same. In attempting to create growth through restraint we are setting an example.

If the Senate is concerned to assist the plans of recovery it will be concerned to make sure that no allegation can be levelled that tax cheats are allowed to flourish and that tax avoidance is something that we tolerate. The union movement made that position clear to the Fraser Government last year and, indeed made it clear in August last year when it indicated it was prepared to recommend to its membership that higher levels of pay-as-you-earn taxes should be paid on the understanding that tax avoidance would be wiped out and that equity would be introduced in the Government's taxing arrangements, so that a jobs fund could be formed by the extra tax revenue gathered to create fuller employment and to mount job creation schemes. That seems to me to be quite a clear indication of a commitment by the union movement to try to assist recovery through restraint. We must match that as a Government. I believe that the business community must match it as a community in order to see that no finger can be wagged as to the absence of equity or the allegation which is made that our principle is, 'Don't do as we do, do as we say'.

Naturally enough, it is not only the union movement that raised the matter. As I said in a more recent debate this week on the May economic statement, the spokesman who took the mantle of speaking on behalf of the unemployed was Bruce McKenzie of the Australian Council of Social Service. He had a lot to say at the National Economic Summit on the basis of what needs to be done to our taxing arrangements in order that the welfare dollar be stretched more to aid those who are in worse circumstances than those of us who have jobs, or those of us who are not welfare beneficiaries. To pick up his position, he said:

At present the highest income groups can evade or avoid their tax responsibilities, while the stringent income test on the poor, means that an unemployed person with a part-time job can lose a dollar for every dollar earned . This is, effectively, a 100 per cent marginal tax rate.

The clear imposition is that while the Government is imposing those stringencies it should also be careful to ensure that tax avoidance is stamped out so that those stringencies are perceived to be across the board and those who are in the worst situation in the economy are not left to foot the bill.

The other point that I think ought to be made in this debate is that the Australian system of taxation heavily favours the gathering of tax through pay- as-you-earn income tax arrangements. We gather most of our tax dollar from that area. That situation has not remained static. From 1975-76 to 1980-81 total tax collections from wage and salary earners increased by 110 per cent while total wages and salaries grew by only 72 per cent. On the other hand, tax collections for non-PAYE taxpayers-those with business, property and dividend incomes-grew by less than 56 per cent over the same period, while their incomes rose by 94 per cent. Consequently, the share of the total personal income tax paid by wage and salary earners has considerably increased. In 1981-82 it was 82 per cent compared to 76 per cent in 1975-76. Not only do we gather a significant component of our taxes from pay-as-you-earn income tax but also the level of what we gather has been increasing. The number of companies targeted for this legislation was first thought to be around 5,600. The figure is now estimated more accurately at around 5,900. Those 5,900 companies that have avoided or evaded their taxes through bottom-of-the-harbour schemes have imposed a higher cost of about $30 a week on Australian families. The point is where does this end? Legislation such as this needs to be introduced in order to bring an end to this growing and burgeoning industry which is the biggest bonanza since the gold rush.

Two major matters have been raised in opposition to this legislation. The first major question is that it is unfair to apply tax retrospectively now that events are in the past, particularly in view of the fact that the Fraser Government's tax laws went through last year. Given that we are talking about only approximately 6,000 companies, the argument about it being unfair to go back seems to be an argument about the alleged or fictional rights of those 6,000 companies. I want to ask this question: What about the rights of the 54,920 other private taxable companies? According to page 9 of the 1982-83 Budget Paper No. 11 there are 60,920 private taxable companies. If 6,000 bottom-of-the- harbour companies are deducted, the rights of 54,920 companies have to be considered. Those companies have properly met their tax obligations. If it were a question of conflict, the rights of those who have done the proper thing must always be predominant. The other thing, of course, is that if the Government is not stern and effective in this area it will invite the attitude that, because of laxity, anything goes. In terms of it being unfair to apply this legislation retrospectively, if we did not go back there would be an open invitation for anyone to engage in whatever scheme they wanted to engage in. That may well encourage a resurgence of the tax evasion industry.

Some argue that the people concerned did not know what was happening. But, of course, as Senator Mason so adequately pointed out, it is beyond belief that most did not know what was happening and that most thought, for some reason or another, they were engaged in something that was shady and cavalier in terms of their tax obligation. But for those who say they did not know and that they were honestly making an error, in looking at their cases one finds, predictably, that they are small companies or that they are companies which have delegated their affairs to an agent and allowed their agent to make decisions on their behalf. If company affairs are delegated then one is bound by what the agents or representatives do. If the companies personally did not know, they were lax in their obligations to their own affairs in not discovering what the agent was doing on their behalf. Of course, even if they argue that they did not know, they were happy to pick up whatever windfall came their way because of the activities of that agent. If, suddenly, one of us found $50,000 thrust into our letterbox and we thought we could get away with it, but discovered later that the Government was taking it, we ought not complain. If we have a windfall or an advantage we should not complain when the Government takes its share. Many honourable senators opposite will have asserted constantly the old Milton Friedman saying that there is no such thing as a free lunch. If people benefit by getting an advantage they cannot claim that they were entitled to a free lunch when the rest of the community has met its obligation.

It has been said that retrospectivity is unfair. This comes down to whether adequate notice has been given and time to pay is allowed. Amending provisions to this effect have been incorporated in the Bill as read a third time in the House of Representatives.

The final major argument put is that there will be massive unemployment if this legislation goes through. I assert that many of the figures that have been put out about future job loss because of this legislation are nothing short of scare tactics designed to try to talk up a storm of protest. They are not factual and vary according to whom you speak. What must be remembered is that these Bills impose a tax not on companies but on the owners of companies. Those owners or shareholders will be called upon to pay the taxes now. They have ways and means of raising money if they cannot meet that bill which will not involve that company, if it is viable and effective, going out of business. So to pretend that owners faced with a tax bill will somehow or other seek not to maximise their position as owners but sell their company, or trade or do something else in order to meet that tax bill, and that that will create unemployment is mischievous.

In conclusion, if we consider the amount of money being forgone by the Department of the Treasury due to tax avoidance and consider what is needed to generate jobs in this economy, it is quite clear that there would be massive re- employment if we were able to recover revenue that was lost to the Budget through tax avoidance. There could be massive re-employment. Those who argue that they are entitled to take the advantages of their shady dealings and get away with it have to answer this question: Why should they, in all equity, be allowed to do that when those funds not recovered could help the economy resurge through a job creation program? I commend the Bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that two principles should govern the consideration of honourable senators in coming to a conclusion on whether or not this legislation is proper. Those two principles are certainty before the law and fair taxation shares. Honourable senators know that last year I supported the recoupment legislation. I did so in an attempt to apply those principles to that legislation. Let me deal first of all with what occured last year. Last year the former Government brought in legislation-it was eventually passed by the Parliament-which sought to recoup from vendor shareholders a taxation benefit which those vendor shareholders had derived from contrived arrangements in respect of their companies. Many of those shareholders, in fact most of those shareholders, were innocent. In fact, they were arms-length transactions.

SPEECH.PARA: The tax avoided by those schemes was company tax and Division 7 tax on current year profits which had an accumulating liability. Clearly there was an accumulating liability. That was avoided by arrangements entered into. It was the purpose of last year's legislation to recoup that even from the majority of innocent vendor-shareholders who had, on the best advice available, entered into those arrangements. I say 'arm's length' because Senator Cook referred to shady dealers. We are not dealing with shady dealers; we are dealing with innocent vendor-shareholders. If we are talking about arm's length transactions by definition of the High Court of Australia in, for example, the Slutzkin case, they are innocent. Yet last year I was prepared to vote for a proposition which would recoup an accumulating liability in respect of current year profits. By what application? It was by the application of two principles-the principle of certainty before the law and fair shares.

Honourable senators might say that I have failed. I know that a number of people who voted against the legislation last year might accuse me of failing in my test of application of certainty before the law. A legal act should not subsequently be clothed with illegality and consequent penalties. Let me remind the Senate that, as the Senate and the Government knew, there was the legal opinion of Brinsden Q.C. of 1974 which was that criminal or civil proceedings could be taken against purchasers who had stripped companies and thus left them in a position of not being able to pay their tax. This legislation does nothing against those promoters. It does nothing to attack the real problems. It does nothing to catch the real shady dealers. It does nothing to catch those purchasers who sent many of the companies to the bottom of the harbour. Let us get that clear. I believe that many of the speeches that have been made show that people do not have the matter clear. I believe that many members of the public do not have the matter clear because of the ill-informed attention that the matter has been given by the media by and large, with a few exceptions.

I applied my mind to the next test; that is, of fair shares in taxation. I believe that on an application of that principle, if there were an accumulating liability and by virtue of an arrangement entered into for the sale of a particular company the vendor-shareholders had avoided paying that liability, in all fairness they ought to pay tax equivalent to company tax and Division 7 tax that was accumulating. I voted for that proposition. I know it has caused a great deal of embarrassment to innocent vendor-shareholders and I believe it has also caused a great deal of dislocation. Nevertheless, on the basis of fair shares, I believed at the time that that was how I should vote and I voted accordingly.

However we now have in this legislation an attempt to impose retrospectively a further tax on those innocent vendor-shareholders in respect of a matter for which there was no accruing tax liability and in respect of some matters on which tax would never have been paid from here to the end of the world. I believe that this legislation is qualitatively different in principle from the legislation which was before us and which the Parliament adopted last year. The Government knows that because it is prepared to accept an amendment which takes out of the scope of the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill accumulated capital reserves.

Prior to the Government's willingness-I believe it was a contrived willingness- to exclude capital profits from this Bill, the Government had predicated the Bill on an assumption that there had been a distribution of tax. The logic of the situation now-if the Government agrees, as it has, to the exclusion of capital profits from the scope of this legislation-is that it predicates the Bill on the assumption that there has been a liquidation. It is quite clear. As every honourable senator should know, had there been a liquidation of any of these companies there would have been no tax liability on the part of the vendor -shareholders to the revenue in respect of their accumulated capital reserves.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the revenue reserves.

—Leave the revenue reserves aside for a minute. The vendor- shareholders know that; the Government knows that. Therefore this Bill is a charade. Let everybody understand that the Government says that it is collecting taxes which it has lost. It did not lose them because they would never have been payable. That is the logic of the situation. Taking that to its logical conclusion in respect of the revenue reserves, why does the Government, now it assumes that there has been a liquidation, not treat the revenue reserves in precisely the same way as liquidation in the real corporate world? Everybody knows that when companies are liquidated their revenue reserves are not realised in one year in respect of the imposition of taxes. They are, of course, distributed over a period of years. The logic of the Government's situation now, if it says that those reserves should go back into the tax barrel, is that it should tax them over the years that they were likely to have been taxed and in the same way as they would have been taxed had there been a liquidation.

SPEECH.PARA: I speak not on my behalf but, I believe, on behalf of a large number of workers in this community and a very large number of Australian Labor Party back benchers and Labor Party members. From what I have heard of the debate thus far from the Government side, with the exception of one or two speakers, there is a total misunderstanding of what this legislation is likely to do. In order to enlighten people a little I want to read from a letter that has been sent to me by a person who has been a member of the Labor Party all his voting life who also happens to be a lecturer in taxation law at the Footscray Institute of Technology. He would, therefore, surely be in a position to know what he is talking about. I am prepared to table the letter that was sent to me by Mr Tim Margetts, together with the letter that he had sent to Mr Clyde Holding with a request that it be brought to the attention of Messrs Keating and Dawkins. The letter to Mr Clyde Holding states:
Dear Clyde,
re: Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill 1983

Further to our recent discussion on Sunday, 29th May, at the F.E.A. election for Melbourne Ports, I am writing to you to clarify my objections against the proposed amendments to the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Act 1982, and would be pleased if you could ensure that these are brought to the personal attention of both Messrs. Keating and Dawkins as a concerned member of the A.L.P .
As explained to you on Sunday, I currently lecture in taxation law at Footscray Institute of Technology and therefore believe I am not speaking from a completely uninformed position.

From my understanding, the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Act 1982 causes a primary tax liability to fall onto the vendor shareholders of the '' target company'' under a situation where there has been a current year profit earned by the target company (therefore a contingent company tax liability). However, due to the asset stripping of this company by a promoter, the company would have no assets to pay the tax bill or instead would be sent to the '' bottom of the harbour''. Consequently, the company tax and/or undistributed profits tax would remain unpaid.

It is commonly accepted and applauded, especially by myself, that retrospective legislation should be introduced to recover such lost revenue. The justification for this retrospective legislation is abundantly clear, as the net result of this artificial scheme and many other similar schemes are to ''increase the load of tax on the great body of good citizens who do not desire or do not know how to adopt these manoeuvres''. Although the vendor shareholders commonly acted upon the advice of so-called ''legal and accounting'' experts, it was these people who made a tax saving less the substantial fees they were charged.

For the record, I believe the Government should not hesitate in using retrospective legislation to counter any further discovered ''artificial and continued schemes''. However, I feel that the Labor Party must, through State Conference, adopt the same as a policy and accordingly let the deterrent effect of such a stated policy be established.

This brings me back to the current proposed amendments which, of course, intends to go a lot further than the legislation last year. From my reading of the Bill and explanatory memorandum, it would seem that the Government intends now to impose a further recoupment tax on the vendor shareholders of these companies. This penal tax will operate on the assumption that as the companies now cease to exist, it will be assumed that their total assets should be treated as distributions back to the shareholders and then taxed as dividends in their hands.

This assumption and consequently the operation of the Bill is in complete contradiction to our present system of taxation of companies and ignores all the tax laws concerning distributions on liquidation of the company itself.
Of course it does-
As a result of such fundamental misconceptions-
He is talking about the Government-

it ignores the reality that undistributed profits over past years and the current year may have both an income and capital character. So as the Bill imposes a tax on 'total assets' of the company, it might therefore also tax capital profits of the company. I need not remind you that our party policy is against a capital gains tax, although I personally believe this may need reassessment in the future.

Yet it is for this reason that I now must strongly object to the proposed amendments as it can be argued the Bill will retrospectively tax receipts that would not have been income under the normal concepts of the Income Tax Assessment Act. The Bill will have a strong penal effect and to impose retrospective laws of this kind is both unjust and immoral. In this respect I quote what Senator Gareth Evans was reputed to say on 1 November last year; 'the Labor Party would confine retrospective legislation, recoupment legislation against tax avoidance to schemes which are blatant . . . our legislation would not be penal in character, but simply seek to recover-like the Government's ' bottom of the harbour' legislation-the tax which was avoided.' (Law Institute Journal, Vol. 57, No. 3, p. 192)

For the purpose of completeness, I wish to point out a further remark made by Senator Evans in April this year; 'it is our intention . . . to remove loopholes created by S.3 (12) (in the Act) . . . Beyond that, we have no intention of proceeding on retrospective recoupment legislation in relation to any of the schemes which are already the subject of remedial action or legislation by the present Government.' (Law Institute Journal, Vol. 57, No. 4, p. 254)

As a member of the Labor Party for nearly all my voting life and with a strong belief in the principals and ideals of the ALP, I find it very difficult to understand how the Government can justify such discriminatory legislation which will tax one group of the community differently from the rest. I hope that this is not so because of a belief that generally these people can afford to make such payments. In my opinion, the proposed laws are discriminatory and I firmly believe many other members of the ALP would be against such legislation if they recognised its discriminatory effect. It is for this reason that I hope that the Government will reassess the position of the proposed legislation and correct the blatant inconsistencies it presents.
I hope that my expectations of a Government that I worked hard to obtain are not so quickly disappointed and look forward to an early reply.

I feel that that raises the matter of a mandate. It has been suggested that because the Government has a mandate it can do what it likes. I do not think that just because a person has a mandate he can do what he likes. What is the Parliament for, if that is the case? We might as well be under a dictatorship. The previous speaker, Senator Cook, referred to the National Economic Summit Conference. He argued that the Government had a mandate because of what was said in the Summit communique.

TALK.START.PARA: —I pointed to the policy speech first, Senator.
—Oh, good-I will come to the policy speech in a minute.
—And to the previous year's statement on taxation by the party.
—I will come to that.
—That is where the mandate comes from.

—I will come to that. But Senator Cook said that the Summit, as the highest body in the land-whatever that means-had given the Government this mandate. However, this is what was said in the Summit communique:

SPEECH.PARA: All parties believe there is a special obligation in the current environment to ensure that artificial tax avoidance and tax evasion is removed, including in the cash economy, and for further development of a general understanding to this effect.
The Summit agrees that action should be taken to improve the equity and efficiency of the Australian taxation system.
I suppose we all agree with that.

Last year Senator Walsh moved an amendment to the second reading motion of the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill 1982. Time is on the wing, so let me very quickly read part of his amendment. At that time I sought to remove paragraphs (b), (c) and (d) of this amendment because I did not think that they quite fell within the principles that should have been applied to that legislation. Senator Walsh's amendment to the then Government's legislation states:
At the end of motion, add ', but the Senate-
(b) is of the opinion that the Bill is grossly inadequate in that:

(i) it deals only with company and undistributed profits tax remaining unpaid on current and prior year profits and does not recoup personal income tax lost in relation to accumulated after-tax profits disposed of by vendor shareholders in the same transactions,

Let the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) who represents the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) tell the Senate where personal income tax has been lost. The legislation now is predicated on an assumption that there was a liquidation. When I say 'now' I mean after the Government agrees to its contrived policy. Let me say why it is contrived. I do not like doing these sorts of things. The discussions I have with Ministers and the like always remain confidential. I was appalled yesterday when I had discussed a particular matter with the Minister to go back to my office and, after about an hour of discussions with an official, to be confronted by the news media reporting that in the morning members of the Australian Labor Party got together and said: 'Get Harradine to move this amendment to whack out the capital tax side of it'. I do not appreciate that sort of reflection on me. The Labor Party knew the logic of the situation. It could not sustain a piece of legislation which would tax revenue which, in most normal circumstances, would never be taxed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you conceding that there are circumstances in which it would have been taxed?

—I have made it perfectly clear that there are ways and means of putting revenue reserves back in the tax barrel if that is what the Government wants to do and to have them taxed in a particular way. For example, revenue reserves may have been reinvested in a new corporate entity carrying on the same business by way of loans or share capital. In those circumstances, the revenue reserves would not be subject to taxation, but why not have a roll-over effect and deem those revenues to be accumulated reserves for the purpose of taxation in the new company? That is the logic of the situation now. That is the sort of thing the Government ought to be looking at if it is to adopt that sort of argument because that is logical.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very difficult to deal with this matter adequately in half an hour but I will refer very briefly to a couple of matters. I would like to read one particular letter for the benefit of Labor Party senators but I do not have the time. Honourable senators are welcome to see it afterwards. It concerns a very old-time Labor personality from this Parliament who is not a shady character at all; he is well respected and well revered.

TALK.START.PARA: —From South Australia?

—No, from New South Wales. His family will be absolutely destitute as a result of this legislation. The consequences of this legislation must be examined. I appeal to the Government to consider giving us an opportunity to examine the legislation. I have received plenty of representations, but I have so structured those representations as to ensure, by and large, that I see nobody and get them in writing. I have a stack. I am sure that on the basis of confidentiality the people concerned would welcome the opportunity to have those representations examined rigorously to see whether what they portend will occur. What the written documentation that I have and the advice that I have been given portend is that, this legislation will affect the employment of 26,000 people.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been a trade union official all my life. I have heard employers scream when they get a log of claims; they scream blue murder. But we know they are not fair dinkum. I know they are very fair dinkum in regard to this legislation. I will not be put in a situation where I have the responsibility and the opprobrium of having to vote for this legislation so that when the first couple of thousand workers go off those workers and their unions blame me. There is a way around it. There is a way to put some of the revenue back into the barrel. But we will not get it this way. Honourable senators have the opportunity to support Senator Macklin's motion to send the legislation to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. The Committee is chaired by a Government supporter, and the Government has the numbers. Why do honourable senators not agree to send this legislation to the Committee for it to examine the consequences? I believe that it is the responsibility of the Government to do so.

I can understand the responsibility of the Minister for Finance-his responsibility is to tax everything that does not move and to get in the money. That is his responsibility and I respect it. The Government has a responsibility and that means that each and every Government honourable senator has a responsibility to consider the consequences of this legislation. The effect on Australian employment at this stage will be disastrous. I challenge the Minister to declare that there will be no substantial dislocation in employment and investment potential as a result of this legislation and as a result of the way the Government is going about it. My time has expired and I regret that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am motivated to speak in this debate, having heard the last speaker, Senator Harradine, and the explanations, justifications and rationalisations for the rejection of this legislation. Unfortunately, I do not think that the previous speaker has seen the legislation in its true perspective. Whilst I respect his point of view-I have had the good fortune to discuss many of the ramifications of the legislation with him over the last couple of days and with many other honourable senators, including the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins), and my Senate colleagues, the Australian Democrats-I think that it may help before the debate is wound up if we have a look at the overall effect of this legislation if it is passed.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing we need to recognise is the immediate burden that will be placed on some businesses, the immediate effect on the economy at large in some fields and the potential that there will be for bankruptcies, unemployment and uncertainty in the community. One of the effects will be that it will mean the end of tax avoidance. If this legislation is rejected, we give the tax avoiders a new lease of life. Another effect, obviously, is that it will add $570m to government revenue. But that has to be done legitimately. I respect the views of those who believe that we should not take the fast buck, even in government terms, to achieve that $570m gain.

Let us look at the motivation of the Government in putting this legislation forward. Is it genuine concern about tax avoidance? Is it a genuine attempt at redistribution of wealth? Many people from Western Australia have asked me: 'Is this a personal vendetta? Or is it a means of assisting economic recovery?' It may well be a mixture of all those motives.

I would just like to go over the attitudes of people with whom I have spoken who are caught up in these new tax provisions. I think it is fair to say that nearly all of them now accept the obligation to pay under the 1982 legislation. I think it is also fair to say that they were just as vociferous and as opposed to that legislation as they are to this. In fact, in my State they have appealed as strongly-certainly, even more loudly- as a result of a very co-ordinated and heavily financed campaign. It is also appropriate to tell the Senate that they now regard bottom-of-the-harbour legislation against wet Slutzkins as being generally acceptable. That was not their attitude in 1982. However, they feel that dry Slutzkins, which they maintain were approved by the High Court of Australia, should not be included in retrospective tax measures. That, of course , is the major effect of this legislation.

Other attitudes include one of uncertainty: 'Where do we go from here? What is likely to happen in the future, not just as a result of this legislation but also as a result of the Pandora's box that it may open?'. They want a right to explain, a right to appeal, to an independent body. If the legislation is approved they want time to pay. Even if they are found to be guilty they want the right to be able to make that payment over a period without penalty, to allow their businesses to continue. They are upset at the selective application of a capital gains tax, which this Government does not have the courage to introduce on a broad basis for everybody in the community. They are concerned-I remind honourable senators that I am talking about the people who are caught up in these new provisions-at the taxing of paper profits which, regardless of whether a company had continued or was liquidated, would not have warranted any tax.

Having heard all those points of view, all those submissions and from all of those people, some genuine, some obviously con men and their representatives, I have had to give a lot of consideration to my attitude. I am concerned at the potential damaging of innocent parties-sometimes shareholders, and potentially employees or creditors-if companies are suddenly liquidated and the flow-on effect in the form of bankruptcies and unemployment right throughout the economy . Other considerations against the legislation included the thought that some guilty parties may get off scot-free and be able to reinvest their proceeds or transfer their funds and themselves overseas. We might be well rid of them. Of course, the promoters and the advisers get off scot-free in any case.

In considering why I should be against this legislation I am also concerned because there were some genuine sales of companies, at time of retirement of the owners, rather than the liquidation of those companies. The proceeds amounted often to genuine, non-taxable, capital appreciation; for instance, when the revaluation of farming properties occurred. In many instances the proceeds appear to me to have represented only paper gains. Frequently, it seems, all that happened was that there was a re-arrangement of affairs simply to help a changing family situation. I guess one might say, in summary that for me the considerations against this legislation include the fact that it seems to be a sneaky, selective application of a capital gains tax which applies to tax legislation the principle of retrospectivity, which so many of us are against.

Therein lies the problem. There is the principle of retrospectivity as against the principle of robbing one's fellow Australians. When those two principles come into conflict one has to consider the other side of this question. I believe that there are justifiable reasons for this legislation, which I will summarise. Firstly, in some cases taxes were due and payable. Secondly, it is a blatant, evasion-style tax avoidance scheme which is blatant and is accepted by the whole community as immoral. It increases the burden on dinkum Australians and has done so for years. Are we to let these people get away with the money and run?

In my opinion, this legislation, if passed, will stamp out tax avoidance for all time. We will never see another piece of retrospective tax legislation. I believe that this Government should muster its courage and announce immediately that it will introduce a tax on large capital gains. That would embrace most of the people in this group. When that happens it might become more justifiable to say: 'Right, let us have a look at this group'. But, again, to apply that retrospectively cuts across a principle about which a lot of people are concerned.

I think we need to recognise also-this has been said many times-that this Government warned the voters, who elected them to govern. If this legislation is lost $500m-plus will be lost to the economy. The alternatives that the Government will obviously have to consider will include increased taxes on other people; increases in company tax, personal tax and sales tax. I say: Watch out for the whammy, Senator Harradine, and other honourable senators who wish to oppose this legislation. It is they who will be responsible for the new, increased taxes. Honourable senators should not blame Senator Colin Mason and Senator Jack Evans for that bludgeon, which will hit all of us. Honourable senators should look at the potential that then creates for increasing the Budget deficit, if the Government does not increase taxes that, in turn, would increase interest rates. Those who have been so concerned about people losing their houses because of increased interest rates will suddenly find that interest rates will indeed increase. A $500m increase in the Budget deficit will occur tomorrow morning if this legislation is lost.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about bankruptcies?

—We should look also at the Government's potential to do what it wants to do to help those who are on welfare. That potential will be diminished dramatically. I put it to Senator Crichton-Browne, who has just interjected, and to others who are living very comfortably on this land that the potential for job creation programs is diminished overnight. Whose need is greatest-that of the tax avoiders, who would not be in these tax avoidance schemes if they did not have hundreds of thousands of dollars to gain thereby? Nobody who stood to gain less than that got into this system. Whose need is greatest-the need of those people, or the need of people on welfare, people who are unemployed, people who will suffer as a result of this legislation being blocked? We should face the fact that 90 per cent of the bottom-of-the-harbour cases which blatantly avoided tax and still benefit from the proceeds thereof will be able to continue their beautiful, luxuriant lives, write their letters from Vaucluse and live in the Lakeside International Hotel in the lap of luxury while the rest of the community suffers as a result of the blocking of this legislation. It is not as simple as Senator Crichton-Browne would have us believe. It is simple in his view because he has a number of friends in Western Australia who have made their millions and are frightened about losing them as a result of this legislation.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Jack Evans has not been in this Senate very long so he probably does not know what standing orders are. But he does know the meaning of the word 'decency' and he was implying that the making of my decision on the legislation was simple because I have friends involved in tax avoidance. That is a reflection on me and I ask that he withdraw it.
—Mr Deputy President, I wish to speak to the point of order.
—Order! I need no further assistance with the point of order, Senator Mason. Senator Jack Evans has just made an unwarranted reflection on Senator Crichton-Browne. He should withdraw it.

—I withdraw the reflection on Senator Crichton-Browne. I simply point to the fact that a number of people in Western Australia who have been guilty of sinking their companies to the bottom of the harbour are very influential members of the Liberal Party in that State even if they are not friends of Senator Crichton-Browne.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it might be appropriate for us to look again at the effects of the proposed changes that, in my understanding, have been agreed to by the Minister as a result of representations made by Senator Mason and me. We have asked for a right to appeal for relief for those who would suffer personal hardship as a result of this legislation and I believe that inherent in that appeal should be the right for those who will suffer from flow-on hardship-that is, where business would be liquidated and where employees would be affected. We have been assured by the Minister and the Commissioner of Taxation-I have that assurance in writing-that not only will those rights of appeal be granted but also that they will be heard quickly and that there will not be delays which could cause undue hardship and cause people to be very concerned as to whether their appeal would be heard and upheld. We have asked further for the Minister to provide in the legislation for people who cannot meet their commitments immediately without causing undue hardship. We have asked that they be given 12 months extra time to meet those commitments, a provision which was not in the original legislation and in fact was being taken out of the 1982 legislation. I give credit to the Minister that he has recognised the difficulties that this will create for people and he has included these proposed amendments in the legislation.

We have asked that the pressure for instant cash as a result of this legislation be alleviated, that people be given the opportunity to rearrange their affairs and that they be given the right to be heard by an independent relief board. We have gone further than that today, but so far we have had total acquiescence from the Minister in those requests. We have asked also for support and, whilst this has not been guaranteed, I believe that we have had a more than sympathetic hearing from the Minister for a proposal that the capital gains sector of this legislation be withdrawn and that the tax on the capital gain proportion is no longer to apply to this legislation. I believe that if that amendment is passed in the Committee stage of the debate, it would completely remove the justification that many people have for opposing this Bill. Having heard the debate on this Bill, it would be recognised that more than half the debate, and I am talking about the real debate as distinct from the emotional debate, has been directed against the fact that the Government has selectively proposed legislation which would apply a capital gains tax to only one sector of the community. Many people agree with Senator Mason and me that that is unjust and that, if the Government wanted to introduce a capital gains tax, it should do so openly and non-selectively to the whole community. By all means it should set limits to the tax. We would certainly not support any legislation that imposed a capital gains tax on the sale of people's homes or on capital appreciation lower than, say, $200,000 and elements of that nature. But there is a belief right through the Senate that there is something wrong with a tax which is introduced under the guise of picking up the bottom-of-the-harbour escapees and hitting them with a tax which has never applied and could never have applied , whatever they did with their companies in the past, the present or the future. One cannot say that that provision can be applied to the rest of the Bill but I think the criterion I have just enunciated is applicable to capital gains and therefore is not acceptable to Senator Mason or me. I hope to have the opportunity to move that amendment in the Committee stage of the debate. I hope that honourable senators will give us the chance to move our amendments and give us all the opportunity to have another look at the legislation and its effects if that part of the legislation is removed.

I think I should conclude by explaining the effects of the amendment of which Senator Mason gave notice. It would provide a right of appeal to an independent body, an anomalies organisation, to all those who believe that they have been unjustly caught in this net. Frankly, that leaves my conscience absolutely clear and I believe it should also salve Senator Harradine's conscience because, with all the representations that we have had, I do not feel capable of making judgments on individual cases. I have not had a tax return in relation to these cases put in front of me and I will guarantee that Senator Harradine had not had one put in front of him. I have not had a 100 per cent bona fide substantiated case put before me. I have heard a number of one-sided cases, with nobody putting the alternative point of view. But I recognise that there may be an injustice about to be done if this legislation goes through. Senator Mason's amendment states:

. . . but in the opinion of the Senate the Bill should be amended to remove its effect on purely paper capital gains of affected companies and to provide for an effective anomalies organisation empowered to decide whether tax assessments arising from this legislation should be withdrawn or reduced in cases of demonstrable injustice.

If this Bill goes through its second reading stage with that amendment, there could not be an honourable senator in this chamber who could object to the legislation because it covers every objection which has been raised. It has the effect of removing the discriminatory and potentially unjust tax on capital gains when these were only nominal or fictitious paper gains from which no real benefit was or would be derived. Overall, it has the effect of reducing the hardships for those directly and indirectly affected and sorts out the rip-off merchants from those less culpable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think in view of the importance of the last vote, so to speak, it might be better if I deal with Senator Harradine's speech first. I start with this point: Senator Harradine was very concerned about innocent vendor-shareholders. Without going into the question of the degree of their innocence, all the shareholders caught by the legislation last year or this year, innocent or not, knowing or not, received the money. Last year they were subject to tax on that proportion of the evaded company and Division 7 tax which equalled their shareholding in the company. Senator Harradine supported the legislation last year. No shareholder will be liable to the taxes sought to be imposed by these Bills who was not also liable to receive a tax assessment in 1982. There could be some who received assessments in 1982, or as a result of the 1982 legislation, who will not receive assessments consequential upon this legislation. In other words, the shareholders, innocent or otherwise, who would be affected by this legislation are exclusively shareholders affected by last year's legislation, but not exhaustively. They would all be shareholders in companies involved in what has become colloquially known as a bottom-of-the-harbour disposal.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine says the Government will accept the legislation as proposed to be amended by Senator Mason and/or Senator Jack Evans. That is correct. The Government, through the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins), indicated yesterday to a number of people that we would accept the legislation with an amendment which excluded the capital profits component of the liability but only in return for a guarantee that at least three people on the other side of the chamber would vote for the third reading of the Bill. Such a guarantee was not forthcoming from three people. After the Government had agreed to accept that amendment as a means of salvaging most-though far from all-of the Bill, people sought to impose further conditions which were unacceptable to the Government. That position still stands. The Government agreed to accept an amendment, as has been proposed by Senator Jack Evans and Senator Mason, solely because it would be better to get $350m than to get nothing, which was the likely alternative. In accepting that amendment, however, we would have been highly conscious of the fact that $220m of revenue would be lost and that that revenue would have to be recovered from some other source.

Yesterday I gave some illustrative examples of the effects of recovering $200m- almost the same amount of money-from three other sources. One would involve a 7 per cent increase in present sales tax collections, which would also add one- quarter of a per cent to the consumer price index. Another would be to increase the income tax of average taxpayers by nearly $1 a week. A third one-which I think might particularly appeal to Senator Harradine-is that on the expenditure side that much money could be saved by withdrawing about one-third of the Commonwealth grant currently paid to Tasmania. They are options. The Government will not necessarily pursue any of those specific options or any mixture of them but that is the sort of position in which the Government will be placed if that area of potential is excluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are just going to throw 1,200 people out of work.

—I will come to that in a minute. Of course, if the whole Bill is defeated at the second reading-as I gather from the tenor of Senator Harradine's remarks it will be-$570m ultimately will be lost and $570m will have to be recovered from some other source. An illustrative example is that that is equal to a 20 per cent increase in sales tax collections and an increase in the consumer price index of the order of 0.7 per cent. Those are the options. That is the sort of impost which those who would defeat this Bill will throw upon the honest taxpayers and citizens of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine, in his speech, said that the Government has assumed a liquidation in the case of these companies. The Government has assumed no such thing. The rationale behind these Bills is not dependent upon an assumed liquidation. If Senator Harradine is suggesting that the right and proper thing to do in the treatment of these companies and their shareholders is to assume that a liquidation had taken place, the proper thing for him to do would be to vote for the second reading and then to vote for the amendment proposed by Senator Mason, because if the companies had been liquidated the revenue profits would have been subject to taxation in the hands of the shareholders. But the fact remains that they were not liquidated. They continued, in the great majority of cases-the overwhelming majority of, if not all, cases-in the hands of the same people who had operated them before. There was a de facto distribution as dividend to the shareholders of the company at the time they were sold to the parallel company owned by the same people.

It is on that basis that logically these Bills are founded-on the fact that there was a de facto distribution as dividend of both the capital profits and the revenue profits of the companies concerned. Of course, they were not liquidated in the conventional way, firstly, because the people in control of those companies thought they could evade every conceivable tax liability and, secondly, because they could not have arranged the fraudulent transactions involved in this area if they had gone through liquidation processes. A fraudulent round robin of cheques was authorised under which the shareholders of these companies, either directly or through agents, received by way of distribution of the funds of the target company which then were passed around the circle to buy back the target company by the parallel company owned almost entirely and almost always, if not always, by the same people. It was a fraudulent activity. For that reason it is not appropriate to regard what happened as being analogous to a company liquidation.

There have been a number of misunderstandings, misconceptions or whatever-one from Senator Harradine and some from others-regarding the way in which revenue profits would be taxed. Firstly, in a liquidation, revenue profits would be subject to taxation on distribution to the shareholder subject to personal tax. There is no provision-indeed it is an offence under section 47 of the Income Tax Assessment Act-to spread that liquidation in a discretionary way with the deliberate intention of spreading the dividend over a number of years. In the cases of large companies, and these would usually be public companies, the liquidation process entails interim payments which may or may not be spread over a period of years. But it is an offence under the existing law to contrive the liquidation process in an artificial way that spreads the dividends over a number of years. That is a rather important fact that I think should be cleaned up. Of course, applying that one exclusion or possibility in this case-that is, that the target companies were liquidated and the profit distribution spread over a period of years-it would not have been possible if the distribution had been spread over a period of years to arrange the round robin in the fraudulent way in which it was arranged. I am advised that I was not quite correct when I said that it was an offence under existing law to spread them in a discretionary way. It is simply not possible to do it. The distinction is a fine one but worth putting on the record.

The essential point to remember with this legislation is that the trigger mechanism which activates these Bills is prior involvement in bottom-of-the- harbour activity, prior involvement in what has been described-by, among others, Senator Macklin and the former Prime Minister-as fraudulent activity and what was accepted as fraudulent activity last year by all but, I think, six of the Liberal Party senators presently here. I have already explained the essential mechanism employed in the fraudulent activities from which these Bills seek to recover tax avoided. Apart from trifling amounts of money, last year's legislation, with one exception which I will deal with in a minute, recovered from the vendor- shareholders, whether or not they were conscious participants in the fraudulent activity-the company tax which had been evaded. In terms of that provision, which I supported then and which I support now, whether they were conscious participants is not relevant. The point is that they raised the money to which they had no entitlement and it was absolutely just that they should have paid back that portion of the money to which they had no entitlement .

The one exception, which was not in the legislation that was originally introduced in the House of Representatives by the previous Government, was clause 3 (12) in the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Bill 1982. Clause 3 (12) exempted from liability vendor-shareholders of companies which, after the transfer of ownership from the vendor-shareholders to the promoters, were placed into a unsuccessful tax avoidance scheme. The clause then introduced a completely capricious and arbitrary test of liability, dependent upon the actions taken by people other than the vendor-shareholders and about which, necessarily, the vendor-shareholders were supposed to have had no knowledge. Vendor-shareholders were taken in or out of jeopardy by the actions of people over whom they had no control and of which, necessarily, so it was argued, they had no knowledge. Capricious law could scarcely have gone further than that. I am pleased to note that even Senator Harradine agreed with that assessment, when last year's legislation was before the Senate, and voted for my amendment to remove that clause from last year's legislation. We failed.

Of course, the secrecy provisions of the Taxation Act, prevent Mr Dawkins, or anyone in the Government, from obtaining access to individual tax or company files. So we do not know, from taxation records, what companies benefited from the insertion of that capricious clause. We do, however, know from other sources -from the McCabe-Lafranchi report-that one major company put into a post-sale tax avoidance scheme was Treamog Ltd. It was flogged off at the end of 1976 with a then current year tax liability of $1.7m. It was owned directly and indirectly , to the extent of 70 per cent, by the then chairman of the Liberal Party finance committee, Mr Denis Horgan, who I always thought was a friend of Senator Crichton-Browne. But today, like St Peter as Christ was about to be crucified, he denied him thrice. This Bill achieves certain things-not in this descending order of monetary importances-

TALK.START.PARA: —You would not say that of Senator Crichton-Browne if he were here to defend himself.
—He just left because he knew what was coming.
—What absolute rubbish.
—He was not game to face it.
—No one would sink to the depths of your mind-
—Order! I suggest the Minister withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw, Mr President, in deference to you. I think Senator Walters ought to withdraw too. She accused me of saying it only because Senator Crichton-Browne was not here.
—I would be only too happy to withdraw the statement that Senator Crichton-Browne could not sink to the depths of the Minister's mind, so long as he has withdrawn.
—Order! The Minister has withdrawn. I ask Senator Walters to withdraw.
—Then I withdraw.

—This Bill reverses the insertion of clause 3 (12) in the Bill finally passed last year. It recovers personal taxation on dividends distributed to original company shareholders on the accumulated and capital profits and some other relatively minor but administratively convenient matters. I have already dealt with the arguments against the Bills in replying to Senator Harradine. I have stressed that this legislation will not be triggered against any shareholder who was not a shareholder in a company sunk with current year profits.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of factual errors were made in the speeches delivered by assorted members of the Opposition. I will correct some of them. Senator Crichton-Browne claimed that, under this Bill, it was possible for a company to be caught with a tax assessment of $1m even though it had a current year tax liability-that is vulnerable to last year's Bill-of only, I think this is the figure he used, $250 . That is not correct. The degree to which companies caught by last year's legislation are affected by this year's legislation is related to the fee paid to the promoter.

I give two examples. A company with accumulated profits, revenue or capital, totalling $1m and therefore a tax liability of, at most, $600,000, which paid a promoter's fee of 2 per cent or, in other words, a promoter's fee of $20,000 -I am not aware of any specific case where the promoter's fee was as low as that- would have had to have more than $20,000 of current year profits before it became liable to the provisions of this legislation. If the 5 per cent promoter' s fee was used-that seems to have been the common fee-the same company could not have been caught or affected by this legislation unless it had current year profits of $60,000, as against a tax liability, in the hypothetical example Senator Crichton-Browne gave, of $600,000 on accumulated profits. Whether Senator Crichton-Browne deliberately misled the Senate in that instance or whether he was snowed by tax dodgers or influenced by organisations such as Arena Distributors or Hal Wallace or whatever, is a question about which I will not speculate at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh, you're at your best when you're in the gutter. Why don't you stay there?
—One of these days I might go down to the sewer and I will find the honourable senator there.
—Order! I ask the Minister to withdraw.
—I withdraw, Mr President.

SPEECH.PARA: The second factual error which was implicitly attributed to Senator Harradine in today's Australian Financial Review-and, I think, is confirmed by the speech that he made this afternoon-concerns the question of liquidation and the treatment of capital profits and the suggestion that it is possible, during a liquidation, in a purely discretionary way, to spread the distribution of capital profits over a period of years. No spreading is permitted under this legislation.

The third factual error of some importance-there is perhaps genuine confusion about this-is the matter of various assertions that the tax rate applied under this legislation will be between 60 per cent and 69.62 per cent. That is the notional rate which can be applied to a company or a trust if the dividend payment has gone to a company or a trust. However, the taxpayers who are the ultimate owners of a company or trust have the discretion to accept the liability themselves rather than the company or trust. The dividend would therefore be taxed at the marginal rate applicable to their income. The maximum possible marginal rate, of course, is 60 per cent.

Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle asserted that this Bill imposed a triple tax but failed to establish a case for that assertion, because there is, in fact, no case. She also castigated the Labor Party for allegedly breaking promises about capital gains taxation and tax laws which had retrospective collection effects. I find those remarks somewhat ironic because in this case this Government is doing precisely what it said it would do on many occasions in Opposition last year and during the election campaign. Senator Harradine read out the amendment which I moved in September or October of last year and which sought to achieve what these Bills seek to achieve. I find it doubly ironic that the Liberal Party , which alleges that there has been a plethora of promises broken by this Government, should now decide to take it upon itself to prevent this Government from doing what it explicity promised it would do when it was in Opposition.

The issue of bankruptcies has been mentioned. I suppose that one would have to concede that in the area of bankruptcies the Liberals really have the expertise. In their first full year of Government there were 2,196 bankruptcies, and in their last there were 5,692. Under the last Liberal Government, the annual incidence of bankruptcies almost trebled. Therefore, I bow to the Liberals' expertise in the area of bankruptcies. However, I do not accept the other assertions that have been made. It has been alleged-there have been phoney bleeding hearts pestering the corridors of this establishment for the last few weeks-that if this measure proceeds there will be wholesale bankruptcies. Senator Harradine even quantified it by saying that 26,000 people would get the sack if this legislation were passed.

I make one initial comment on this view. The same sorts of claims were being made last year and there is no record of any firm being bankrupted or put out of business because of the legislation passed last year. At the very least, there is a prima facie case of gross exaggeration in those claims. The companies which are currently operating are unlikely to get assessments because they have replaced the companies with liabilities which were sunk. The shareholders of some operating companies will no doubt receive assessments. They might have to sell to meet that liability: They might have to sell one of their units on the Gold Coast, some of their other real estate or one of their Rolls Royces. I suppose it is conceivable, although I believe it highly unlikely, that they may actually have to sell shares in the operating company to meet their taxation liability. In that case there is no reason why the company would necessarily cease to operate, because the shares would be purchased by someone else. If the person who has the liability has to accept a substantial capital loss, so be it. But even if all the shareholders were caught in such a way, it does not necessarily follow that a business would be closed down for two reasons: First, there is time to pay provided for in the Bill; and, secondly, the business can be taken over. I suggest that any business which is profitable and viable at this stage ought to be a very attractive target for takeover by anyone else for more normal periods. The logical extension of the argument that we cannot recover what the former Prime Minister called stolen money-85 per cent of his party did not publicly dissent from that description-is that if a person robbed a bank and then started a business quickly, not only would he not be put in gaol but also he would not even have to pay the money back. That is the logical conclusion to be drawn from that argument.

In the few minutes remaining to me I will deal with the proposed amendments. An amendment has been moved to refer this Bill for study to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. That amendment will be opposed by the Government for very good reasons.

First, it is not possible for the Finance and Government Operations Committee, or any other committee, to establish the facts in individual cases because of the secrecy provisions of the Taxation Act, which I have already mentioned. Therefore, the exercise is futile. It is even worse than futile, because the Finance and Government Operations Committee will be in the position of having people come before it making assertions that may or may not be true and being unable either to verify or refute those allegations. In other words, there will be an open season. The Finance and Government Operations Committee will become a sanctuary for anybody who wants to tell any story, true or false. He will be secure in the knowledge that there will be no risk of exposure.

The second reason that the Government will oppose this amendment-I suppose it is really fairly insignificant compared with the first reason, which was that such an inquiry by the Committee would be entirely fruitless-is that it would very substantially delay the final resolution of this legislation. For those who purport to be concerned about laws which have implications into the past, that ought to be a quite serious consideration in itself. The Government will not accept the other proposed amendment. I repeat my earlier remark. We will support in the Committee stage, if the Bill gets that far, the removal of the capital profits component but only if there is a firm guarantee from three senators or more that the Bill will pass the third reading. We will not accept any other second reading amendment and we will not accept any Committee amendments other than that relating to capital profits and forecasts by Senators Evans and/or Mason.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation. I would not normally rise, but I think it worth correcting the untrue things said from time to time by Senator Walsh. He said that fraudulent actions were accepted as such by all but six Liberal senators last year. The clear implication of that is that fraudulent actions are supported and condoned by those other six. I was one of the six who crossed the floor, for which I am still immensely pleased, and will do so again. But any implication or imputation that I condone or accept fraudulent actions is untrue, to say the least. Senator Walsh knows that and if he does not he is as bright as he looks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation. Apparently Senator Crichton-Browne did not hear what I said.
