I said that the former Prime Minister described those actions as fraudulent. He described the financial and pecuniary gain received as a result of those actions as stolen money. I said that 85 per cent of the members of the Parliamentary Liberal Party did not publicly dissent from the Prime Minister's view. I said that the six Liberal senators who voted against it on the previous occasion are still here, and that is correct.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Macklin's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add: ', but in the opinion of the Senate the Bills should be amended to remove their effect on purely paper capital gains of affected companies and to provide for an effective anomalies organisation empowered to decide whether tax assessments arising from this legislation should be withdrawn or reduced in cases of demonstrable injustice.'
Question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Questions so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1983 [No. 2]

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX (RATES) AMENDMENT BILL 1983INCOME TAX (INDIVIDUALS) AMENDMENT BILL 1983INCOME TAX (COMPANIES, CORPORATE UNIT TRUSTS AND SUPERANNUATION FUNDS) AMENDMENT BILL 1983INCOME TAX (PAYMENTS FOR WORK) (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 31 May, on motion by Senator Gietzelt:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that we are to have a cognate debate on these Bills and the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2). Some of these Bills were measures of the former Government and were not passed prior to the dissolution of the Parliament. Some new measures arise from the economic statement of May. In general, there are a number of tax provisions. The Bill to which I want to address some remarks and to which I wish to move an amendment is the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill. I speak with regard to the deductions of tax at source. This proposal was enunciated by the former Government. The provisions that are now before us are different in some of their concepts from the ones which we had foreshadowed but which had not been developed into legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The new system provides that there will be a deduction of tax at source from persons and firms in the building and construction industry and in architectural , engineering, surveying and other technical building services. It will apply also to the joinery, road transport, motor vehicle repair and cleaning industries. We find in the Bills that under no circumstances will householders need to make deductions from the payments at source. These Bills relate to projects that cost over $10,000. That is a higher figure than the one we envisaged when we were dealing with this concept of tax last year. We looked at projects around the $3,000 mark as attracting this sort of withholding of tax. We looked also at perhaps a higher retention rate. The rate in the principal Bill is a level of 10 per cent of the gross payment. It is said that in most cases the rate set will be less than the tax that is payable on the work done. I think that is a desirable feature of the legislation. The rate that has been set will mean that there is not an unnecessary excess of withholding from the person who is providing the services. As I understand it, the Commissioner of Taxation may approve a lesser rate where he is satisfied that this would be justified on the previous history of the firm concerned. He may also issue certificates of exemption.

When the Bill was before the House of Representatives we moved an amendment. We were concerned about the effect of this tax on sub-contractors. We felt that the Bill had inadequate provision to protect the independence and continued survival of subcontractors. We also believe that there ought to be some way in which we can monitor the effect of the provisions of the Bill because it is a new concept in taxation. We want to see whether some monitoring of it would reveal any unnecessary difficulties that might arise. We hope, in the spirit of passing legislation, that there can be some reporting back or monitoring by the Government and by others on the effect and administration of it. We are told that difficulties can be foreseen by bodies such as the Housing Industry Association and others who have put matters before us. It is for this reason that we believe that monitoring of the effect of the tax is an essential part of the introduction of a new tax of this kind.

The provisions in some of the other Bills that are before us relate to industry incentives, changes to provisions made by the former Government with regard to depreciation. The Government's statement of 30 March referred to some of the changes, and there are others. The Opposition does not oppose these Bills. As I said earlier, some of them relate to provisions that we had in prospect, such as those relating to investment in Australian films, the tax payable with regard to non-residents and interest on overpayments becoming assessable income, particularly as they relate to the tax that will be distributed amongst the States. Certain other Bills in this batch are consequential upon things that arise in others. In general, a number of the tax procedures, whilst not always in the form that may have been brought forward by us, were foreshadowed by us as measures which we might encompass in future legislation. Others are worthy of support in their own right.

The provisions that were announced in the economic statement which withdrew, changed or reduced some benefits, have had expression in other places and on other occasions. But we are concerned that the concessions that are to be terminated include such things as the two-year write off for the cost of converting oil-fired plant to an alternative energy source and the special 100 per cent depreciation for petrol storage facilities. The rate of depreciation on primary production plant is to be reduced from 33 1/3 per cent to 20 per cent on contracts signed after 19 May. Of course, we are very concerned about the discontinuation of the health insurance rebate prior to the introduction of the new Medicare program. We are also very concerned about the termination of the rebate for housing interest in excess of 10 per cent on loans of up to $60,000 and the interest withholding tax which is to be withdrawn from the general exemption. Those sorts of things are of concern to us. But at this stage of the parliamentary session and in view of the other expressions we have made on these matters, we do not propose to oppose the Bills. I wish them a speedy passage, subject to the comments that some of my colleagues wish to make on specific issues. I move the following amendment in respect of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1983:
At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that it contains inadequate provision to protect the independence and continued survival of sub- contractors'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak specifically about the change in the tax concessions available to individuals or companies which make films. The Australian film industry has been one of the great success stories of recent times. I do not think we all realise how much the image and awareness of Australia around the world has been changed by the dramatic success of Australian films. It has also been beneficial inside Australia. It has improved our self-image, our acceptance of ourselves as a major cultural force in the world. This dramatic success has come to fruition in the last 10 years.
—What is cultural about Mad Max?

—Mad Max is a very well made film. Mad Max II, or The Road Warrior , as it is called in the United States of America, has had a dramatic impact around the world. The honourable senator might not like it; not everyone does. But it was a dramatic box-office and cultural success for Australia around the world. Mad Max II was perhaps more remarkable than Mad Max. For the first time people are being made aware of Australian culture in a major way. Sophisticated magazines such as the New Yorker have had six-page reviews of Australian films. A few years ago that would not, and could not, have happened. One of the remarks I read in a major overseas magazine referred to the 'maturity', 'intelligence' and 'clarity' of our Australian films. One English critic said, about an Australian film: 'exciting, subtle, beautifully made, beautifully photographed, superbly acted and extremely moving, I regard it as just about perfect'. James Mason, the English actor, once confessed that he was tremendously jealous of the Australian film industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The only justification any government can have for subsidies or concessions for the film industry is that they will raise the level of Australian film culture and the output of high quality films. There can be no other justification. It was important that loopholes, through which Australian investments were being channelled into films which did nothing for the Australian film culture, were closed by the previous Government. But there were problems last year with film investment. The trouble was that investors became very wary about committing funds to films because of uncertainty about whether there would be a return on their investment. Investment is always a problem. Investment in films will always be speculative. When a film is completed, what does one have? One does not have a valuable capital asset, such as a block of land or a building. All that one has are some reels of film in a can which people may or may not want to see. People invest in an asset like that only because some revenue will be obtained from it. They are not part-owners in a capital item. There are very few feature films which make profits. Only about one in six Australian films returns a profit to its investors. By the way, one in ten films made overseas return a profit, even in Hollywood.

We have been producing feature films in recent years at an erratic rate. I will run through the figures for the last few years so that the Senate will be aware of the fluctuation. In 1976, 19 feature films were produced; in 1977 there were 19 films; in 1978, 14 films; in 1979, 17 films; in 1980, 23 films; in 1981-82, 33 films; and in the financial year which is about to end, 21 feature films were produced. At one stage it was expected that only six to eight films would be made in this financial year because of the difficulties imposed by the tax concessions which will be amended tonight, and uncertainty about the future of the film industry. Nevertheless, the industry has picked up and 21 feature films will be made this year. Of course, there must be incentives for investors to invest. There are many competing interests for the investment dollar.

A number of points must be made about the film industry. First of all, it is labour intensive. A feature film employs about 150 people, excluding actors, and probably about 3,000 people are directly employed in Australian film production, and many more on a part time basis. This is good for employment but it is expensive for the production of a film. Budgets have risen dramatically in recent years, partly because of competition for scarce resources and partly because more realistic returns have been given to those involved in the film industry. Any tax incentive scheme relies basically on two assumptions: Firstly, that Australian films will continue to be of high quality-there is no purpose in encouraging the making of low quality films-and secondly, that they will continue to be made economically.

The system of tax concessions which is being replaced by this Bill, unfortunately, encouraged the production of too many low quality, high cost films. The problem of the so-called 12 month rule, which is in the legislation that we are amending, is that it forces film producers to mount, film, edit and release a film all within the same financial year, and usually, for investment reasons, in the second six months of the tax year. One did not lose one's tax deduction if the film was not completed in the financial year, but unless it was completed within the same financial year the tax deduction could not be claimed in the year of investment; it had to wait for the year of release. Most investors in films have wanted their tax deductions in the year in which they made their investments. That caused very serious bunching and the hasty making of films. The 12 months rule imposed a 12-month or, more usually, a six-month cycle on a process which normally would take about 16 to 20 months. It was unrealistic to expect quality films to be completed and on screen within 12 months.

In addition to being squeezed in the making of films, the condition of the new Companies Act regarding prospectuses caused serious difficulty, and it caused a further cut in the available time for film making, down to as little, perhaps, as six months. That is an almost impossible time in which to achieve a film of any merit, and the result was too many tax quickies. Bunching also had a disastrous effect on costs. The competition for facilities and crews caused an unreasonable bidding up of their costs. Technicians, crews and casts, faced with a stop-go system whereby they had no work for six months followed by a period of intensive work, tended to claim high rates of pay to cover the full year.

I welcome the amendments. They were promised by the previous Government, and they would have been in place by now but for the change of government. The amendments enable the costs of making a film to be spread over two years instead of one year. The advantages are obvious. The technical, financial and personnel resources will now be able to work at a steady rate throughout the year, and that will reduce the explosion of costs which has been one of the features of recent years. This will help to place the Australian film industry on a sound investment basis and it will also maintain the high quality of our best films and reduce the number of tax quickies.

These amendments, foreshadowed by the former Treasurer, Mr Howard, earlier in the year, coupled as they have been with stringent safeguards, have raised very markedly the morale of the film industry. A period of stability and growth is now foreseeable, which, as I have said, is very important in this dramatically successful industry. But there is still one remaining problem to which I draw the attention of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) who represents the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins). That is the requirement to issue a prospectus. Under the Companies Act, producers of films are required to issue a prospectus for potential investors. These prospectuses can take many months to produce and can inflate a film budget by up to $80,000. I am not saying that it is impossible to get by if one has to issue a prospectus. One example I can give is Barron Films, which put out the prospectus for a new Bush Christmas. It is the first Australian film to be completed after raising the finance through a prospectus. Barron Films put out the prospectus in October 1982, and it was fully subscribed in eight weeks. But selling a film through a prospectus-in exactly the same way as investors are invited to put money into any new company-is something with which the film industry and the film investing public are still finding it difficult to come to terms. This problem should be examined.

The requirement for a prospectus came into effect in July last year. As I have said, it is time consuming and expensive. We should examine the possibility of exemptions from the requirement for a prospectus for large investors. Certainly, we should not allow money to be taken from small investors who do not have the resources to examine exactly what is going on without a prospectus. But many films are made with a relatively small number of large unit investments by sophisticated investors, and I think that if all investors put in $10,000 or more each, there should be an exemption from the requirement to issue a prospectus. It involves substantial cost. It raises the cost of our film making. It reduces the potential profits and, therefore, the attraction to investors of our film making. I urge the Government to look at the problem of the prospectus to see whether something can be done. I welcome what the Government has done with regard to these film making concessions. I cannot refrain from pointing out , of course, that it is implementing what we proposed to do, but I am glad that the Government has done it. I strongly support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill which Senator Hamer dealt with. I shall endeavour not to repeat very much of his speech and to confine myself essentially to the nature of the tax concessions and to making a couple of comments on an associated subject.

SPEECH.PARA: It was in 1977 that the Fraser Government decided that films should be written off over two years, 50 per cent in each successive year. Subsequent experience showed that, whilst it sounded a generous arrangement, this needed to be extended, and it was in late 1980 that the Fraser Government announced that it would provide a 150 per cent tax write-off plus a tax exemption on 50 per cent of the investment. At the time, the Government decided that there was to be a time limit. It was the limit referred to by Senator Hamer-12 months-which, in effect, has meant a bunching of film production in Australia, given that it takes about six months to know that one has the finance to make a film and then to organise it. At the time, the suggestion was made that this could lead to the production of low quality quickies. To some extent that has happened. Certainly not all the films made since that concession was introduced could be thus described, but there has been some element of that.

The vigour of the Australian film industry in recent years-although not in this financial year-is certainly something that has been well reported and generally welcomed. But there have been those in the industry who have been concerned, and who were concerned at the time of that tax concession, that it could lead to a number of low standard films. In the event, that is what happened in a number of cases. It was on 13 January this year that the former Treasurer, Mr John Howard, announced that the period for the spreading of the tax concession would be extended from one year to two years. I note that the operation of this section of the Income Tax Assessment Act will date back to the announcement by Mr Howard in January, when he was still Treasurer. I am a little sorry that this legislation has not come forward earlier. I understand that the Government has wanted to put it all in one omnibus Bill, but it is not connected with a number of the other items that are in the Bill, and they have a different origin. The origin of this legislation goes back some months.

There was some anxiety in the Australian film industry that delay in this legislation could lead to uncertainty and difficulty in the raising of money for the making of films in this financial year. As it transpires less than a month of the financial year will be left after the passage of the Bill. However, it was a little while ago that the new Government committed itself absolutely to carry out its promise to extend the concession over two years. I believe the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) made that statement in late March after the election of the present Government. Therefore, as an aside I would like to take to task a headline on a story which appeared in the Sun- Herald of 22 May 1983. The article reported a statement by Sue Milliken, the President of the Film and Television Producers Association of Australia and a very intelligent and active woman, welcoming these tax concessions. The writer of that article, one Maeve O'Meara, put the statement into the context of the mini-Budget and said:
While the Federal mini-Budget has had a devastating effect on several sections of the community, Australian film producers and investors couldn't be happier.

In case anybody read that article and believed it I say that these tax concessions have absolutely nothing to do with the mini-Budget. Whilst I am sure she is right in the first half of her sentence, in saying that the Federal mini- Budget did have a devastating effect on several sections of the community, if Australian film producers and investors are happy, it is not because of the mini -Budget. In fact, they are probably as unhappy as is everybody else about the mini-Budget.

I would like to raise one aspect of the legislation, the arrangements that have been entered into. Before I go on to do that I wonder whether the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes), who is in charge of the passage of the legislation at the moment, might take on board a request I would like to make. The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment in his speech in the House of Representatives on 25 May stated:
In the United States of America the failure rate--
That is, the failure rate of films-
Is one in 10. In Australia it is about one in five or one in six. Since 1970 some 29 films out of 139 made in Australia returned profit.

I have not been able to identify 29 films produced since 1970 which have made a profit. I wonder whether the Minister could note my request that a list be provided to the Senate at some appropriate time before the end of this session tomorrow afternoon and have it incorporated in Hansard.

The other aspect of the legislation that I want to take up is the matter of the deductions. Under the provisions of this legislation an Australian Film Industry Trust Fund, in which contributions will have to be deposited, is to be established. The Trust Fund is to be administered by the Department of Home Affairs and Environment. The detailed arrangements for the Trust Fund-as to payment of moneys, extraction of moneys, certification of what moneys are to be used for and so on-are really extremely complicated. I would like to suggest that the Government may well think that instead of involving the Department of Home Affairs and Environment in this extremely technical and quite difficult area of trust funds it might give consideration to looking at an alternative. I am not putting forward any amendments and I am not suggesting that it be done in this legislation, but I would request that in the next couple of months the Government look at an alternative suggestion to see whether it may not be a preferable way of handling that money.

I suggest that the Government look at whether the Trust Fund might be administered by the Reserve Bank of Australia. The Reserve Bank has branches in every State. It is the Government's bank and it has had experience in commercial turnaround. There are some precedents for the Reserve Bank being used to administer funds, similar to this one, which were set up under the provisions of Commonwealth legislation. The accessibility of the bank is a factor. Whilst I appreciate that there is an office of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment in every capital city, to set up this sort of section within the Department in every capital city may not be the best way to use officers of the Department. I think it is quite likely that the Department might decide not to set up a section in every capital city.

In every State of Australia there is today either a quite vigorous local film industry as a result of activities by State governments as well on this matter or there are attempts to set up vigorous local film industries. I appreciate that the industry is essentially centred in Sydney. Again I say that I do not necessarily expect the Minister to respond instantly to this question. Unless the suggestion is abhorrent, which I do not think it is, I would like him to take it on board and look at it.

One other point about which I want to say a few words before I conclude relates to a copy of an Australian Associated Press article which came to my attention today. In the context of this legislation it raises a subject about which I have asked a question in the Senate on a previous occasion during this session. I would like to take this opportunity to say just a few more words about the matter. The statement is dated 1 June and reads:
The producer of the cruelty to kangaroos film 'Goodbye Joey' today said the film was made for the pure business exercise of making money.
Producer Peter Cunningham said investors who wanted to take advantage of tax concessions available for films, and to make a profit, had approached him.
He said he hunted around for a subject which would gain free press and free publicity.
His wife saw a magazine article by the RSPCA which highlighted cruelty to kangaroos, and they decided to make a film on that topic.
The statement continues:
. . . He said the film was designed to show cruelty took place and was widespread in the Australian community, not just the kangaroo industry.

There were other things mentioned besides that. I just want to put on record in the Senate a little about Mr Cunningham and what he has been saying about himself and his film depending on which country he has been in. When the subject was raised in Australia he went on record as saying that he made the film to make money. In this case he says he was approached by people who wanted to take advantage of the tax concessions that we are debating tonight, who clearly did not have any motivation on the subject as clearly neither did he. They looked around for a subject which might make money and, interestingly, as he says, a subject which would gain free Press and free publicity.

The reasons Mr Cunningham gave in the United States of America recently for making this film had nothing to do with making money. They had everything to do with the motivation that Mr Cunningham presented on national television in the United States-on a network program shown on several hundred different television stations at peak viewing time on a Saturday night. He said that he had a deep motivation to reveal to the world-to the United States, Japan and Europe-what was happening to kangaroos in Australia. He said how terribly important he felt it was that the export of kangaroo products to those countries be stopped. Clearly the way to do that was to show in those countries a film which he presented as the truth on the Australian kangaroo industry.

Mr Cunningham is reported to have made yesterday-in Australia-the speech from which I have quoted. In Australia he talked about how he was taking advantage of tax concessions and about how, in order to make a profit, another important thing was free Press and free publicity. He has certainly got his free Press and free publicity. So far as I am aware, unless he made a lot of money out of the showing of six minutes of that film on the National Broadcasting Co. network, he still has not made a profit. It is an appalling film. I am aware that he arranged public showings of it in various parts of Australia and had but a handful of people turn up to see it.

There was some controversy about the film being shown on our television networks. Mr Cunningham's sly statements imply that some sort of censorship was imposed on him by government agencies to stop this film being shown on our national television networks. I have discussed the film with the people in all the networks who made the decision that it was not to be shown. It was an individual decision made for sound commercial practices or because Mr Cunningham would not comply with viewing practices which are standard when television networks decide whether they will purchase a film. So it is Mr Cunningham's fault, and the fault of his film, that the film was not shown on national television.

I notice that Senator Gietzelt looks a little startled. I will give one example . In an article printed in a Queensland newspaper, attacking the State Minister for Tourism, National Parks and the Arts, Mr Tony Elliott, Mr Cunningham said, in effect: 'If Mr Elliott felt that way, why wasn't he allowing it to be shown on television?' It was said as though the Queensland Minister was doing something to stop the showing of the film. I have seen all 90 minutes of this abomination and if it had been showing in my living room I would have got up and turned it off. But I had a duty to watch it and I did watch it. I am not surprised that nobody else wants to watch it, much less pay money to see it.

The fraudulent nature of the worst parts of the film has been largely covered in the Press and I will not repeat it. The diabolical nature of Mr Cunningham is such that he presented himself in the United States as a person with a conscience and a care for kangaroos at a time when there was a legal move in the United States which would have taken the kangaroo off the threatened species list. There also was an attempt by a United States Congressman to put kangaroos back on the endangered species list, which would have stopped the import of all kangaroo products by the United States, that sparked the showing of this film in the United States. Mr Cunningham appeared there, saying that if people in the United States cared about cruelty to kangaroos then they would put the kangaroo back on the endangered species list. That was his story there. I am also aware that he appeared on a talk program, which was a publicity type lead up by NBC to the showing of the extract for which it had paid good money. A request was made to the NBC to have somebody else interviewed on that program who could put the Australian point of view. I am aware that Mr Cunningham went to every length possible to prevent someone who could put a contrary point of view appearing on the program with him.

One could ask some questions about just how sound his motives were at either end. I hope he never gets the benefit of the film industry tax concessions for two reasons: Firstly, it is a woeful film anyway and a torture to watch. I do not just mean in relation to the cruelty to kangaroos; it is boring for most of the time and it is very badly put together. Secondly, it is virtually unintelligible unless one knows something about the kangaroo meat scandal. Another point I wish to make is that there is quite fraudulent misrepresentation in the film of the kangaroo meat scandal. Fortunately, no part of this misrepresentation was shown on national television in the United States. Flashes of news stories with headlines referring to the beef substitution scandal in Australia are interspersed with an interview with an official of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union.

I have talked to this official since then, and I understand that he was talking about the risk of kangaroo meat being sold as pet meat in a certain way within Australia. He said that there were certain risks of contamination of meat and of it being thought to be different sorts of meat, but he was really referring to the method of presentation for sale. He at no stage suggested that the kangaroo meat substitution scandal was on-going. When I spoke to him he was quite emphatic that he did not say or mean to say anything to give that impression. By interspersing with these newspaper headlines cut pieces of his interview about risks with kangaroo meat appearing to be other meat, it looked as though the kangaroo meat substitution scandal in the export area is alive and well. It happens that I followed that scandal fairly closely because it very much affected my State of Queensland. I was able to recognise some of those newspaper headlines as headlines which appeared on stories which reported on evidence given to the Woodward Royal Commission of Inquiry into the Australian Meat Industry, which investigated the beef substitution scandal. That report of that Commission came into Parliament last year. The stories are well over 12 months old, some of them close to two years old.

I watched this film in Mr Cunningham's presence and finally I realised the message I was supposed to be getting from this mish-mash of interviews and pictures of newspaper headlines. I said to him: 'Are you suggesting that kangaroo meat is still being substituted for beef for export to the United States?' and he said: 'I have been told that is so'. I said: 'Do you have any evidence for that?'-honourable senators should remember that the film was running on-and he said: 'I will discuss it with you later'. At the end of the film the Minister had to go to another appointment, which everybody in the room knew about. The film ran for a certain length of time and at 6.30 p.m. the Minister had to go to another appointment. At the end of the film the meeting broke up and Mr Cunningham made no explanation whatsoever. As I have said, I contacted that union official and he assured me that that was not his suggestion -so I take it that Cunningham did not get the suggestion from him-in which case this film is a gross misrepresentation of the Australian beef industry. For the sake of making profit and to get the benefit of some tax concessions, he does not care whether he torpedoes an industry that is worth hundreds of millions of dollars. He is hawking that movie around the world, trying to show it in the United States, Japan and Europe.

This is not the sort of film I was referring to earlier when I said that poor films had been made to take advantage of the tax concession. I think it is an extraordinary film and Cunningham is an extraordinary individual, and I hope he goes broke for his trouble.

TALK.START.PARA: —Almost as extraordinary as the Opposition.

—Well, he very clearly does not care whether he sends a lot of other people broke. I am not attempting here to canvas all the ins and outs of the kangaroo shooting industry and what the alternatives are. That is for another time. I am quite satisfied by the action, as I understand it, that the Minister has been taking on that subject. But it is people like Mr Cunningham who give tax concessions and film producers in this country a bad name and I am glad that he is not typical.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I express the appreciation of the Opposition that this legislation has been introduced in this session in time for this financial year. I am sure film producers have expressed their appreciation of that too. This has been a topic on which eventually there was bipartisanship between the Government and the Opposition, including the time when we were in government and the present government was in opposition. I ask the Minister for Social Security to take on board my suggestion that the Treasurer look at the possibility of subsequently doing something about the arrangement for the trust fund for the moneys to which I have refered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the same matter. I do not know whether the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) wants a cheerio call.
—You are not on the speakers list, Senator.

—I am sorry. I could hold on to this until the Committee stage but it seems logical to get through it at the second reading stage. Then we can have a speedy passage of the Bills at the Committee stage.
—Hear, hear!

—The Minister agrees. As previous speakers have indicated, the Government is amending certain aspects of the Income Tax Assessment Act in respect of the Australian film industry. The amendments relate to deductions for capital investment in qualifying Australian films. I have received a letter requesting that another amendment be made to this Act in respect of the film industry. It relates to the educational and documentary film making sector. No doubt the entire Senate will be pleased to learn that I do not plan to move an amendment, since that would hold up the entire package. However, I think it is worthwhile to read part of a letter that was sent to me by Educational Media International. It makes the following point:

SPEECH.PARA: Over 80 per cent of the educational and documentary films used in Australian schools and in adult education and industry are produced overseas. Teachers are crying out for more educational films with Australian content. While feature films and experimental films have enjoyed a measure of Government support over recent years, educational films have languished and received very little assistance at all.

The writer goes on to say that there has been a reliance on Film Australia and other government organisations for the production of educational films, together with those sponsored by other government departments and large corporations. However, a few producers like those involved with this organisation have been struggling over the last few years to produce educational and documentary films on a thoroughly commercial, risk-taking basis, but because so few people are involved at present it has not achieved the government recognition which the feature film industry has had-as Senator Martin's speech would indicate, with some dire consequences on occasions. The writer requests that an app-ropriate amendment be made to the legislation when is it presented in the Senate, apparently unaware of the ramifications that this would have, and concludes by making the points that there is a desperate need for educational films with Australian content and that almost every important event and geographical area of Australia remains to be documented on film in a suitable form for use in Australian schools. It had been my intention, had the House of Representatives not gone on holiday, to move an amendment to insert after paragraph (b) of clause 44 a new paragraph:
(ba) by omitting paragraph (e) of sub-section (5) and substituting the following paragraph:
'(e) a training, public relations or documentary film the cost of production of which is not intended to be recovered by commercial dealing with the film.'

Obviously I have no intention of now doing that, but I would like the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) to see whether he can give on behalf of the Government some assurance that this aspect of film making in Australia will be considered with a view perhaps to an amendment to the Act in the near future, perhaps by some regulation or, for that matter, administrative fiat, so that this area, which is of importance to Australian schools, is considered.

The second matter I would like to raise relates to clauses 56 to 65-the collection of tax at source from certain payments for work or services and associated amendments. It relates to road transport and associated industries, specifically to private contractors generally known as truckies. I understand that the transport workers are up in arms over this, maybe because there is some confusion or misunderstanding in the area. Page 5 of the explanatory memorandum says:

The new measures provide that the Commissioner may issue a deduction exemption certificate on an application by a taxpayer who has carried on business from established premises for the immediately preceeding 3 years and can demonstrate that he has, in all respects, maintained a satisfactory record of compliance with the tax laws during that period.

I have received at my office a number of phone calls asking what will happen to contractors with different employers, particularly with regard to road hauliers. I would like some clarification from the Minister with regard to that. For instance, will it be possible for an exemption certificate to be issued to each truck according to load? Just exactly what is the situation? Will the 10 per cent tax relate to annual turnover or just to profit? I am assured by some of them that they do not make a 10 per cent profit on their turnover anyhow and that this would be rather punitive.

The only other point I want to make is that the Democrats are concerned that the Government within its first 10 weeks has broken an election promise with regard to the tax rebate for contributions to health insurance funds. It was foreshadowed in the election campaign that this would be eliminated when Medicare came into operation or on 1 January, presumably, whichever came first. The Government, in a money making exercise, has seen fit to abolish this rebate from 30 June. While we do not intend to oppose this legislation, I would like to express the party's concern over that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be brief. I speak to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1983 (No. 2). My comments relate to tax incentives for the Australian film industry. I am delighted that the Government has taken on board the proposals that were put forward by the previous Government. I am sure that the amendments will be of great benefit to the Australian film industry. They will enable, of course, the expenditure over two years instead of one year, which will prevent the bunching of low quality, rushed films which took place in the past. I am sure it is fair to say that Australia now produces some outstanding films-in my view of world standard. Of course, the current tax year, 1982-83, has been a most difficult one for Australia's film industry, particularly because of the uncertainty as to what would happen to the amendments to the Act which were proposed. Now, of course, investors no longer need to be wary and are able to commit funds in a very proper, responsible and sensible way. I noted the speech made by Mr Cohen, the responsible Minister in the House of Representatives, wherein he said quite sensibly that anybody who thought that the taxation provisions were too generous really did not have the slightest understanding of the film industry and had no idea what he was talking about. I am delighted that the Government has taken that new-found or reborn view because it was only on 14 May 1982 that Senator Walsh said:

SPEECH.PARA: In October 1980 we received another instalment of fiscal irresponsibility straight out of the Prime Minister's head with the film tax rort. The rort is that expenditure on film production is immediately deductible from taxable income at a rate of 150 per cent and the first 50 per cent of the income derived from that film will be free of tax. In its original form the write-off, the 150 per cent tax deduction, was available as soon as the money was paid into the production account.
He went on at some length.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was that?

—It was Senator Walsh. He called the Act, as it was, a rort. The provisions in it are now to be made more generous. It is now probably a double rort in Senator Walsh's mind. I am glad that he was chastised or summed up appropriately by Mr Cohen who said that he clearly had not the slightest idea what he was talking about and no understanding of the film industry. I commend the Government for its clearer thinking and its more precise understanding of the difficulties of private enterprise. It accepts that tax incentives are required in certain sectors to ensure that we have quality of production in the film industry. I congratulate it for recognising that and for accepting the previous Government's proposals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Opposition for not opposing this legislation. Of course, one did not expect it to do so because the legislation was foreshadowed by the previous Government. I think that was accepted by Senator Walsh in his second reading speech. I will endeavour to answer all the questions that have been put to the Government tonight with the exception of the final one from Senator Crichton-Browne. I have no intention at all of entering into the private warfare between Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Walsh, except to say that I am surprised that Senator Crichton-Browne did not chastise Senator Martin. I thought Mr Cunningham 's efforts in making the kangaroo movie in the way that he did for a quid would have been considered highly praiseworthy by Senator Crichton-Browne. I accept that Senator Martin did not accept it.
—Why do you say that?
—Because Senator Crichton-Browne seems to believe that anybody who makes a quid out of anything is doing the right thing and it does not matter much about the method.
—That's a roughie.
—I am a very rough person. I think that could be applied to Senator Crichton-Browne even more.
—Come on! Be fair. I will be deeply hurt if you say that again!

—I am sure the honourable senator will! The Government opposes the amendment to the motion for the second reading which has been moved by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. I make the following points: We believe the amendment is unnecessary because the new source deduction measures are quite separate and distinct from the pay-as-you-earn system. They are contained in a separate division of the Income Tax Assessment Act, the new Division 3A, to be inserted by clause 65 of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1983. The measures do not in any circumstances imply the existence of an employer-employee relationship where a person is required to deduct tax at source from payments made to another person or otherwise affect the status of the recipient of the payment. This position was made abundantly clear by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) when, as Treasurer, he proposed these measures on behalf of the previous Government in various papers and speeches outlining the basis and the features of the then proposed legislation. The existing pay-as-you-earn provisions which extend to payments under a contract wholly or substantially for the labour of a payee not being an employee as such similarly do not affect the determination of a contractor's status under any other laws. Notwithstanding that situation, further amendments proposed by the Government included in clauses 58 and 65 of this Bill will in fact make it clear that the extended operation of the pay-as-you-earn system to payments for labour will not apply to payments that are prescribed for purposes of the new source deduction system. This will further distinguish the boundary between the two systems and allay the fears expressed, especially by building industry representatives, that the deduction of the tax at source will jeopardise the independent status of sub- contractors.
—Do you understand any of that?
—Yes, I understand it all, Senator. I read it better than you do, too.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hamer made several comments on the film tax amendments. One comment related to the necessity for companies to put out a prospectus. I am advised that films with budgets of under $3m can apply to the National Companies and Securities Commission for exemption from the prospectus provisions, thus freeing them from the time delay and the cost of such provisions. I will refer Senator Hamer's concern about the people who obviously do not come into that area to the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) and see whether I can get some reply. Similarly, I will endeavour to get the list of the 29 Australian movies that made a profit as requested by Senator Martin, before this session finishes. I would be as interested as she is to see it. As there seems to be more movie buffs per capita in this Parliament than anywhere else in the country I think many people would be interested.

I share her comments about the gentleman named Cunningham who has, quite irresponsibly, probably done irreparable damage to the Australian film industry, to Australia's reputation in general, and also, potentially, to the Australian meat industry. This is a serious matter. I also note that Senator Martin mentioned that not all the films made under the tax provisions were good. I make the comment that last year, coming back from Europe, I travelled on a Qantas Airways Ltd aircraft which showed a series of Australian films many of which had been proudly advertised to be shown on that trip. One of those movies was called The Pirate Movie. I would never recommend anyone to see that movie, nor to have it used to advertise the Australian film industry.

Senator Haines asked some questions about the possibility of extending provisions to Australian made documentaries and educational films. I will also take that matter up with the Minister. Senator Martin suggested that the trust fund in which film investments are to be held should be administered by the Reserve Bank, rather than the Department of Home Affairs and Environment. Questions exist about whether under the current legislation the Reserve Bank could operate such an account. Discussions are currently being held with the Australian Film Commission and other representatives to ensure that the arrangements proposed in the Bill work to everyone's satisfaction. However, I am assured that the Government will monitor its operations, as suggested by Senator Martin, to see whether such changes are necessary.

I think I have covered all the questions that were raised, answered some of them, not answered others and given assurances that I will get answers to others . I thank the Opposition for its support for the legislation in general. As I say, for the reasons that I gave, the Government opposes the amendment. I will not read them again for Senator Haines's edification. I ask her to read them in Hansard to see whether she understands them any better.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one point I wish to raise on the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1983 (No. 2). In the Australian Democrats' opinion an extraordinary situation has arisen. The Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) in his second reading speech said:

SPEECH.PARA: Among concessions being terminated by this Bill are the two year write-off for the cost of converting oil-fired plant to an alternative energy source and the 40 per cent conversion allowance for the cost of non-oil-fired plant installed to replace oil-fired plant.

This gives me a terrible sense of deja vu. I thought that we had reached the stage in this country of genuinely appreciating that there will be an energy shortage in the future regardless of the present glut of petrol which is far more apparent than real. Any enlightened government of this country might at least consider this an important matter. In other words, the Government is putting the blinkers back on and saying that we will continue burning up our oil . This legislation will create a disincentive to people to convert to other forms of energy. Of course, by 1990, according to the Petroleum Gazette which is an industry paper, Australia's oil demand is predicted to be 120 million litres a day. Less than half of that will come from known fields. But by 2000-of course things that happen now will very easily affect things which happen in 2000; it is not that far away-134 million litres a day will be used, and only 27 million will be available from current fields. Self-sufficiency in oil will have dropped from about 68 per cent now to 43 per cent in 1990 and 20 per cent by 2000. If that is not sufficient I think the bare facts speak for themselves. The National Energy Advisory Committee, in its report 'Renewable Energy Resources in Australia 1981', states:

In the longer term, Australia has the technical potential to exploit renewable energy by virtue of its large area and its climate. In the shorter term the high costs, particularly the high initial costs of many of the newer technologies, are the main barriers to their more extensive use. It would be desirable for the Commonwealth and State governments and their utilities to renew existing policies to ensure that they do not inadvertently discriminate against renewable energy forms.

That is, of course, a very sensible statement. Even in its wildest dreams in this report, NEAC has not foreseen a situation where a government would knowingly discriminate against renewable energy forms. It merely says that we should be careful not to inadvertently do so. But this Government, which has come into office with great pretensions and which has said that it will reform the Australian community, has taken this step as one of its first acts in its first 3 months in office. I would be delighted to have some explanation from the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) on why this non-progressive, economically stupid step in the long term has been taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the best answer I can give the honourable senator is to refer him to the economic statement of May 1983 and add a bit to it. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has decided to terminate the special depreciation arrangements for storage facilities for petroleum fuel and the taxation concessions available in respect of conversions or replacements of oil-fired and liquified petroleum gas-fired plant. These incentives were introduced to provide a short term boost to investment in these areas following the outbreak of the Iran-Iraq war in 1979 . That purpose has been achieved and the concessions will now be terminated.

Nothing in this legislation and nothing as a result of that statement means that the normal depreciation and write-off provisions that exist already will be changed. Only the special provisions which were introduced for a special purpose will be changed because, in the judgment of the Government, that purpose has now been achieved. I can understand that the honourable senator, with his concern that we should get away from a reliance on oil to alternative sources, might view the legislation in the light that he has. I do not believe, and the Government certainly does not believe, that the removal of these concessions and special depreciation allowances will make a lot of difference to the present rate of conversion to different sources of fuel. I also point out to honourable senators that in any case, under the legislation, the concessions were due to terminate by 30 June next year. The economic condition of the country was one of the reasons why this measure was brought forward in this way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1983, the same Bill that Senator Mason referred to, and specifically to clause 4 which relates to the proposed reduction in the 33 1/3 per cent depreciation rate applying to the storage of grain, hay and fodder in the course of carrying on the business of primary production. We are up against some rather interesting footwork on the part of the Government. I refer the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) to a Press release by the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin. Unfortunately, this Press release was issued on 30 March 1983 and it contains a rather interesting statement about what the Government was going to do in the Bills it would put forward. The Minister said this:

SPEECH.PARA: Under the new provisions, all new primary production plant will be depreciated over three years, instead of the previous five years.
In other words, the Government proposed reducing all depreciation rates to three years instead of five years. Mr Kerin continued:
In addition, on-farm storage facilities for hay, grain and fodder will qualify for the higher rate.
What reasons did the Minister give for this? They were very good reasons. He stated:

. . . the recent drought had seriously curtailed primary producers' investment in plant. However, he hoped the brighter future predicted for the rural sector and the confidence and recognition the Government had shown in the industry by proceeding with the tax incentives would encourage primary producers to invest in their property.

That is an extremely well argued point. It is one which, I think, has been accepted by many people. We tried to press the previous Government on this issue but to no avail. If we wish to drought proof properties we must make sure that we provide attractive depreciation rates. The depreciation rate of 33 1/3 per cent is, I think, a relatively attractive one. We must make sure that primary producers put more of their resources into drought proofing their properties, in particular, into buildings used for storing grain, hay and fodder on which, under this Bill, the depreciation rate is to be reduced to 20 per cent.

I take the Minister back to the debate we had in this place on the various measures that the previous Government introduced in relation to the drought of last year which has now broken. There was a lot of discussion in that debate about whether the measures that the Government was using in that time might support inefficient farmers as against efficient farmers. I made the point, in my contribution to the debate, that the astute primary producer would get a better return for his money if he invested it in a unit at the Gold Coast instead of investing it, as a prudent producer might, in storage on his farm or holdings. If a prudent farmer invested the money in storage for grain, hay and fodder the previous Government's emergency measures, which applied to fodder, would not have meant as much to him as to a person who was looking for higher depreciation rates, such as could be obtained by buying units on the Gold Coast or whatever other capital gain method he chose. The need for this Government to look at capital gains in some areas was one point raised in the previous debate.

The point at issue here is that the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, on 30 March recognised the important issue at stake. He recognised that it was important to give this boost to primary production and he therefore looked at depreciation rates. The National Farmers Federation, in a Press release of 20 May commenting on the mini-Budget, was particularly critical of the changed depreciation rates in relation to storage. It commented that the reduced depreciation rates were totally inconsistent with the report of the Working Group to Provide a Policy Discussion Paper on Agriculture-the Balderstone Committee-and the overall objectives of seeking much more flexible depreciation rates that that Committee suggested. Indeed, the Balderstone Committee suggested that a flexible arrangement should be looked at whereby the primary producer could choose the rate over which his plant was depreciated between three and ten years. It is appropriate in some areas to have a longer depreciation rate than a shorter one. The economic advantage is not always in depreciating over a shorter time. I believe that flexibility arrangements in relation to the various types of primary production would be extremely important.

I would also like to draw attention to the Australian Labor Party's policy speech made prior to the election. Labor promised support 'for private sector investment, to encourage installation of new capacity which is likely to strengthen economic performance.' The speech also stated:
This will be achieved by continuation of the recently introduced accelerated depreciation allowance . . .

I repeat the words 'This will be achieved by continuation of the recently introduced accelerated depreciation allowance'. The first time we consider depreciation legislation, in fact the very opposite occurs. I wonder whether Senator Grimes would like to explain why it is that the Government has chosen to do this. Presumably it is not on the basis that the drought has broken because, if it is, what the Minister is committing the Government to is the very thing we were critical of the previous Government about-that is, short term measures for short term gain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Macklin has said, under the depreciation measures that were announced by the former Government on 19 July last year depreciation over five or three years is to be allowed in the general depreciation allowance area. As part of that package, it is true that the period of depreciation for certain primary production plant, including improvements for the storage for hay, grain, fodder and so on, was reduced from five to three years. In fact, we honoured that promise of the previous Government by allowing the extended depreciation announced on 19 July last year to operate until the day the economic statement was made.

SPEECH.PARA: However, in the judgment of the Government, the reduction to three years in general goes beyond what is reasonable because that arrangement is clearly anomalous when it is compared with the deduction for capital expenditure allowed to other industries. So it was a decision of government, in the light of economic conditions and in the light of comparable conditions between different industries, that the deduction period is to revert to five years with the effect only for plant acquired under a contract entered into on or after 19 May and commenced to be constructed by the taxpayer after that time. Of course, it is a difficult economic decision to make. It is an unpopular decision in some quarters. But we believe that it is wrong to have these varying depreciation rates for the various industries. It is on that basis that the Government made the decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder why it was that the Minister responsible on 30 June did not believe that it was anomalous. On 30 March, under this prospective legislation, honouring the pledge made in the economic statement presumably, he sought to say that all depreciation rates in primary production will be taken back to three years in acknowledgement of that particular problem with that industry. I ask: Why has the Government now chosen to take the entire lot over to the five-year period instead of following the suggestion of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) on 30 March and taking it back to a three-year period in keeping with the promise made before the last election?

—It is worth while pointing out that the economic statement-which I have not seen and do not have here-was in fact made before the Expenditure Review Committee had investigated the situation. It certainly referred to the package which was introduced for 19 July 1982. We still have a situation in which the allowances in this area are more generous than allowances in the other area. As a result of the Expenditure Review Committee's decisions as a result of economic decisions which have had to be made by the Government, this decision was made. I do not think any predictions of disaster in the industry by Senator Macklin or anyone else will be borne out in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuing the question of the Government's decisions in this area, I wonder whether the Minister for Social Security ( Senator Grimes) will be in a position, either now or later, to provide some information as to what saving will be achieved by the removal of this particular policy, which has already been discussed. I do not wish to say any more than that about that aspect.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the matters of very real concern, which this policy approaches but does nothing to solve, is that of energy costs and the provision of energy for primary industry, secondary industry and tertiary industry in Australia. What has happened is a result of the failure by governments around Australia to come to grips with the problem of financing statutory authorities which provide power , permitting them through the use of leverage leasing in effect to sell off some of the assets, and, through adopting policies of very low percentages of internally generated funds, being applied to capital expenditure, creating a situation of massive exposure to the vagaries of interest rates. Of course, interest rates are affected by international matters and are not limited to what we can control within this country. Where gearing ratios are so inordinately high, as they are now becoming in virtually every electricity energy producing authority in Australia, is this not just one more problem being created by the Government for the future of Australia and the utilisation of energy? On a more appropriate occasion I shall speak in more detail about that problem.

Let me cite just one fact: The percentage of internally generated funds being used for capital expenditure purposes by the combination of all of the statutory authorities in charge of the development of electricity energy in Australia has dropped from 29 to 19 per cent. One of them in particular, the Hydro-Electric Commission in Tasmania, has averaged 12.02 per cent over the past five years. I would have thought that that was an alarming fact which would have been a matter of concern to the Government in dealing with this problem. Perhaps the Minister would care to comment on that matter as well as the particular question that I asked.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I will have a crack at the first question the honourable senator asked but I might have to pass on the second one, although I have heard the honourable senator express his concern many times on the matters that he has raised, particularly with regard to statutory authorities. Although they are affected by this legislation I suggest that I am within reasonable grounds in saying that they are only indirectly affected. I will seek a proper answer from the responsible Minister, firstly because of the detail needed and, secondly, because of my admitted lack of expertise in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: The figures showing the effect of extending from three years to five years the period over which primary producers can depreciate certain plant and equipment appears on page 57 of the economic statement of 19 May. The savings are estimated to be $9m in 1983-84, $44m in 1984-85 and $89m in 1985-86. I point out that those are pretty reasonable savings. They are the figures in the document.
Bills agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment or requests; report adopted.
