DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1983CUSTOMS TARIFF (COAL EXPORT DUTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1983EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 May, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bills be now read a first time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1983
The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1983 now before the House proposes amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1982.

Schedule 1 of the Bill operates from 1 January 1983 and enacts tariff changes which in the main were introduced into the Parliament during the 1982 Budget sittings as Customs Tariff Proposals Nos 16-26 (1982).
The amendments initially introduced by these proposals gave effect to decisions taken in respect of reports by the Industries Assistance Commission and the Temporary Assistance Authority.

The Proposals were not embodied in the Customs Tariff Act 1966 and have since been translated into a simplified format to meet the requirements of the Customs Tariff Act 1982, which has operated since 1 January 1983.

To give legal effect to Customs Tariff Proposals Nos 16-26 (1982) from their date of operation to 31 December 1982 an amendment is included in this Bill to deem the repealed Customs Tariff Act 1966 as having been amended in accordance with the proposals.
Schedule 1 to the Bill also includes a number of changes to ensure the correctness of the Customs Tariff Act 1982.

Schedule 2 of the Bill operates from 1 January 1983 and sets out the rates of duty applying to New Zealand goods as a result of the closer economic relations trade agreement with that country. New Zealand goods not included in this schedule are accorded duty free entry into Australia.
Schedule 3 of the Bill operates from 19 January 1983 and contains a further change to correct the Customs Tariff Act 1982.
A summary of amendments contained in the Bill has been prepared and copies are available from the records and table office. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
CUSTOMS TARIFF (COAL EXPORT DUTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1983

Coal export duty was introduced in the 1975-76 Budget with effect from 19 August 1975. The then Treasurer, Mr Hayden, indicated that coal prices and especially prices for high quality coking coal had risen dramatically in the two previous years, and that very large windfall profits were being earned by the export sector of the coal industry and that the Government considered it reasonable that part of the increased profits should be channelled to the community by means of an export duty.

The level of duty was set at $6 per tonne on high quality coking coal with a carbon content above 85 per cent on a dry ash free basis and $2 per tonne in other cases. Amendments introduced between October 1975 and August 1981 exempted certain types of coal from duty and varied the rate of duty for other types.

The purpose of this Bill is to ratify the exemption from coal export duty of all coals then dutiable at $1 per tonne effective from 29 July 1982 as notified in Commonwealth of Australia Gazette of 29 July 1982.

As a consequence, the only coals that are still dutiable are high quality coking coals mined from open-cuts in production before 1 July 1980 and from depths not greater than 60 metres and these are dutiable at $3.50 per tonne.

The exemption of 29 July followed consultation between the former Minister for Trade and Resources, the Rt Hon. J. D. Anthony, the Premiers of New South Wales and Queensland, the Australian Coal Association and the union movement. The exemption was part of a series of decisions reached by the then Government and the Governments of Queensland and New South Wales in July 1982 aimed at assisting the industry at a time when it was facing difficult marketing conditions with escalating cost pressures.

At that time a clear need was seen to reinforce Australia's international reputation as a supplier of coal. While the exemption gave an immediate benefit to establised exporters, in the longer term the bulk of the benefits will accrue to new projects.
This Government proposes to review the range of taxes and related charges currently imposed on the coal industry.

The Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) has already initiated action to convene a joint meeting with relevant Ministers from the exporting States and the Australian Coal Association, at which proposals aimed at rationalizing industry taxation may be put by all parties. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1983

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Excise Tariff Act 1921 to enact four excise tariff alterations that affected the rates of excise duty on stabilized crude petroleum oil, naturally occurring liquefied petroleum gas, beer, certain manufactured tobacco products and certain petroleum products.

Excise Tariff Proposals No. 2 (1982) were introduced into the House on 17 August 1982 as a Budget measure. They increased, from 8 p.m. on that date, the excise duty on beer by 8 cents per litre, certain refined petroleum products by 1 cent per litre and certain manufactured tobacco products by between $2.48 and $4.95 per kilogram.

Excise Tariff Proposals No. 3 (1982) were introduced into the House on 24 August 1982. They increased the excise duty on stabilized crude petroleum oil from $186.26 per kilolitre to $205.97 per kilolitre and the excise duty on naturally occurring liquefied petroleum gas from $20.46 per kilolitre to $25.93 per kilolitre, with effect from 1 July 1982.

Excise Notice No. 2 (1982) was published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette on 30 December 1982. That notice further increased the excise duty on crude petroleum oil from $205.97 per kilolitre to $227.13 per kilolitre and naturally occurring liquefied petroleum gas from $25.93 per kilolitre to $36.63 per kilolitre, with effect from 1 January 1983.

Those three alterations were made in accordance with the policies of the previous Government and while the double dissolution terminated the effect of those instruments, measures were taken to ensure the continued collection of the duties at the increased rates.

However, consistent with statements made during the March election campaign the Government reduced the price of Australian produced crude oil by $1.79 per barrel with effect from 1 April 1983. This reduction recognised the cut in the official Saudi Arabian price for the marker crude Arab light of $US5.00 per barrel. The devaluation of the Australian dollar forced on the Government in the wake of the election campaign reduced the impact of the Saudi Arabian price cut on Australian prices. Nevertheless, a significant reduction was possible to the Australian price of crude oil.

Consistent with this change in the import parity price it is necessary to set new rates of excise on crude oil effective from 1 April 1983. This alteration was effected by Excise Notice No. 2 (1983) which reduced the excise duty on stabilized crude petroleum oil from $227.13 per kilolitre to $216.11 per kilolitre. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —These cognate Bills are now at the second reading stage. As Senator Peter Rae has said, they embrace a number of excise and Customs measures. I wish to speak briefly tonight on one of them, the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill. In particular I wish to concentrate on clause 4 of that Bill, as it relates to diesel fuel. Taken with the Diesel Fuel Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1982, the Bill implements last year's Budget decision to abolish various exemptions from excise duty on diesel fuel for use on public roads and proposes to replace it with limited claim rebates of the duty on fuel used for, for instance, domestic purposes, in hospitals, nursing and convalescent homes, and in the agriculture, mining, fishing and forestry industries.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems that when this measure was brought in last year the reasons for the change were threefold. Firstly, exemption arrangements had proved difficult to administer so as to prevent abuse. We saw some indication of the abuse but also a lot of innocent people suffered and continue to suffer. Secondly, by denying some users exempt status it was intended to reduce the usage of excise exempt diesel fuel for purposes for which other fuels are more appropriate. Thirdly, the changes were designed to broaden the tax base by increasing reliance on indirect taxation. But it seems that the Australian Labor Party is committed to reducing the incidence of indirect taxation. It seems to be part of its platform because at page 52, item 12, under taxation, it is stated that Labor will reduce the relative incidence of indirect taxation.

Also, in the statement of accord between the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Council of Trade Unions-the so-called prices and incomes policy-it is stated at pages 12 and 13 that the Government will endeavour to reduce the relevant incidence of indirect taxation because of its regressive and inflationary nature. Indeed, Mr Hawke, in the Government's national recovery and reconstruction plans, stated that Labor's commitment to eschew increases in indirect taxes will set inflation on a downward trend. But what concerns me is that this Bill seeks to increase indirect taxation. I suggest that, if this is the policy, it makes a sham of those statements.
But there have been many other problems associated with these new arrangements, especially for people in the Northern Territory. This is the point that I will speak on briefly tonight.

Since those changes, some industries have had continued relief. But tonight I wish to mention particularly those people in the tourist industry who have been hit very severely by the excise duty. While people in the agricultural, mining and fishing industries have been exempt-at least exempt to some degree-those in the tourism industry have suffered. It may be hard for honourable senators, so far away from the pioneers in the outback in the Northern Territory, to believe that these small groups of people are suffering considerably. Their costs have increased and many businesses are being sent to the wall. There is danger of destroying the small operators in the tourist industry. Tourism is being developed in the outback areas of the Northern Territory-perhaps even further out than Ayers Rock. Pioneering-type people are breaking ground in the tourism field out in those areas. Eventually, tourism will increase in those areas. But while those small pioneering business people suffer all these various setbacks, losses and hardships, they are ultimately forgotten.

I believe the time has come for a change. The previous Government indicated, when we made protests about these measures, that it would review the excise duty as it affects the tourist operator. On behalf of those people in the outback, I make the plea that they should be considered now. Tourism is worth some $12 billion in Australia. Many people do not realise that the travel industry is possibly larger than the mining industry and employs some 400,000 people. I make the plea to the Government that it review this decision.

Once again I speak on behalf of those small people in the outback-I know plenty of them-who have given away the comforts of the cities, the convenience of the towns and have made their way out into these very isolated and remote places. The excise duty is proving to be such a handicap to them that I think in this next year or two, as I have said before, many will go under. I think of places like Daly Waters. People may remember it. Books have been written about this area-about that rather romantic and isolated place, the Daly Waters pub-Ross River and so many places. The people living there are pioneers. This legislation is hitting them very hard. I suggest that the Government should look at their situation and bring some relief to these small people. The amount of revenue that would come from these small people in the outback is extremely small. Relief from the excise would allow them and their families to live and so develop the tourist industry in the outback.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity of speaking on but one of these Bills, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1983, which will amend the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975. It is indeed a very brief Bill of slightly more than one page. All it does is add a couple of paragraphs to countervailing duties provisions. But it does give me an opportunity of reminding the Government that in this climate of economic uncertainty and vulnerability there is a need to monitor very closely what is happening in the manufacturing sector, the level of manufacturing activity and the extent to which local manufacturers are being affected by imports.

SPEECH.PARA: Regrettably, as with all governments, the difference between this Government's perception of what is happening and industries' constant warnings of what they see is happening is indeed large. We have this gulf of difference. Sometimes this gulf is one of suspicion and lack of trust. I hope that over the years we may be able to lessen that gulf. In doing so I believe we will not only enhance the prospects of increasing manufacturing in Australia but also overcome some of our unemployment problems.

In this time of international recession there is always a tendency for overseas companies and countries to try to dump their produce overseas. Australia is a particularly vulnerable market for such happenings. We hear of the European Economic Community countries dumping their surplus products not only on Australia but also on our markets overseas, such as Japan. Cheese is a typical example. We not only have the problem of the loss of overseas markets to contend with but also the protection of the home front in the first instance. Unfortunately we have found that attempts by government to try to shorten the interval between the threat of dumping, the time the goods arrive and remedial action is always far too long. What happens? Markets are jeopardised and in many cases it takes months for them to recover. Given the present vulnerability, jobs are lost, people have to stand down and pay packets are affected.

I therefore welcome the announcement made by the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator John Button, who has called for an urgent review of all dumping matters. I hope that this review will be sufficiently thorough and widespread, covering all sectors of industry, large and small, because so often in these inquiries it is the intermediate business that misses out. Often the intermediate sized business is the most vulnerable. Possibly it does not have the expertise in handling dumping matters that larger businesses may have. This sector of the economy employs a very great number of people. Traditionally, manufacturers have complained about the length of time it takes to bring dumping cases to finality before a court. I applaud the actions of the Fraser Liberal Government last parliamentary session in adding to the staff of the Australian Customs Bureau and reducing some of the red tape. This overcame many of the problems that were raised by manufacturers and helped to ensure that dumping does not take place.

I am not talking about protection; I am talking about dumping. Dumping is abhorrent. It puts goods into the export market at prices which are substantially below those of the goods being produced at home by local manufacturers. A lot of developing countries, unfortunately, are a little prone to dumping practices. Some of these countries, I believe, adopt such practices, probably unwittingly, to get foreign exchange. A lot of manufacturers in Australia complain about cheap goods coming in, with government assistance in some cases; they are underpriced, marginally costed, or the like. Places such as Korea, Taiwan, China, India, New Zealand and Russia are all frequently cited, but it does not stop there.

Most members of this Senate would be aware of the concern that I, as a Tasmanian, have with the closer economic relations agreement with New Zealand. I applaud all the genuine efforts that have been made to minimise the problems. It has been thought that many of the problems between the two countries were insurmountable. Coming from Tasmania, I recognise that the produce of our two countries is very similar. Therefore, it was necessary to eliminate as quickly as possible some of the artificial measures of assistance that exporters from New Zealand have received in the form of market support schemes, export incentives and a number of other assistance measures. I acknowledge the amount of work that has been undertaken on both sides of the Tasman between primary producers of specialist products and manufacturers, but I still give the warning that, despite all the meetings and industry panels that are held, merchants who can see a quick buck can get under these voluntary agreements. If they can see something in it for themselves, they will trade goods at prices which adversely affect the markets of one country or the other. We will have to live with the problem of people seizing an opportunity to make a quick buck, despite all the goodwill among manufacturers, produce merchants and so on. That is the really weak link of voluntary agreements. We will have to constantly monitor such actions to ensure that industry on both sides of the Tasman is not harmed in this way. The present economic climate is not right for any reduction in tariffs . The job position is too vulnerable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the only reason?

—No, of course it is not the only reason. Wages, productivity and inflation are all other reasons. Tonight I wanted to dwell merely on this one reason. I do not think that in every speech I make I have to give the whole gamut of problems that we are encountering. I think it is time that we focused attention on particular reasons, with goodwill and understanding among all parties, whether we have a free trade philosophy or not. We have to recognise that over recent years there has been a tremendous loss of employment in manufacturing. It happened in the heyday of the Whitlam Government with its 25 per cent across the board tariff cut. Industry has never really recovered. Action has never been taken on such a scale since that time to restore the competitive advantage of producing locally. This has fairly wide implications, particularly in the defence industry. Frigates may have to be sent back to the United States of America for repair to certain parts of their equipment simply because the expertise is now not available in Australia. This lack of ability of Australian manufacturing to cope with a wide range of areas in relation to defence matters is of concern. I am pleased that Senator Button is taking note of some of these comments.

SPEECH.PARA: The other area which gives me concern is the setting of quota levels. Some of the current quota levels were set when trade was very much more buoyant than it is now. In some cases those quota have built-in growth factors which favour imports over local production. We can appreciate that when we have a declining market and when a quota has been set up with a built-in factor that favours imports the local manufacture is very much at a disadvantage. I venture to say that most of the textile manufacturing industry in Australia is in trouble at present. One of the reasons is the quota setting formula, which I would like to see amended as soon as possible. If we are not careful the small manufacturer and the business in Australia will become very much part of a dying race. As we know, this sector of the economy employs over 60 per cent of the work force. It appears that the only time it receives very much attention from any political party is election time when votes are being canvassed.

I believe that Australia is a great country. But it worries me to see the decline in manufacturing because manufacturing provides an opportunity for a wide range of expertise and skills within the community. I believe that the attitudes and philosophies of a community are widened when skills are very divergent. If we are to tutor young people through universities and give them high degrees what are we going to follow up with? Will they just be surveyors for open cut mines which export the resultant product overseas? We have to try to increase the level of activity in Australia so that we can convert the raw material into its final form. It is therefore necessary that we employ the highest level of technology. I think it is important that we not only employ that high level of technology but also encourage research and development in Australia. Not only is it costly to import other people's technology but also the skills that are needed will be produced overseas.

I believe that we have to create the widest sphere of opportunities for young graduates to be able to take their place in the Australian work force. We can do that only by broadening our manufacturing base. It is true that we might have to ensure that some traditional practices, including management practices, are changed, but in our attempt to create what is known as sunrise industries let us not neglect established industries. If we put a little more research and enterprise into those industries we can retain our labour force. It would be a lot cheaper to keep those people in employment than to introduce new industries and allow them to slide down. I take this opportunity, at the close of the session, to warn the Government not to fiddle too much with tariff reductions because I believe that could have severe consequences on our manufacturing industry and on employment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1983. I do so because I want to make clear to the Senate and the public not only the extent of the broken promises of the Hawke Government but also the magnitude of its deception and, I add, the misleading statements on this matter by Ministers. I remind the Senate-although it needs no reminder-that over recent years the Australian Labor Party was continuously vocal against the price rises which occurred under the Fraser Government in relation to oil and petrol. Indeed, very clear statements were made by members of the Labor Party that they would never do such a thing. Let me make abundantly clear what their argument was. As late as 25 January this year the then Opposition spokesman on resources and energy, Senator Peter Walsh, made a statement in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's policy of world parity pricing is fraudulent . . .
That is, the Fraser Government-
It is a taxing policy disguised as a pricing policy.

He went on to say that the Labor Party would not support in any way the use of petrol pricing-putting up the price or not putting it down-in order to gain or save revenue. Quite clearly, that policy was abhorrent to the Labor Party. If one wants a further example one can consider the words of the previous Opposition spokesman on minerals and energy, the person who is now the Treasurer . He said--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about all the times you put it up.
—We will come to that. It will be good for Senator Gietzelt's immortal soul to look at the deception that was involved in this matter. Mr Keating said:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fraser's remarks only underline our view--
That is, the Labor Party's view-
that the Government's oil pricing policy is not an energy policy but a taxing policy.
Mr Keating said that was wrong. He continued:
Mr Fraser is greedy for more tax revenue. His Government's Budget forecasts are in tatters . . .
He went on to condemn the idea that anyone should so manipulate the price of petrol to save revenue for his deficit. He said:
In these circumstances, Mr Fraser refuses to pass up the option to go on squeezing Australian motorists irrespective of any continued fall in international oil prices.
Then he said:
Government policy ties Australian petrol prices to the price of crude oil from Saudi Arabia. Any fall in the Saudi price must be passed on to Australian motorists in lower petrol prices.

One thing was made clear-that a Labor government would never use a petrol pricing policy as a taxing policy. We know that if there is any fall in the price it must pass it on. But we can do better than that. We can refer to what was said by the then new Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hawke. As late as 9 February this year, in his election statements, he said certain things and it is very important for us to understand them. He said:
Petrol prices will be immediately cut by about 3 cents per litre under a Federal Labor Government.
I repeat: Three cents a litre. He continued:
The $3.23 a barrel rise imposed by the Fraser Government on January 1 will be scrapped.
As well as immediate benefits to motorists and business the petrol price cut will reduce the Consumer Price Index by about 0.5 per cent.
The next sentence is of tremendous importance. He said:
If the OPEC price falls further in the interim the price will be cut by that further margin.

Quite clearly there were to be two cuts-firstly, a 3c cut and, secondly, if the price of the Organisation for Petroleum Exporting Countries was to fall further the price in Australia would fall by the further margin. Nothing could be clearer than that statement-no taxing policy must be adhered to. Along came the new Minister for Resources and Energy, who is interested in talking about the credit or otherwise of other people. In a Press statement on 16 March 1983 he attempted to suggest that he was paraphrasing what Mr Hawke had said. He stated:
Before the Election we promised to cancel forthwith the January 1 $3.23 increase or,--
He did not say 'and'-
if the OPEC fell by more than that, by the full amount of the OPEC cut.

Honourable senators will see the absolute deception. Mr Hawke said: 'You will get two price cuts. You will get a 3c price cut and then, if the OPEC price falls, on top of that, you will get that price fall'. What happened? It was not very long before the present Government decided that the 3c price cut was wrong. The Labor Party in opposition said that the previous Government would put up the price. The Labor Government decided that the cut should be only 1.5c, so the first statement fell by the board. During January, when the previous Government and I, as Minister, increased the price, there was a tirade of abuse from the Australian Labor Party. The Labor Party said: 'What right has the Fraser Government to put up the price when OPEC prices have not risen?'

It is true that freight prices have risen. It is true that devaluation has forced up the price of oil purchased overseas. The Labor Party said: 'We will not use devaluation as an argument. The price has not gone up and therefore the Fraser Government should not have put up the price of petrol at all'. In other words, the Labor Party was saying that the use of devaluation as an argument was absolutely wrong and the use of increased freight charges as an argument was absolutely wrong. So the Labor Party believes that those arguments should never be used in working out a taxing method in order to protect revenue. It believes that a government should always precisely follow the OPEC price and should never use movements in devaluation or freight charges. Indeed if the 3c price cut had been implemented and the OPEC price fell, that further fall in price should have been passed on.

The fascinating thing was that when the new Minister for Resources and Energy, who is so solicitous about other people's credit, put out his Press statement, he was very careful to show movements in devaluation and freight rates. What did he do? He deliberately misled people about what Mr Hawke had promised. He knew that Mr Hawke had promised two things, in parallel with each other-a 3c fall and a further fall if the OPEC price fell. He put out a statement, as a Minister, not that it would happen as a supplement, but, I repeat:
Before the Election we promised to cancel forthwith the January 1 $3.23 increase or, if the OPEC price fell by more than that, by the full amount of the OPEC cut.

Of course, that is a completely misleading statement. What did the Government do ? It used the devaluation and increased freight rates argument to wipe out the $ 5 fall in oil prices. That is a strange argument because Senator Walsh had argued earlier that there had been a de facto fall before and that the previous Government should have passed it on. He then argued that that was no longer the case. The Government, instead of giving the 3c cut which it promised during the election campaign, gave a 1.5c cut. Instead of passing on the $5 fall, which would have cut the price of petrol by some 4c to 5c, it gave nothing. It blithely said: 'We are doing this because of devaluation and increased freight charges'.

That was anathema to the Labor Party as an opposition. That was what Labor went to the people saying: 'We oppose the Fraser Government doing these things'. It is no good their arguing that they had to do this because they had a large deficit. Mr Keating and Senator Walsh had stated emphatically that one should never use an alteration in the price of oil or petrol as a tax measure. But in any case, what a fraud. When they did this, they knew that the $9.6 billion figure that they had pushed around was wrong; so much did they know it was wrong that they did not even use it at the National Economic Summit Conference. By the time that the Summit had come, they were using an entirely different figure. Yet when the Summit had come and they had had the discussions in another place, they were still fraudulently peddling here a figure of a deficit of $9.6 billion, knowing that option A and the Summit documents, which they said they preferred, had a growth in gross domestic product of 2.7 per cent, and knowing that option C had a growth of 3 per cent. Knowing those things and having used those things there, they went on peddling this deceit that they had to do these things in the name of a deficit which they knew did not exist.

TALK.START.PARA: —It never existed.

—It never existed. It was a fraud perpetuated in order to say: 'Look, we made some promises, but we shall not carry out any of them'. What we have now is not just the streaker; we have the emperor's robes. As we know from the story, the emperor's robes showed him naked, but in this case it is naked of any alibi or any defence. Let us allow that in other things the Government has been saying, 'We must do this; we must not implement this promise because it would alter the revenue'. What the Government has said emphatically about oil prices is that one must never use petrol pricing as a taxing measure, but that is precisely what it has done.

SPEECH.PARA: So I repeat, we have had not just a broken promise, not just another one of the dozens of broken promises, but a deception, a misrepresentation as between two Press statements, a complete misleading of the people on this matter and a deception on the considerations. This Government said, when in opposition: 'We would never use devaluation and freight rates'. After all, that is what the January price increase was based upon-an alteration in freight rates and devaluation. But my goodness, no sooner had it got its hands in the till than, on 16 March, the man who now seeks to smear the credit of others in this place broke every single promise and committed every possible deception. The man who was most noisy about petrol pricing and how it was wicked to raise petrol prices , the man who said that one must never use that as a tax, the man who said that devaluation and freight rates should not be so used, the man whose party said: ' We will give you three cents plus the full value of the $5 otherwise', came along and, first made a misleading statement in his Press statement-it is here for all to see-and then, without any kind of blush, attached a schedule on how to do it, showing the use of devaluation and freight rates to do it.

I hope that we shall never again hear in this chamber any lectures in ethics from that particular gentleman. This is Senator Walsh, who every day is more holy than thou, as honourable senators know. He talks about others being discredited. The fact is that not only is he in emperor's robes, but those robes are tattered and fall to the ground. I know of no greater series of deceptions than those that lie here. It is a very sad day indeed when perhaps the main issue that the Labor Party pursued for three years, that of petrol pricing, should be one of its most dastardly breaches of promise, one of its greatest deceptions. It is time that the public knew about it. The public has been led to believe that this is only a matter of getting 1.3c instead of 3c. That is not true at all. The promise was 3c plus the value of $5. The promise was, in fact, 7c altogether. If there is one Minister who should take note of this it is the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button), who is presently in the chamber, because nothing hits the people more than the price of petrol.

One can look at the mini-Budget and see where the Government hit people. It hit the farmer with his avgas. The farmer is knocked to the ground at the moment from the effects of drought and flood. What did the Government do? It put up the price of avgas. It hit the ordinary traveller by raising the price of avtur, ordinary jet fuel. The Government is reducing freight equalisation for fuel in country areas. All these things have occurred against the background of what the Government has been saying for the last three years, the main thrust of which was that it was utterly wrong to alter petrol prices in any way as a taxing medium. I can say only that I hope we will never again hear any of those hypocritical statements. I wonder whether honourable senators remember their Shakespeare. I quote:
Mark you this, Bassanio,
The devil can cite scripture for his purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having heard the speech Senator Sir John Carrick has just given in relation to one of the Bills with which we are dealing cognately-the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill-I can say only that it will be abundantly clear to anyone and everyone why I on behalf of the Opposition will now move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of this Bill. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion add:

', but the Senate notes that the Government has failed to honour its election commitment to reduce the price of petrol by 3 cents per litre and its pre- election undertaking to disregard currency fluctuations in setting the price of Australian produced crude oil'.

I do not think I need to take the time of the Senate to add to the reasons why the Opposition believes that honourable senators should give this Bill a second reading cognisant of the fact that there has been a major, massive and extremely clear breach of undertaking. It is one of the numerous breaches which have been very clearly outlined by Senator Sir John Carrick, the former Minister for National Development and Energy. He is the person who is probably exclusively and exceptionally in a position to be able to outline the nature of that deception.

The remainder of the matters dealt with by this Bill comprise excises on natural gas, beer and tobacco products. They are consequent upon the 1982 Budget of the former Government-that is, the Liberal-National Party coalition Government. With the exception of the duty on crude petroleum, to which Senator Sir John Carrick has referred, the matters arise from the 1982 Budget. The new Government is implementing the policy of the former Government. There is an understanding, which I believe ought to be referred to at the moment, and that is that when budgets are introduced they announce a variety of measures which require legislation later to implement them. But there is the accepted practice that from the time of announcement those rules will apply; that is, the new announced rules in relation to excise matters, tariff matters, tax matters and a variety of matters will apply from the date of announcement. I repeat that the new Government is implementing measures of the former Government. Naturally, the Opposition totally supports that happening. It is proper that that should happen . I do not wish to delay the Senate by talking for a long time in relation to each of these matters, which are supported by the Opposition, but I will deal very briefly with each of the Bills.

I have just referred to the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1983. The next Bill is the Customs Amendment Bill 1983, which in a lot of ways is a fairly major Bill. It modifies the existing by-law system for granting tariff concessions. I refer to it relatively quickly, in the light that it is a decision of the previous Government which is being implemented by the new Government. It gives effect to certain changes recommended by the Industries Assistance Commission. Those recommendations resulted from a consideration of the way in which an important part of our total Customs tariff system operates.

It is relevant to put on the record briefly that the sole and long-standing criterion for concessional by-law entry has been that suitably equivalent goods are not reasonably available from local production. That has been the basis upon which one could have admitted to Australia, without penalty, goods which could not be obtained here. The provision was designed to protect Australian industry. If Australian industry was not producing a certain product application could be made for exemption from what might otherwise mean the payment of an extra price penalty. That criterion caused considerable difficulties on economic, administrative and legal grounds. As a result, in April 1981 the commercial by- law system was referred by the former Government to the Industries Assistance Commission for review. That was to be the first complete review of the by-law system. The Industries Assistance Commission suggested something which causes me a slight degree of concern. I will refer to it later. It proposed that the new criterion to be applied to goods for which admission to Australia was sought on the ground that no suitable equivalent, or comparable, goods were manufactured here should be as follows:

Commercial tariff concessions will be issued where the Minister is satisfied that no goods serving similar functions are produced or are capable of being produced in the normal course of business in Australia.

The words used are important because they define what becomes at times a particularly contentious criterion which involves, for Australian individuals and companies, significant amounts of money. The key words in the new criterion are 'serving similar functions' and new section 269B (4) provides an interpretation of these. I am concerned because the new test will be the degree of 'cross-elasticity of demand' between the imported and the Australian produced goods. When we begin to import into legislation what amounts to jargon, we are starting to go down a track that we may one day regret taking. The term 'cross- elasticity of demand' may be of significance in economic debates between economists, or people who have the enthusiasm to pursue the jargon of economists . It is almost like returning to the practice of incorporating latin maxims in our legislation rather than expressing it in words which may be understood by the average citizen. I suppose that by and large Customs matters involve people who are specialists. The average person who will read the Customs Act, which we are amending, is likely to be reasonably expert and not an average member of the community. But when we use such terms as a criterion in legislation we certainly exclude a large section of the community from having any capacity to understand what the legislation might be all about.

I do not wish to delay the Bill but I wanted to make that comment. Although the situation which has arisen may be unfortunate, I do not in any way blame the Government. As I said earlier, this Bill comes before the chamber on a completely bipartisan basis. It is a recommendation of the Industries Assistance Commission, accepted by the former Government and being implemented by the present Government. So I am making the comment only for the purpose of future reference. I hope that we will not have jargon introduced into legislation. Notwithstanding the criterion being met, proposed new section 269E provides that the Minister may refuse to grant a concession if he considers that such a concession would have a substantial adverse effect on the market available to goods produced in Australia or if it would not be in the national interest. The phrase 'not in the national interest' gives considerable flexibility to the Minister of the day.

I do not wish to deal at great length with other matters, but let me sum up this piece of legislation by referring to one or two. There is quite an important requirement for advertising applications for new concessions in the Commonwealth Gazette which, it is believed, will make for better public scrutiny of the system which is operating, particularly by local manufacturers whose views will be taken into account prior to a decision being made on an application. It is important to refer to that fact when we are debating this legislation to ensure that people know that that opportunity will be there should they wish to avail themselves of it. Finally, the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills said in relation to this Bill:

The Committee reserves final comment on this aspect of the Bill until the completion of the examination by the Administrative Review Council of the current review of decisions under the Customs Act 1901.

However, the Committee draws the clause to the attention of the Senate in that it might be regarded as making rights, liberties or obligations unduly dependent upon non-reviewable administrative decisions.

That relates to clause 5 of the Bill. In view of the fact that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, whose service to this chamber I think has been extremely valuable, has suggested that it ought to await completion of the examination by the Administrative Review Council, I do not think we should hold up the Bill. We should accept the advice of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. Accordingly, I will conclude this part of my remarks by saying that the Opposition supports the Bill which is, after all, something which it initiated in the first place.

The next Bill to which I wish to refer is the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1983 which makes amendments which are consequential upon amendments to the Customs Act 1901. Again these matters arise out of decisions taken by the former Government and are being implemented by the present Government. The Opposition supports it. There was some suggestion that an amendment would be moved. I do not wish to take away from anything which Senator Jack Evans may say in a moment, but the Opposition was concerned about the matter which was the cause of the amendment he proposed. In view of the fact that apparently he has obtained some undertakings which no doubt he will shortly outline to the Senate, the Opposition will not take the matter any further but supports what Senator Jack Evans was doing and the importance of getting some resolution of the matter of concern.

I turn to the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1983 which provides for a decrease in the rate of coal export duty on certain coals. The present provision imposes a rate of duty of $3.50 per tonne. This amendment excludes the provision that coal other than high quality coking coal fetch a rate of duty of $1 per tonne and inserts a new section 7 to provide that coal other than high quality coking coal is exempt from export duty imposed by the Act.

That amendment arises out of the 1982 Budget-that is, the Budget of the former Liberal-National Party coalition Government-and is being implemented again by the new Government pursuant to the proper mode of operating in such matters. I indicate that the Opposition will support that amendment, which was initiated by it in government.

The final Bill to which I refer is the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1983, which is almost wholly the implementation of decisions of the previous Government. There is the implementation of the Industries Assistance Commission and Temporary Assistance Authority reports which were accepted by the former Government, together with the removal of the 2 per cent revenue duty on ships, Customs tariff changes resulting from increases in excise duties in the 1982 Budget, complementary provisions of duty-free admission for those ships eligible for payment of bounty when constructed in Australia, changes arising from Australia's commitment to the South Pacific Regional Trade and Economic Co- operation Agreement and an addition of goods to schedule A of the now superseded New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement. Whilst I would love to talk about all of these subjects for quite some time, because they are matters about which I think there is a lot to be said, in view of the fact that they are bipartisan implementations I do not wish to hold up the Senate at this stage by referring to them in detail. Therefore, I indicate that the Opposition supports the amendment which I have already read and, with the exception contained in that amendment, supports the passage of the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for the warm comments they have made about this legislation. There are a couple of matters on which I should comment. I regret that Senator Kilgariff did not make his speech about diesel fuel excise last year. Perhaps he did; perhaps he was just making it again. All I want to say about that is that the Government is very conscious of some of the issues which he raised and which he alleged impose hardship on some sections of the community; certainly inequities or apparent inequities. The Government is examining those matters. I think I can safely say that it will have some response to them in the Budget context, or certainly during the Budget session of Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank Senator Watson for his contribution to the debate. I wish we could have had it on another occasion-no doubt we will-when we could debate some of the issues he raised regarding protection policy generally. As Senator Watson well knows, the Government is committed to not reducing levels of protection in the current economic situation apart from those schemes which contain particular phasing provisions. It will maintain that commitment. Senator Watson also spoke at some length about dumping. I inform the senator-again as I believe he knows- that the Government has been concerned about dumping complaints and the effects of dumping. There have been substantial discussions about that issue with industries concerned about dumping and also those who are concerned about it for different reasons, such as the National Farmers Federation. I believe that this week the Department of Trade will be publishing a discussion paper on the question of dumping. I asked earlier if this paper had been published. It clearly has. That is good. I believe that paper will be the subject of considerable further discussion within the community in the next month or so and officers of the Department will be conducting seminars or discussions on that paper in the next few weeks. The Government is very concerned about the issues which Senator Watson spoke about in relation to dumping. The Government is taking all possible steps in relation to those matters. Senator Watson invited me to take note of his comments on a number of matters. I do.

With regard to the comments made by Senator Sir John Carrick, I was surprised to find him so worked up about what he alleges to be deception and broken promises. I have been a senator since only a little before the Fraser Government was first elected. I suppose I grew up in that environment. If we are found guilty by the present Opposition, of course we have the same excuse or plea to make to the judge-the people of Australia-that is, that we grew up in a bad political environment in terms of broken promises and a failure to honour commitments to the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you gave the streaker's defence.
—I am always fascinated by Senator Walters's interjections. The difficulty is that I do not understand that one. I assume it was more intelligent than most.
—It was the former esteemed leader of your party, Arthur Calwell, who said that two Wongs don't make a white.
—I do not know what the relevance of that comment is to a tariff debate, but I suppose Senator Peter Rae is suggesting that there should be a tariff in immigration matters as well.
—I was merely thinking that it wasn't much of an argument to say that, whatever mistakes we might have made in government, you were entitled to make mistakes too.
—I agree. It is totally puerile. It is about the level of debate which took place in the Senate yesterday when we were supposed to be discussing industry policy.
—You are pretty sensitive.
—Yes, I am very sensitive, Senator; and I will tell you why if you want to bring the debate on again.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as Senator Sir John Carrick's comments are concerned, I make the point that the Government came to office at a time when the economy, as Potter Partners in a letter to companies about the share market situation commented, was in the worst condition it had been in for 50 years. We came to office confronted with the need for a devaluation as a result of the irresponsible comments by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) speculating about currency movements. In that situation, the Government honoured its promise insofar as it took steps to reduce the price of petrol from 1 April 1983. But, in so doing, it , of course, was caught with the effects of the devaluation. In that sense, the comments made about the one and a half cents which were put to us are correct in terms of the ultimate effect.

Of course, the Government has had to make a lot of difficult decisions about these matters and undoubtedly will continue to have to do so in the next few months. I do not think that we would be particularly respected by anybody if we shrank from the need to make difficult decisions about these matters. I really think it is of little point to refer to debates which took place in the Senate five and six years ago in support of an argument about a differential of one and a half cents per litre in the price of petrol in 1983. But, if that is important in the lexicon of Opposition weapons with which to beat this Government, of course, the Opposition will do so. But I am not sure how significant that action will be seen to be.

I found it extraordinary that Senator Sir John Carrick chose to talk about the extent to which this Government, in the May economic statement, had allegedly acted in a way which was detrimental to the interests of farmers. The example that he chose was fascinating. He said that farmers would be very adversely affected by the increase in the price of avgas. I do not know what farmers he knows-I know a lot do have aeroplanes-but I would not have thought that an increase in the price of avgas would be a matter of general concern to the farming community.

TALK.START.PARA: —It must be to the pastoral industry.

—I appreciate that and I appreciate there would be a concern about crop dusting. But I am talking about the general range of farmers in Australia. If the small increase in the price of avgas were all Senator Sir John Carrick had to rely on in terms of his criticism of this Government's attitudes to farmers as expressed by the mini-Budget, I find that an extraordinarily desperate allegation. I must say that it is not one we have heard from any of the farm organisations in discussions with them about the May economic statement . They know, as do most Australians apart from honourable senators opposite, that in terms of the May statement there was a need for some degree of sacrifice to be made by all sections of the Australian community. The farm organisations, as Senator Scott, who is nodding his head, wisely knows, are not particularly upset about an increase in the price of avgas.
—Senator Sir John Carrick mentioned that on top of another matter.

—I understand the point. I thank Senator Peter Rae, who spoke on behalf of the Opposition, for his support of the Bills. I am filled with fellow feeling about his concern for the English language and jargon when he referred to 'cross-elasticity of demand'. There is, of course, an explanatory memorandum to the Bill which might in some way help in understanding that. But I do not perceive that to be Senator Peter Rae's real point. He is talking about the unfortunate consequences of jargon. I am trying to think of an example I struck the other day which is probably worse but I cannot remember it. I thank the Senate for its support of the Bills and I hope they can now have a speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: I had a number of discussions with Senator Jack Evans, an Australian Democrat senator, in relation to a matter which concerned him and about which he came to see me. Perhaps I can short-cut what I have to say about this matter. Last year a question emerged in relation to dumping complaints concerning PVC. The real allegations were that dumping was occurring from Hungary and the United States of America. A number of steps have taken place and a number of discussions have been held since that complaint was first made, and I understand Senator Evans's position to be that it appeared that there had been unfortunate delay. I think it has been explained that many of those delays occurred because of the Department having to consult another department about what could be done about this matter. I want to say, in trying to expedite this question, that, as a result of the Department's consideration of the matter, discussions with the Attorney-General's Department and so on, I am able to give an undertaking that a reference will be made to the Industries Assistance Commission next week-I believe by Wednesday but I can certainly say next week-in relation to this matter. This Bill, together with its companion Bills, Supply Bill (No. 2) 1983-84 and Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1983-84, seeks interim appropriations for the services of the Government for the period 1 July 1983 to 30 November 1983, by which date it is expected that the Appropriation Bills (Nos 1 and 2) and the Appropriation Bill for Parliament, which will form part of the Budget for 1983-84, will have been enacted.

Supply Bill (No. 1) seeks appropriations totalling some $5,741.3 million for the ordinary annual services of the Government. This is $925.3 million, or about 19.2 per cent greater than the equivalent amounts provided in the Supply Act (No . 1) 1982-83.

A large part of the increase reflects higher staff ceilings approved by the previous Government after the 1982-83 Budget, salary and other cost increases and an extra payday which falls within the Supply period in 1983-84 as compared with 1982-83.

I mention two specific provisions in the Bill. First, $21 million is included under the Australian Electoral Office for the purpose of the referendums on fixed term parliaments and other matters of constitutional reform, in repect of which the Attorney-General introduced Bills on 12 May.

Secondly, $150 million is provided for the Advance to the Minister for Finance, $25 million more than in 1982-83. Apart from an adjustment made last year to bring the Supply Bill (No. 1) provision into line with that included in the Appropriation Bill (No. 1), this is the first increase in the amount provided in the (No. 1) Advance since 1979. The need for the increase reflects the growth in expenditures over this period and the pressure placed on the Advance in recent times.

The need for the Government to seek urgent interim appropriations at the special sittings in April-including supplementation of the Advance in the Appropriation Act (No. 1) 1982-83-was a clear manifestation of the pressure.
I wish to emphasise that this Bill does not anticipate decisions yet to be taken in the 1983-84 Budget context.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: -There is only one controversial section in the National Health Amendment Bill. That is the section which applies to the new pharmaceutical benefits declaration. The former Government, when extending the $ 2 pharmaceutical benefit to all pensioners and to disadvantaged persons who qualified under the guidelines for a health card, realised that there must be some method of stopping the abuse that was taking place in the system. The only people entitled to free medicine from the chemist were pensioners who held pensioner health benefit cards-by the simple fact of their pensioner number appearing on the top of the prescription form. We knew that there was considerable abuse of the system. Some people were telling doctors that they were pensioners, were giving fictitious numbers and then going along to the chemist and obtaining free medicine. Estimates were made of the extent of the abuse and the Government decided that, when the benefit was extended to a considerable number of people-indeed to all pensioners holding health care cards ; there was no means test--
—You are not defending the old form?
—No, I am not. I am saying that the old form, where the pensioner number appeared at the top, was open to abuse and because of the abuse -
—I am talking about Jim Carlton's form.

—Senator Tate should listen. I have not reached that point yet. I just said that with the original prescription form, where the pensioner's number appeared at the top, there was certain abuse. Indeed, it was estimated that the cost of the abuse was in the area of $20m.
—Much of it by doctors.

—I can assure Senator Childs that there was no need for a doctor to abuse the system. That gave him no advantage, it advantaged his patient. A patient would say to the doctor, 'I am a pensioner. My number is such and such'. The doctor, in all good faith, would fill in that number at the top of the prescription form. The patient would take that prescription form along to the chemist and be entitled to free medicine.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that there was some abuse of this system. I repeat, it was estimated to cost $20m. That is not chicken feed. It might be chicken feed to Government senators. Indeed, during the hearings of the Estimates committee, Senator Grimes said that there was not much abuse, that it was only an estimated figure and no one was sure of the amount. But it was $20m and that is a considerable amount of money. We found, when we did extend the benefit generously-so that the patient had to pay only $2 instead of $4-to all pensioners and disadvantaged people who held a health card, that something had to be done to stop any further abuse. The prescription form introduced by our Minister for Health at that time, Mr Carlton , was one that I admit, as he does, had become very complicated. Patients had, in filling in the form, to supply a deal of evidence to prove their identity and entitlement to the medicine and elderly patients, especially, found this difficult. There was a fair bit of objection to this-
Government senators-A fair bit!

TALK.START.PARA: —For once, I agree entirely with the Government senators. There was a fair bit of objection to this, to the extent that the Minister for Health said that he would review the procedure and introduce a Bankcard type system. The chemists and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia were very much in favour of that. They said that a Bankcard type of system would suit them fine; that it would be very simple system and would prevent a considerable amount of abuse. The Minister for Health said that he would bring in a simplified form. But that was not the view of the Opposition. At that time the Opposition, in the form of Senator Grimes, said that it would abolish it altogether.
