SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 March this year-as everyone knows, that was three days before the election-Senator Button was reported in the Hobart Mercury as stating that a major American company was negotiating to establish a computer hardware manufacturing plant in Tasmania, and that this would employ 300 Tasmanians. He said that if his party was elected:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we would quickly encourage such a development and support it financially.
He went on to say:
The Federal Government would not be prepared to give the American company the full amount of money it was seeking.
Then he refused to say how much that figure was. Indeed, no detail whatsoever was given, although he said:
The matter is one of urgent negotiation and the company is taking into account Tasmania's labour market and expertise in wanting to come here.

He said a lot of research had been done. This American company was willing to come down and employ 300 Tasmanians, and the inference was that we really should not be worried too much about the dam. He also stated that he had spoken to the company's interstate agents. That must sound pretty firm to honourable senators. He had spoken to this company's agents and he assured the Tasmanian people on 2 March that this company was indeed ready to negotiate and come down to Tasmania.

Following Senator Button's election statement, the Tasmanian Government telexed him on 15 March, after he had become Minister for Industry and Commerce, and asked him for details of the negotiations with the American company. No reply was received from Senator Button. A second telex was sent to him on 8 April. On 21 April Senator Button telexed the Tasmanian Government advising it of the name of the company. But the company that he named as being very willing to go down to Tasmania was not an American company. It was a Melbourne firm. The Melbourne firm had approached the Tasmanian Government with some preliminary proposals. The firm is a marketing and distributing agent for an American manufacturing company which could be interested in setting up a plant in Tasmania.

As our State Government was very anxious to encourage industrial development in Tasmania, it repeatedly telexed the American company seeking the details of its plans and requirements and advice about the way it could assist in the implementation of those plans. A telexed reply was received recently from the American company stating that it had no plans whatsoever to establish a computer hardware manufacturing facility either in Tasmania or, indeed, anywhere in Australia. Senator Button's statements in the Press report of 2 March have been proved to be completely without foundation. The honourable senator made claims about an American company's intention to build a large factory and create jobs in Tasmania. That company has stated that it has no such intentions. On 5 May the Tasmanian Government again telexed Senator Button and asked whether he could vouch for the bona fides of the alleged intentions of the American corporation to set up a plant in Tasmania. Senator Button did not reply to that telex.

If honourable senators remember, I also asked Senator Button questions in this place about the matter and again he would not give any answer to me. It is very clear now why he did not answer me and why he did not reply to the Tasmanian Government: He had no direct knowlededge of the American company's plans or intentions. He had purely accepted hearsay reports in Australia from people who were interested in beating up a story on the eve of the Federal election for their own political purposes. He did no research whatsoever. He accepted the hearsay suggestions that the company could set up a plant and used them solely for his own political purposes several days before the 5 March election. The people from whom he accepted the hearsay reports were attempting to demonstrate to the Government that there were other things to look at apart from a dam. One of the Australian parties involved in making the computer plant in the Press statement of 2 March claims exactly that. The whole exercise was a cynical, irresponsible, baseless ploy by people opposed to the Gordon below Franklin project. They tried to create claims about alternative sources of employment in Tasmania and alternative uses of funds. But computers and computer parts do not make electricity. They will not meet Tasmania's power needs in the 1990s. The American company whose name was so wrongly and irresponsibly used in this affair has no current plans to set up in Australia.

Senator Button has acted most unwisely in this affair once again. He gave endorsement to false claims about industrial expansion and job creation in Tasmania on the eve of the Federal election. In doing so, he has shown great insensitivity towards the plight of the unemployed in Tasmania where, over the last few years, the unemployed rate has been greater than in any other State. Senator Button has been party to the making of unsubstantiated claims, to the raising of false expectations and to much wasting of official time which would have been better spent seeking more genuine job creation proposals. His cynical, irresponsible attitude towards Tasmanian job creation has been matched by his Government's cynical, miserable, punitive actions towards Federal expenditure in Tasmania and by his leader's abolition of the Wynyard Airport scheme, the Craigbourne Dam scheme and the Warner Creek scheme. Again, those things surfaced only after the Federal election. It is clear that this self-styled Government of co-operation and consensus does not govern fairly and equitably for all Australians. It has no intention of doing so and it never did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to Senator Walters for alerting me to the fact that I was to be savagely attacked during the adjournment debate.
—If you think that is savage, you wait.
—I am waiting.
—You had better watch out.

—I assure the honourable senator that I do watch out, and I will continue to do so. I am sure that the whole Senate is grateful to Senator Walters for telling us 'computers do not make electricity'. That is something which I have learnt tonight and which I am sure that Senator Crichton-Browne and others have learnt as well. It just illustrates the absurdity of the level of debate which has taken place about industry development in Tasmania. The art form now, I presume, is to make electricity; I do not know for what purpose. I hope that electricity will be generated in Tasmania for other purposes.
—You are not treating it seriously.
—I do not treat Senator Walters seriously. That is probably the pity, as she sees it. I clearly do not.

SPEECH.PARA: Prior to the election campaign I was in Tasmania. In the course of a Press conference, in a lengthy discussion about industry in Tasmania, I referred to two matters. Senator Walters might like to take me up on the other matter at some future stage. One of the two matters to which I referred was the desirability of developing high technology industries in Tasmania, of which the computer industry was an example. I instanced the fact that there was a very high level of computer literacy in Tasmania because of the relative sophistication of the Tasmanian education system in relation to computers.

As to the other matter I mentioned at that Press conference-Senator Walters might dig this one out too-I expressed the view that, if a national maritime museum were to be built in Australia, it ought to be sited in Hobart in order to attract more tourists to Tasmania and because of the peculiar history of Hobart as a port. I felt it appropriate that that matter should be considered by any government following the publication of a report which had been commissioned by the previous Government and was awaiting publication, which publication was interrupted by the calling of the elections. That is still my view.

I expressed a view in respect of both those matters. I said that the sort of industry which one would like to see in Tasmania was a computer industry. I then told those present that I had been approached in Melbourne, as I was, by the agents of an American computer company who had expressed interest in siting a factory, or whatever one makes computers in, in Tasmania. That is all I said. That is true. Senator Walters says that I had not been approached by the American company. That is absolutely true. I never claimed that I had. I said that I had been approached by agents for the company.

Of course, the proof of all that is that there has been correspondence with the Tasmanian Premier about that matter. Senator Walters referred later in her speech to 'much wasting of official time'. I will tell her where the wasting of official time was. It was in the Premier's office. Instead of passing my letter on to his Minister for Industry and Small Business, who I concede has been very diligent in sending me telexes about this matter, the Premier apparently dwelt on the mail, without passing it on. I have received telexes from the Minister for Industry and Small Business in Tasmania. I obtained a reply to the first telex which he sent me. I am endeavouring to obtain an informed reply to the second telex which he sent me. When I obtain an informed reply, I will respond to the appropriate person-the Minister for Industry and Small Business in Tasmania.

I will not respond to Senator Walters in relation to a matter in respect of which I am in communication with the Minister for Industry and Small Business in Tasmania. I really do not want to say any more about the matter. I think that trying to make an issue out of this matter illustrates again a degree of desperation on her part. I expressed my view before the election in relation to industry in Tasmania, and I will express it again. If I can do anything to assist with the establishment of a computer company in Tasmania I will continue to do so. None of the efforts which I or the Minister for Industry in Tasmania have made has been assisted by Senator Walters barging into this issue. I regard it as an insult in the extreme, or I would from most people, to be described by Senator Walters as being unconcerned about the price that would apply to the unemployed in Tasmania. Senator Walters does not have a mortgage on virtue. She does not have a mortgage on attitudes to people in the electorate. She does not have a mortgage on virtue in relation to people who are suffering in this country. If she did and had explained it a bit more in the last seven years probably she would not be sitting where she is tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask a question of the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Communications. As the question has a somewhat longer preamble than would be appropriate in Question Time, I considered it appropriate to raise the matter now. The question arises from an answer which the Minister gave to an honourable senator's question yesterday regarding the Channel 0-28 network. Yesterday's Hansard states:

SPEECH.PARA: The second part of the question related to the extension of Channel 0-28 to capital cities other than Sydney and Melbourne, which are the two capital cities which currently receive that service. I said last week in an answer to Senator Bolkus that that matter will be reviewed in the Budget context. I repeat that answer. The only thing I can add is that it is high in the priorities of the Government's communications policy to achieve that extension as quickly as possible.

My concern relates to a commitment which the previous Government made to extend this service to the Canberra-Goulburn-Cooma region. That commitment was made on 25 July last year when it was announced that multicultural television would be extended via Channel 0-28 to another 10 Australian cities and country centres. This specifically included the Canberra-Goulburn-Cooma area under the timetable for 1982-83. The statement referred to the fact that Canberra had been chosen as the first city because of the line carrying multicultural programs to Melbourne which already passes through the national capital.

The matter came up and caused some concern during the election campaign. On 22 February the Canberra Times referred to the Labor Government's statement that was interpreted as there being a possibility that this would not occur. The matter was referred to by the Age of 23 February. The article stated:
The ALP announced this week that it would adapt or replace the SBS, which runs Channel 0-28 and radio stations 2EA and 3EA.
I am mindful of the Labor Party's platform as printed at clause 18 on page 16. The policy provides:

Subject to satisfactory alternate arrangements being made with ethnic communities for management of 2EA and 3EA, and for funding of ethnic broadcasting by alternative means, the abolition of the Special Broadcasting Service.

The Ethnic Broadcasters Council and the Ethnic Communities Council of the ACT have been very active for a very long time in campaigning to have the 0-28 service brought to Canberra via the line that now goes through the national capital. As a result of the answer which Senator Button gave yesterday I wonder whether he can clarify the situation as to what we believe was the commitment that the service would come to this area this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In my answer to a question from Senator Bolkus I said that the matter of the extension of Channel 0-28 would be considered in the Budget context. I am sure Senator Reid would expect that that is the time when we would deal with this matter. My recollection of the program of priorities enunciated by the previous Government, as Senator Reid said, is that Canberra was on the top of the list, followed by Adelaide, Wollongong and so on. I see no reason why the present Government would not follow that order of priorities. A decision will be made about this matter in the Budget context. My recollection of the cost of bringing Channel 0-28 to Canberra is that it would be in the order of $1m; I am not sure.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Reid also referred to the Australian Labor Party platform with regard to the Special Broadcasting Service. I did not apprehend that she had any concern about that matter in relation to bringing Channel 0-28 to Canberra. If she did, I can only answer it in this way: The Government, before the election, enunciated a very specific program about the future of the SBS. Perhaps the honourable senator could indicate whether she wants me to go into the matter now . I will certainly supply her with a copy of the election program which was announced. It foreshadowed some changes to the structure of the SBS, but not in a way which would affect the provision of multicultural television services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to bring to the attention of honourable senators the appalling lack of basic human rights in Chile. In the ten years of Pinochet's dictatorship, agonising hardship and insecurity have been suffered by the Chilean people. Tens of thousands have been killed since the 1973 coup and approximately one million people have been exiled . Violation of human rights is a constant occurrence. Political repression, censorship and persecution are facts of life. All sectors of the Chilean community have been affected, including the church, which has come under attack for its defence of human rights.

SPEECH.PARA: Torture is a blatant Government policy. Amnesty International recently made public its finding that Chilean political detainees are systematically tortured and sexually abused by Government security forces, with strong indications that Chilean Government medical personnel are actively participating in the torture. Amnesty International has documented cases of the most vile and hideous abuses against political prisoners in its 80 page report on human rights in Chile. The daily survival of the Chilean people is threatened by the disastrous economic policies and failures of the Pinochet regime. Unemployment is reportedly running at 40 per cent of the population and inflation at 30 per cent. There is an enormous shortage of housing and a large sector of the population does not receive basic nourishment. User pays policies in education have led to considerable under-enrolment in schools.

These circumstances gave rise to a massive broad based demonstration against the Pinochet regime in Santiago on 11 May. The people on the streets called for jobs, food, justice and freedom. Pinochet replied with further repression, leaving two killed and hundreds injured. Media censorship was tightened and massive house searches took place in Santiago and other major cities. In night raids, hundreds of people were rounded up and held in a stadium. There are growing fears that those who have been detained may be subjected to torture and possible death-as have many who have gone before them.

The Australian Government should use every possible international forum to protest against the widespread repression and denial of human rights to the millions of underprivileged people in Chile and in other Latin American countries which are dominated by repressive and corrupt military juntas. We should also be advocating to our so-called rich and powerful friends that they should not continue to prop up these regimes with generous credits and supplies of arms which are used against their own people to deny them basic democratic rights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to comment briefly on one of the documents which were proposed to be discussed on Tuesday but which missed out. Fortunately, I have been able to have it listed for the August session. It is the fifth annual report of the Commonwealth Ombudsman. I note from some newspaper comments that the Ombudsman himself was disappointed that the report had missed comment and discussion in the Senate, so I thought that I would make a few comments tonight and hope that others will take up the matter further in the August session.

SPEECH.PARA: The Ombudsman says in the report that, with some notable exceptions, his annual report to the Parliament has not engendered much comment from the floor of either the Senate or the House of Representatives; he had expected more. Perhaps I am simply trying to meet some of the Ombudsman's requests to the Senate. The report mentions a number of things which perhaps are known to other senators but which I find quite fascinating. It mentions that the first office was opened in Canberra in 1977 with an investigation staff of two and a backlog of 200 written complaints. Last year there were 2,500 written complaints and 9,000 oral complaints; so there is now a staff of 50 in seven offices around Australia, which is a considerable growth in five years.

Many of the complaints that come to the Ombudsman are outside his jurisdiction. They are matters which concern State problems that have been raised by people, and the Ombudsman, of course, is required to point out that he cannot deal with those. Other complaints are outside the Ombudsman's jurisdiction. There has been a great increase in the number of complaints, as the figures I have mentioned show. The Ombudsman proposes that these are due to two factors, perhaps because there is much more involvement by the Government in people's lives. He cites as an example social security matters and the fact that in the last year, 1982-83, there were 1,700 complaints about social security matters, and 374 in the year 1977-78. This is directly paralleled by the number of people who are unemployed or in other ways dependent on social security pensions.

He also suggests that another reason why there is an increased number of complaints is that there is a much better awareness among people of the Ombudsman and of their rights. Not only is this because the Department of Social Security is telling people of their rights but also because even our educational systems are giving people information about their redress if they are unhappy with decisions by departments.

The Ombudsman also reports that a number of complaints received involve matters of great complexity and take considerable staff time to deal with. To list just a few examples, a number of complaints dealt with were official examples consequent upon allegations about the use and effects of herbicides in the Vietnam war, actions connected with the cancellation of pensions and sickness benefits following allegations of a widespread conspiracy to defraud the Commonwealth, investigations and prosecutions of doctors for alleged infringement of the National Health Act and the health insurance legislation, the effects of Commonwealth planning proposals on land affected or potentially affected by such proposals, the provision of wrong advice leading to claims of substantial losses by individuals relying on that advice and alleged unauthorised interception of telephone services. Those are simple examples that the Ombudsman cites as examples of the complex nature of some of the complaints that cannot be dealt with in a simple fashion.

In many ways the Ombudsman is pleased with the response of various departments to any investigation that his organisation has had to conduct. However, he says that whereas there has been a lot of co-operation, in some cases there has been active defensiveness and obstruction, and some places have even created, it seems, specialists to deal with dealing with the Ombudsman. There has been some finessing of ways of dodging the appeals. He draws our attention to this and in various parts of the document he makes further reference to it. He is not too troubled by it because, he says, it is for him to determine whether he will investigate a matter, so clever footwork by people in various departments will not necessarily prevent him from following up any complaint that comes to him.

Essentially, though, the Ombudsman is in praise of the departments and their co -operation with any investigations he has tried to institute or has instituted. He says that, interestingly enough, the effect of the Ombudsman has been to encourage departments to make decisions that take into account the possible need for accountability, so that in some ways the existence of the Ombudsman has encouraged departments to build an accountability factor into their departments. He says that this, in fact, in the long run has a cost-benefit effect. He mentions in particular the Australian Telecommunications Commission, which has gone to considerable lengths to put internal accountability mechanisms and complaints mechanisms into its organisation so that people can have most of their complaints dealt with within the organisation and do not have to seek the support of an ombudsman in dealing with any problems. In the report he states:

Telecom is, of course, only one of a number of agencies that have seen the value of improving relations with clients and such developments in the long run must be seen as more cost-effective than responding to large numbers of inquiries from external review bodies.

In the opening section he addresses himself briefly to complaints that were raised in the first place about an ombudsman perhaps being antagonistic to a Westminster parliamentary system. He says that all his experience over the last five years has shown that, far from eroding such traditional systems, the institution of ombudsman has reinforced and supported their functions. He says that, in fact, quite a number of parliamentarians or their constituents seek the Ombudsman's help in pursuing complaints; so members of parliament themselves have actually asked the Ombudsman for help. Again, the Ombudsman can sometimes decide that the parliamentary system may be a more appropriate way for people to follow up complaints or seek satisfactory solutions to problems they have. So he finds that the Ombudsman and the Westminster system work very nicely together.

The Ombudsman also makes the point that he does not see his task as necessarily finishing with the resolution of a complaint but that, in fact, the complaint may lead to further investigations and recommendations to departments about changes in administrative practices or policies so that deficiencies leading to complaints do not continue to exist. In various places in the document he points out that insufficient staff means that that part of the Ombudsman's role is, by and large, not fulfilled at this stage, although this is something he would like to see happen.

The final point I make tonight, which the Ombudsman raises in his report, concerns the fact that the ability of the Ombudsman to function independently of government depends not on the mode of the appointment of the Ombudsman but on the powers which the Parliament chooses to vest in him, together with a statutory guarantee of tenure. In these vital respects the Commonwealth Ombudsman's position is secure. This is a very brief outline of this document. I think it contains some most important material. I am glad that we will have the opportunity to deal with it more fully in August.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise in the Senate a proposal that the Government, in its budgetary considerations, contemplate the prospect of allowing mineral exploration companies the advantage of offsetting their losses against profits derived from other areas of activity. I note that in an answer to a question asked yesterday the Minister for Resources and Energy , Senator Walsh, appeared to be advocating a consistent treatment for all mining revenues, irrespective of the mineral involved. That approach does not take into account all the varying degrees of difficulty attached to locating and extracting different minerals; nor does it take into account the economics of the wide range of mining projects in Australia today.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, if this is a principle which the Government seeks to apply where there are revenue benefits to it-for evidence of this we need look no further than the introduction in the recent economic statement of a clamp down on the concessions which have been available until now for the goldmining industry-it is a principle that should apply equally when there are benefits to be received by the mining industry. I refer particularly to the discrepancy between section 124AH of the Income Tax Assessment Act relating to exploration expenses incurred in respect of petroleum and section 122J of the same Act which refers to expenses incurred in exploration for minerals. Many honourable senators may be aware that section 124AH was added to the Act following the previous Government' s 1976-77 Budget as an attempt to stimulate exploration in the oil and gas industry in Australia.

Together with the parity pricing policy the previous Government's policy of providing a taxation incentive to explore for petroleum has been a notable success to say the least. In 1980 90 exploration wells and 27 development wells were drilled in Australia. In 1981 the figures were 149 and 55 respectively and in 1982, when there was a downturn in demand, 230 exploration wells and 93 development wells were drilled. The trends in the length of seismic surveys also demonstrate a high degree of activity in petroleum exploration, with 62,686 kilometres of seismics shot in 1980, rising to 87,295 kilometres in 1981 and 118 ,515 kilometres last year. In other words, within the parameters set by international conditions it is possible for a government to provide some encouragement through its Budget policies in the field of mineral exploration.

Regrettably, while the point was proven in the oil and gas sector, the same advantages have not been extended to the many exploration companies searching exclusively for minerals other than petroleum. Of course, those companies are visited by section 122J, which allows a deduction of exploration expenses from revenues derived by the taxpayer either directly or indirectly through mining. Unlike the petroleum explorer, the mineral explorer must have an income derived from mining against which exploration costs may be offset. Petroleum explorers may offset their exploration costs against income from any other source on the simple proviso that they satisfy the Commissioner of Taxation that their business carried on activities that included exploration for petroleum within Australia by way of definition.

These two provisions have a clear and discriminatory effect. Companies already deriving income from non-mining activity which diversify into petroleum exploration with the obvious intention of producing petroleum either by themselves or with joint venture partners receive a tax encouragement whereas similar companies diversifying into exploration for minerals other than petroleum are not similarly assisted. Looking at it perhaps from another angle, small petroleum exploration companies with an income derived from investing shareholders' funds receive this benefit, thereby allowing them to preserve their capital for longer and so engage in longer exploration programs. Small mineral exploration companies must meet not only their exploration costs from their revenues but also the full amount of the tax bill which arises as a result of their investments.

The funds which shareholders invest in a small mineral exploration company are therefore much more quickly dissipated than those in a small petroleum exploration company, allowing for a much shorter exploration program before the mineral explorer is forced to return to the capital fund raising market. In the present economic climate this presents mineral exploration companies, as one can imagine, with considerable problems. The companies engaged solely in mineral exploration spend more on exploration than they make out of mineral production yet they cannot claim all or part of their exploration costs as a deduction whereas petroleum exploration companies can. It is not a matter of the mineral exploration companies doing so well at present that they do not need assistance. They certainly do. The Australian Mining Industry Council's 1982 survey covering all alumina, copper, lead, zinc and nickel producers in Australia, and most of our iron ore and coal producers, shows a sharp decline in after-tax return on assets in the mining and exploration industry over the past three years. In fact after-tax returns were 2.5 per cent in 1982, down from 5.5 per cent in 1981 and 10.6 per cent the year before that. Of course, the effective return on funds in the mining and exploration industry last year was 3 per cent, with profits that were less than one-third of the 1981 level.

More than most other industries, the mining industry has been hard hit by the current recession but that does not mean that the need for exploration diminishes. As the world economy strengthens, demands for minerals will also grow again and when the capacity for existing mines is taken up there will be a need for new mines to be discovered and opened. It is essential that the initial exploration work be done now before that point is arrived at. The most prospective new areas must be identified and the preliminary studies must be undertaken well in advance of the recovery in demand because of the long lead times involved in opening new mines, often in remote parts of the country.

I urge the Government to consider encouraging exploration for minerals by extending the deductions, which currently apply under section 124AH of the Income Tax Assessment Act to petroleum exploration, to all forms of mineral exploration. If the Government is really committed to a lasting recovery and to providing future secure employment for all Australians, if it is really concerned to ensure the development of export industries in order to redress our present adverse balance of trade, it will adopt policies which assist the mining industry rather than harm it. I will be most interested to hear the views of the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McIntosh's account of the current deplorable human rights situation in Chile will have touched a responsive chord with all honourable senators concerned with the condition of liberty around the world. Of course, there is by and large bipartisan concern in this place about such matters as reflected, for example, in the substantial membership across all the parties of the Parliamentary Amnesty Group. I believe it is appropriate that Senator McIntosh should have drawn our attention to this matter tonight. As to the Government's attitude on this matter, I simply state that Australia has made clear on a number of occasions its concern at the human rights situation in Chile by supporting resolutions condemning it at meetings of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights and at the United Nations General Assembly. Australia's attitude in this respect is certainly known to the Chilean Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Commonwealth Ombudsman, Professor Richardson, and his staff would have been gratified at the extended consideration of the Ombudsman's report that was given here tonight by Senator Crowley. It is the case that the Ombudsman is doing a splendid job in helping to improve and maintain the quality of public administration in this country. It is further the case that the Ombudsman's report, as the Ombudsman himself has said and Senator Crowley has repeated, has had less than adequate attention in the Parliament each year in recent times. I believe it is again very appropriate that Senator Crowley should have taken the opportunity to give a more elaborate account of what was in that report than might otherwise have fallen upon the ears of honourable senators, let alone befallen their eyes.

As far as the matters raised by Senator Crichton-Browne are concerned, I pretend to neither expertise nor information in the areas to which he addressed himself tonight. But I will ensure that his remarks are addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, in order that he might give consideration to them and reply as he thinks fit.

I refer to just one other matter while I am on my feet. Senator Primmer took advantage today of the opportunities afforded by the first reading debate on a money Bill to repeat and to some extent to elaborate on a number of allegations that have now become familiar from him relating to the conduct of certain officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and, indeed, the conduct of the whole Department itself. In this respect he was taking further matters that were the subject of debate on the adjournment on the evening of 25 May and also of replying to the ministerial statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, in the House of Representatives on 26 May.

I simply say that I regard the raising again of these matters by Senator Primmer as unfortunate. Having now had the opportunity to read what Mr Hayden said in the other place on 26 May, I believe that although his remarks on that occasion were in some respects hard, they were in fact fair minded. I share Mr Hayden's hope that Senator Primmer, honestly and sincerely motivated as he may be, will perhaps refrain from further canvassing these matters in public, at least until the further reports on his allegations which are presently being compiled by the Public Service Board and the Ombudsman are in fact complete. I further hope that when these reports come into the public domain, or at least are completed, Senator Primmer will accept the conclusions of those reports, whatever they might be.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.47 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Has there been any case of confusion within the Defence forces in relation to the policy and procedures detailed in the DI(G) OPS 05-1 Policy and Procedures for Defence Force Assistance to the Civil Community and DI(G) OPS 01-2 'Defence Force Aid to the Civil Power' since the introduction of these policies and procedures. If so, what action was taken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Defence Instructions in question were first issued in 1978 for the particular purpose of clarifying for Defence Force personnel, policy and procedures regarding Defence Force assistance to the civil community and aid to the civil power. They were issued to all Service units for reference and permanent retention.

From time to time, since 1978, service units have indicated that they were uncertain as to the category of a particular request for assistance or aid and, in accord with referral arrangements built into the Defence Instructions themselves, have sought guidance from higher authority. Such requests were considered routine and to be expected, given the wide range and sometimes complex nature of individual requests.

Subsequent to the recent case of the request from the Attorney-General's Department for Royal Australian Air Force photographic surveillance over South West Tasmania, the Department is reviewing the instructions to see whether changes are required.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 3 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Under what circumstances are random samples of votes taken during the course of counting votes for a Senate election.
(2) What instructions are given to divisional returning officers about the way in which they are to choose random samples.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Section 135 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act sets out the procedures for conduct of the scrutiny in a Senate election. Sub-section (5) of that section sets out the procedures for the filling of the several vacancies and paragraph ( e) (v) of that sub-section sets out the requirement for each divisional returning officer to take ballot papers at random from the parcel containing the ballot papers of the elected candidate. Paragraphs (f), (g) and (h) of sub- section (5) also require that these procedures be followed in the successive distribution of surplus first preference votes.
(2) That section of the divisional returning officers' Standard Election Procedure Manual dealing with the Senate scrutiny refers to section 135 (5) and provides-
'When selecting ballot papers at random the ballot papers from which the random sample is to be taken should be placed face down on the table so that the vote upon the ballot papers cannot be seen'.

At the time of the 5 March 1983 Federal elections the Australian electoral officers for South Australia and Western Australia issued the following instructions to divisional returning officers in their respective States about the way they should choose random samples:

'When taking ballot papers at random the divisional returning officer should afford ballot papers an equal probability of continuing in the count and therefore there should be no selection criteria used in order to achieve this.
The following steps should be taken:
(a) All ballot papers must be faced downwards so that no markings are visible.

(b) Take at random from within each and every bundle of ballot papers concerned a number of ballot papers in proportion to the number to be transferred to a continuing candidate as against the number arranged. (Rather than take complete bundles or even a consecutive number of ballot papers within each bundle.)
Examples 1. 12,000 ballot papers to be transferred out of 24,000 (240 bundles) arranged. The proportion is 50 per cent. Therefore take 50 randomly from each of the 240 bundles.

2. 1,468 ballot papers to be transferred out of a total of 6,422 (65 bundles including one 'broken') arranged. The proportion is 22.85 per cent. Therefore take 23 out of most bundles and 22 out of others but ensure total take aggregates to 1,468.
(c) Following the taking at random the elected candidates ballot papers will be separated into two groups:
(i) the ballot papers which are to be transferred to each continuing candidate and remain in the count.
(ii) the ballot papers which are to be put aside as finally dealt with. These must be re-assembled, counted into bundles of 100s and 1,000s, wrapped, labelled , sealed and removed from the count.'
In Victoria the Australian Electoral Officer's instruction was as follows:
'At the fresh scrutiny band ballot papers in 100s and then 1,000s.
At all times when selecting ballot papers at random they must be faced downwards so no markings are visible.
Selection at random-break each bundle of 100 and select haphazardly from such bundle in proportion to the number of ballot papers to be transferred.
Re-assemble ballot papers selected at random and band in 100s.
Re-assemble ballot papers set aside in 100s. The banding of ballot papers in 100s and 1,000s is to be applied where practicable only.'
The Australian Electoral Officer for Tasmania issued the following instructions to his divisional returning officers:

'After completion of the second recheck of Senate ballot papers which should at that stage still be in counting centre parcels, you should then proceed to the amalgamation of these counting centre parcels of ballot papers to candidates as first preference votes. Your progressive total sheet should be used to ensure that at the amalgamation of each successive counting centre parcel the progressive balance of each candidate's first preference votes agrees.

At the time of this amalgamation or at any stage prior to this, under no circumstances should ballot papers in any candidate's parcels be blocked-that is to say sorted into parcels containing a straight ticket vote and parcels containing other than a straight ticket vote. The ballot papers should be allowed to mix freely throughout the total of the contents of that candidate's parcel of first preference votes.

When taking random selections from any parcel of ballot papers such random samples should be taken from the total ballot papers contained in that parcel. Under no circumstances should ballot papers only be taken from a portion of any parcel. You should further ensure that some ballot papers are taken from each and every bundle of ballot papers in the parcel.

When extracting a random sample of ballot papers all of the ballot papers from which the random sample is to be taken should be placed face down prior to the commencement of the taking of the random sample and all ballot papers both in relation to the random sample and those remaining should remain in this face down position until the completion of the taking of the random sample in order to ensure that at no stage can the votes on these ballot papers be seen and hence no suggestion made that the random sample has been in any way specifically selective.
Upon completion of the taking of the random samples all ballot papers to be set aside should be immediately parcelled, sealed and labelled as to their contents. '

The Australian Electoral Officer in Queensland issued no particular instructions on the procedures for random sampling. In his general pre-election instructions he reminded the divisional returning officers of the provisions of section 135 (5) (e) (v) in the following terms-

'Each divisional returning officer must be aware of his responsibility under section 135 (5) (e) (v) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act in regard to his random selection of Senate ballot papers and ensure that his procedures stand up to the scrutiny of scrutineers and are not to be found wanting should there be a recount.'

No instructions or reminders on random sampling were issued to the divisional returning officers in New South Wales or to the returning officers in the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 21 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What applications have been made recently to have acupuncture recognised by the Commonwealth as a speciality item.
(2) What decisions were taken in respect of such applications, and if these applications were rejected, what were the reasons for the rejection.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1 and 2) Acupuncture, when carried out by a registered medical practitioner, is covered by a specific item (Item 980) in the table of medical services contained in the schedule to the Health Insurance Act.

Where a medical practitioner who is recognised as a specialist for the purposes of the Act provides acupuncture treatment, benefits are payable under the acupuncture item only (Item 980). Benefits are not payable under any specialist consultation item.

No applications have been made to have acupuncture recognised as a specialty item. However, requests have been made to have the fee increased beyond that currently applying under Item 980, which is the equivalent to the fee for a standard surgery consultation by a general practitioner (6 to 25 minutes). These requests have mainly been received from specialists or their patients. No action has been taken on these requests for an increased fee as it has been considered that the current fee is reasonable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 21 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which health funds have at any time in the past or at present covered treatments by acupuncturists.
(2) How does such coverage operate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) On 1 April 1981 the Government introduced Item 980 into the table of medical services in the schedule to the Health Insurance Act to cover the services of acupuncture when rendered by a legally qualified medical practitioner.

All registered health insurance organisations providing medical benefits are required to pay benefits to insured persons for medical expenses incurred for acupuncture treatment rendered by legally qualified medical practitioners under Item 980.

Prior to 1 April 1981, attendances at which acupuncture was performed by a legally qualified medical practitioner attracted benefits under the appropriate consultation item. For example an acupuncture service by a general practitioner during an attendance lasting 20 minutes at his rooms would attract the schedule fee for a standard surgery consultation item. Again, all registered medical benefits organisations were obliged to pay benefits.

With regard to benefits for acupuncture services provided by non-medically qualified acupuncturists I am informed that there are nine registered health insurance funds which provide ancillary benefits towards the cost of such treatment, from supplementary/ancillary tables operated under the National Health Act. None of the other registered funds have offered such benefits in the past and subsequently deleted them. The names of the health funds concerned, and details of the benefits provided, are as follows:
*Army Health Benefits Society (all States): A benefit of $6 per service by a registered acupuncturist in private practice with a limit of $50 per person per year.

*Cheetham Hospital Benefits Fund (Victoria): Provides a benefit equal to 50 per cent of the fee charged by an acupuncturist. A limit of $400 per member per year applies to benefits paid for any ancillary services.

*Government Employees Medical and Hospital Club (New South Wales): A benefit of up to $9 per service where treatment is rendered by a recognised acupuncturist. A limit of $300 per person per year applies to the aggregate of benefits paid in respect of treatment rendered by a recognised acupuncturist, physiotherapist, chiropractor, chiropodist or speech therapist.
*Naval Health Benefits Society (all States): A benefit of $10 per service with an annual maximum of $100 per person.

*Reserve Bank Health Society (all States): A benefit of $12 per visit with a maximum of $200 in any one year for acupuncture treatment when referred by a medical practitioner for a specific ailment requiring essential treatment.

The Hospitals Contribution Fund of Australia (New South Wales): A benefit of up to $8 per service when rendered by a qualified acupuncturist accredited with the Acupuncture Ethics and Standards Organisation. No maximum ceiling in any one year.
The Latrobe Valley Hospitals and Health Services Association (Victoria): A benefit of $8 per service. A limit of $250 per year applies to benefits paid for all ancillary services.

The Manchester Unity Independent Order of Odd Fellows in Victoria: A benefit of $7 per service for acupuncture treatment when rendered by a registered chiropractor with an annual maximum of $100 for a single member and $200 for a family member.
*Queensland Teachers' Union Health Society: A benefit up to $8 per service by an acupuncturist recognised by the Society with a limit of $100 per calendar year per person.
*Restricted membership funds.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 21 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it compulsory for cigarette manufacturers to display the warning ' smoking is a health hazard' in a prominent position on cigarette packets; if so, why is it not compulsory for the warning to be displayed on packages of cigarette tobacco as well.

(2) Is it also compulsory to display information regarding the tar content in tobacco on cigarette packets and are batches of the products tested regularly to determine the authenticity of the tar content figures that some cigarette packets display, since they are claimed to be determined by Government method.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. During a period prior to 1973 legislation was introduced nationally and in all States and Territories requiring the statement 'Warning-smoking is a health hazard' to be placed prominently on cigarette packets. The dates of commencement ranged from 1 January 1973 to 1 July 1973.

The statement is not required on packets of cigarette tobacco because a decision was taken at that time to concentrate on manufactured cigarettes, which account for approximately 90 per cent of tobacco sales.

(2) It is not compulsory for tar and nicotine yields to appear on cigarette packets. This labelling is in accordance with the voluntary code in respect of CPM ('tar') and nicotine labelling on cigarette packaging, which was jointly agreed to by representatives of the tobacco industry and the former Federal Government.

The voluntary code requires all primary cigarette packages manufactured or landed in Australia to have printed on one side panel the corrected particulate matter (CPM) (sometimes referred to as 'tar'), and nicotine yield per cigarette of the brand concerned.
The code provides for a modified form of 'banding' of tar and nicotine yields, and for maximum yield limits for tar and nicotine of 18 mg and 1.6 mg respectively.

Cigarette brands are routinely tested under the cigarette testing program to ensure that the tar and nicotine yields fall within the stated bands. This is a collaborative program between the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories (AGAL), which conducts the tests on behalf of my Department, and the tobacco industry. The testing method and the machines conform to the International Standards Organisation standard.

There have been unavoidable delays in the testing program owing to technical problems in AGAL's cigarette testing laboratory. However, testing has resumed and the results are expected to be available at the end of 1983 or early 1984.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 22 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have any charges been brought against any cadets following recent allegations of mistreatment of cadets at the Royal Military College, Duntroon, during 1983; if so, how many cadets have been charged.
(2) What staff were on duty at the times of the alleged offences by cadets.
(3) Have any charges been brought against any staff arising from the actions of cadets; if so, how many staff have been charged.
(4) Are the duty staff considered adequate to maintain good order and military discipline.
(5) At what stage in their training are cadets instructed in military law and the differences between lawful and unlawful orders.
(6) Were the cadets accused of misconduct present at the whole of the hearings into their alleged misconduct and was the evidence taken in writing.

(7) Were the accused made aware of the provisions of section 141 (1) (a) of the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 and given the opportunity to prepare their defence or choose a person to represent or advise them.

(8) Has the treatment of the accused cadets been strictly in accordance with the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 and has their treatment been used to cover up for members of the Defence Force who, by act or omission, have negligently performed a duty required by their office or appointment.
(9) Will the Minister for Defence refer all these cases to the Defence Force Ombudsman for his consideration, before any cadet is discharged.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questons:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (9) I refer the honourable senator to my statement on 11 May 1983 in the House of Representatives (Hansard page 417).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Support, upon notice, on 4 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Was the information supplied to Senator Colston in answer to Question No. 2585 ( Hansard, 27 October 1982, page 1923) correct; namely, that no chain was purchased from overseas sources by the Department of Defence Support or the Department of Administrative Services during 1981-82 on behalf of the Navy, the Royal Australian Air Force and the Army; if not (a) was a contract to the value of $43,552 let on 3 November 1981 to a Korean firm to supply chain for the Australian Navy; (b) was the tender number for this contract 2137213U; and (c) what was the reason for incorrect information being provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Support has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to question No. 2585 was incorrect.

(a) 1. No. 2. The value of the contract was $20,475. 3. Tenders for this requirement closed on 3 November 1981. 4. The contract was placed on 13 May 1982 by the Department of Administrative Services. 5. The contract was placed on Pitt Waddell Bennett Chains Ltd, Victoria, who are agents for a Korean manufacturer.
(b) Yes.
(c) The item was recorded incorrectly in the computer data base.
